Question: A 3-year-old girl was brought to the clinic by her parents because of failure to thrive. They mentioned that she had been eating and drinking well but has not gained weight in 3 months, and in fact she has lost about 0.5 kg. On further questioning, they acknowledge that she has been irritable for many months now and has had a diminished appetite. There has been no vomiting or diarrhea. Her past medical history includes resolution of mild eczema at age 2 years and otitis media treated with amoxicillin at age 2.5 years. On physical exam, her weight is 12.3 kg (5th percentile) and her height is 89 cm (10th percentile). Head circumference is normal. She appears pale and her mucous membranes are dry. No oral thrush is seen. Respiratory, cardiac, and abdominal examinations are normal. Neurologic examination reveals no focal deficits, but there is a delay in fine motor skills and lack of interest in toys. No rash is seen. A fasting blood glucose is 130 mg/dL and hemoglobin A1c is 9.8%. Of the following, the most likely cause of this patient’s weight loss is: 
Options: A: Type 1 diabetes mellitus
B: Type 2 diabetes mellitus
C: Inflammatory bowel disease
D: Excessive caffeine intake
E: Phenylketonuria
Answer: A

Question: A 40-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension is being treated with metformin and enalapril. He comes to the emergency department with new-onset, mid-epigastric pain that is severe and sharp. The pain has persisted for the past 4 hours and is unrelated to meals. He denies heartburn, nausea, and vomiting. His vital signs are as follows: temperature 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure 160/110 mm Hg, pulse 84/min, and respirations 20/min. Examination reveals epigastric tenderness, and bowel sounds are slightly decreased. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.4 mg/dL
Leukocyte count 10,400/mm3
Aspartate transaminase 41 U/L
Alanine transaminase 55 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase 210 U/L
Total bilirubin 1.2 mg/dL
Lipase 180 U/L
Amylase 172 U/L
Sodium 138 mEq/L
Potassium 4.2 mEq/L
Chloride 107 mEq/L
Calcium 8.8 mg/dL
Glucose 250 mg/dL
Blood urea 26 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
. What are not the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Enalapril
B: Metformin
C: Hyperparathyroidism
D: Alcoholic pancreatitis
E: Diabetic ketoacidosis
Answer: A,C,D,E

Question: A 40-year-old patient is brought into the emergency department after suffering a motor vehicle crash where he was pinned underneath his motorcycle for about 30 minutes before a passerby called 911. While evaluating him per your institution's trauma guidelines, you discover pain upon palpation of his right lower extremity which is much larger than his left counterpart. The patient admits to decreased sensation over his right lower extremity and cannot move his leg. There are no palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses on this extremity, and it is colder and paler in comparison to his left side. Measured compartment pressure of his distal right leg is 35 mm Hg. What are the next best step in this patient's care? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Emergent fasciotomy
B: Emergent fasciectomy
C: Emergent fasciotomy
D: Emergent division of fascia
E: Internal fixation

Question: A 65-year-old man presents with painless swelling of the neck over the past week. He also says he has been having intermittent fevers and severe night sweats which require a change of bed sheets the next day. His past medical history is significant for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) diagnosed 10 years ago with which he admits to not always being compliant with his antiretroviral medication. The patient reports a 20-pack-year smoking history but no alcohol or recreational drug use. A review of systems is significant for a 6 kg (13.2 lb) unintentional weight loss over the past 2 months. The vital signs include: temperature 37.8℃ (100.0℉) and blood pressure 120/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, there are multiple non-tender swollen lymph nodes averaging 2 cm in diameter that is palpable in the anterior and posterior triangles of the neck bilaterally. Axillary and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present on the right side. A cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. The spleen size is 16 cm on percussion. Laboratory studies show the following:
Hemoglobin 9 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 88 μm3
Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3
Platelet count 130,000/mm3
    Serum creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Serum lactate dehydrogenase 1,000 U/L
An excisional biopsy of a superficial axillary lymph node on the right is performed and a histopathologic analysis confirms the most likely diagnosis. Which of the following are the next best diagnostic step in the workup of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Antinuclear antibody
B: Hepatitis C virus antibodies
C: JAK-2 mutation
D: Peripheral blood flow cytometry
E: Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) test

Question: A 24-year-old woman presents to a physician with acute intolerable abdominal pain and vomiting. On examination, there is a mass on the rectum on rectal examination. The patient is then rushed to the operating room for laparoscopic resection of the mass. A tumor arising from the colonic mucosa is found blocking 70% of the lumen. Which of the following are the most likely complications of this tumor? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Melena
B: Anemia
C: Nausea and vomiting
D: Diarrhea
E: Loss of appetite
Answer: B,C,E

Question: A previously healthy 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of an abdominal mass noticed a few days ago. He appears markedly pale and lethargic. Examination shows a 6-cm, nonmobile mass in the left upper quadrant that crosses the midline. 24-hour urine collection shows elevated homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid. Further evaluation including biopsy confirms the diagnosis of intermediate-risk neuroblastoma. The physician recommends the established standard treatment, which is initiation of neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgical resection, if possible. After a thorough discussion of the risks and benefits of chemotherapy, the likelihood of unresectability without neoadjuvant treatment, and the prognosis without it, the patient's parents steadily refuse chemotherapy because they do not want their son to suffer the side effects. They prefer to take their son home for supportive care only. Which of the following are the most appropriate action by the physician? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Help the parents to arrange supportive care at home
B: Seek a court order for neoadjuvant chemotherapies
C: Recommend for parents to take 2 weeks to think about decision
D: Seek a court order for neoadjuvant chemotherapy
E: Survey.seek a court orders for neoadjuvant chemotherapies

Question: A 43-year-old woman with a history of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) visits her physician because she has been experiencing dizziness for the past month. She also reports unsteady gait and a sensation of pressure in the back of her head. She had a similar episode 10 years ago. This episode is not preceded by upper respiratory symptoms. She denies nausea, vomiting, fever, chills, or syncope. Examination during this visit shows horizontal nystagmus on rightward gaze but no other abnormalities. The physician suspects a recurrence of BPPV and prescribes a 24-hour course of meclizine. After 1 week, she returns to the office for follow-up. Her symptoms have not improved. She repeatedly denies any hearing loss or ringing in her ears. Vital signs are stable. The physician prescribes metoprolol and performs the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
Options: A: Perform cervical MRI
B: Perform audiometry
C: Prescribe a course of prednisone
D: Prescribe a course of acyclovir
E: Refer the patient to a vestibular rehabilitation therapist.
Answer: E

Question: A 44-year-old man presents to the family medicine clinic for some small bumps on his left thigh. The lesions are non-pruritic and have been present for the last 3 weeks. He reports feeling fatigued and malaise for the past few months. The patient has no known medical problems and takes no medications. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and uses intravenous street drugs. His heart rate is 82/min, the respiratory rate is 14/min, the temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), and the blood pressure is 126/80 mm Hg. Auscultation of the heart is without murmurs. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Three 2-3 mm, dome-shaped, hardened papules are noted on the left thigh. Central umbilication can be observed in each papule. There is a non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy present. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Kaposi sarcoma
B: Molluscum contagiosum
C: Molluscum contagiosum
D: Atopic dermatitis
E: Acute urticaria

Question: A 44-year-old man presents to the family medicine clinic for some small bumps on his left thigh. The lesions are non-pruritic and have been present for the last 3 weeks. Question: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the physician for evaluation and management of shortness of breath. The shortness of breath began 6 months ago and has been getting worse. He has also noted peripheral edema in his feet and ankles over the past 2 weeks. He denies chest pain, palpitations, syncope, or dyspnea on exertion. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 168/100 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 20/min, and temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Examination of the heart shows an S3 gallop. There is pitting edema in the feet and ankles. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Acute renal failure
B: Chronic heart failure
C: Acute pulmonary embolism
D: COPD
E: Aortic stenosis
Answer: A,C,D

Question: A 35-year-old woman presents to a psychiatrist for an initial consultation. She reports that for the past 3 years, she has experienced several periods of depressed mood. The episodes do not coincide with any specific life events and seem to resolve after 4-6 weeks. During these episodes, she experiences a depressed mood, sleep disturbances, and a poor appetite, but she at times is able to enjoy spending time with her children and husband but other times she is distressed and cannot enjoy time with them. Upon further questioning, she also reports experiencing occasional episodes of elevated mood over the past ten years. During these episodes, she is very productive at her work as a lawyer and requires less sleep than usual. Her past medical history is notable for obesity, type I diabetes mellitus, and rheumatoid arthritis. She is on insulin and takes methotrexate. She smokes marijuana occasionally. Her temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 17/min. On exam, she is quiet with a flattened affect, but is cooperative and answers questions thoroughly. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Bipolar I disorder
B: Cyclothymic personalities
C: Cyclothymic disorder
D: Persistent depressive disorder
E: Affectiv personality nos

Question: A previously healthy 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of fever and headache. His symptoms began 4 days ago when he developed fevers to 103°F (39.4°C), associated with headache, sore throat, rhinorrhea, and nonproductive cough. Ibuprofen provided temporary relief of his pain, but his temperature would return to 102°F (38.9°C) within a few hours. The headache gradually increased in intensity over the past 3 days, and he came today because it is now unremitting. He has no nausea or vomiting. His cough is worse at night. He denies stiff neck, photophobia, or vision changes. His temperature now is 102°F (38.9°C), pulse is 132/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 120/74 mmHg. Examination of the head, eyes, ears, nose, and throat shows tonsillar hypertrophy, injected conjunctiva, and clear nasal discharge. He has tiny petechiae on the soft palate. Auscultation of the lungs reveals normal breath sounds with a few scattered wheezes. Cardiac examination demonstrates normal rate and rhythm without murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Examination of the abdomen, extremities, and neurologic systems is entirely normal. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Measles
B: Meningitis
C: Viral pharyngitis
D: Influenza
E: Sinusitis
Answer: B,E

Question: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the police. He was found unconscious and covered in bruises outside of a local bar. The patient has a past medical history of polysubstance abuse, depression, multiple suicide attempts, neuropathic pain, and schizophrenia. As part of the patient’s initial workup, a head CT is performed which is unremarkable, and an arterial blood gas is performed as seen below:

pH: 7.29
PaCO2: 95 mm Hg
PaO2: 70 mm Hg
Bicarbonate: 24 mEq/L

. Which of the following are the most likely etiology of this patient’s current presentation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Alcohol
B: Heroin
C: Cocaine
D: Heroin
E: Heroin

. Which of the following are not the most likely etiology of this patient’s current presentation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Alcohol
B: Heroin
C: Cocaine
D: Heroin
E: Heroin

Question: A 35-year-old woman presents to the office with a 3-week history of post-coital vaginal bleeding. For the past 3 years, she has experienced abnormal uterine bleeding characterized by heavy menses and prolonged duration (lasting 7–10 days). She also reports pain and bloating in her lower abdomen. She had one pregnancy, which a normal vaginal delivery 5 years ago. Her last pap smear was 2 years ago and was normal. She has no other medical problems. Physical examination shows moderate tenderness to palpation of the uterus and ovaries. No masses are palpable. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Ultrasonography
B: Endometrial biopsy
C: Curettage and hysteroscopy
D: Dilation and curettage
E: Electrocautery of the endometrium
Answer: C

Question: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being in a motor vehicle accident (MVA). On examination, the patient has severe shortness of breath, tachycardia, and hypotension. Inspiration and expiration produce a classic "crunching" sound. A chest X-ray would be expected to show which of the following? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Bilateral pneumothorax
B: Unilateral pneumothorax
C: Subcutaneous emphysema
D: Mediastinal emphysema
E: Aortic rupture
Answer: C,D

Question: A 9-month-old boy is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for a routine health checkup. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. He was breastfed for the first 3 months and then switched to cow’s milk and about two months ago she started giving him fruits and vegetables. Family history is noncontributory. Today, his heart rate is 120/min, respiratory rate is 40/min, blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg, and temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F). On examination, he has a heartbeat with a regular rate and rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Generally, the boy looks pale. His weight and height fall within the expected range. A complete blood count (CBC) shows the following:
Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.1 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): 65 fL
Total iron binding capacity (TIBC): 550 μg/dL
Serum iron: 45 µg/dL
Serum lead: < 5 µg/dL
. What are the best treatment for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Iron supplementation only
B: Proper diet and iron supplementation
C: Multivitamins
D: Proper diet only
E: Lead chelation therapy

Question: A 38-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a 6-month history of double vision. For the past 2 years, she has had periods of tingling and numbness in her hands. She has a 10-pound weight gain over the past 2 months. Over time, she has noticed a decreased sensation of thirst. Her level of alertness has also recently declined, and she is frequently sleepy during the day. She denies fever, chills, sweats, or headache. Her blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg, and her pulse is 48 beats/ minute. Examination shows ptosis and diplopia. She has slight proptosis bilaterally, and nystagmus on side-to-side gaze. Her tongue is enlarged and furred, and she has a dry mouth. On examination, her skin is dry and her hair is excessively brittle. On neurologic examination, she is slow to react questions, but oriented to person, place, and time. Sensation is diminished in both hands with reduced response to pinprick and vibration. She has absent reflexes in her lower extremities, but brisk reflexes in the upper extremities. She walks with difficulty due to both bilateral foot-drop and a shuffling gait. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: MRI of the eye globes
B: Thyroid stimulation hormone levels
C: CT scan of the orbit
D: Thyroid ultrasonography
E: Serum anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies
Answer: B,E

Question: A 56-year-old woman is being seen for a follow-up visit 2 weeks after she began therapy with gabapentin for postherpetic neuralgia. She reports that the new medication has significantly reduced the burning pain and has helped her sleep. The physician notes that while she was previously unsteady on her feet, she now walks normally. Although she has had constipation, she has managed this problem with fiber supplements. Today, her blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Physical examination is otherwise normal. Which of the following is not the best plan for this patient?
Options: A: Continue gabapentin therapy at the current dose.
B: Gradually increase the dose of gabapentin to a maximum of 1800 mg/day if the current dose causes additional constipation.
C: Add a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor to the patient’s regimen to improve postherpetic neuralgia symptoms.
D: Avoid long-term use of gabapentin because of its risk of psychiatric side effects.
Answer: C

Question: A 45-year-old woman comes into your office with complaints of "lump" she found on her neck while showering. She denies any other symptoms and states that she has not gained any weight. On exam, you notice a 2 cm nodule on her anterior neck. Her TSH level is normal and radionucleotide scan reveals a cold nodule. Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) reveals follicular architecture suspicious for malignancy. What are the next best step? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Punch biopsy
B: Surgical excision
C: Removal techniques
D: Ultrasound
E: CT scan

Question: A 45-year-old woman comes into your office with complaints of "lump" she found on her neck while showering. She denies any other symptoms and states that she has not gained any weight. Question: A 35-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for routine physical examination. His symptom history is benign, with no complaints. His last physical examination was 5 years ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. His physical exam is reassuring, however, he is noted to have an enlarged spleen that extends to the pelvis on his abdominal exam. The patient denies any blood transfusions, blood clot history, or chronic illnesses. During his workup, he is found to have the following lab results:
Hemoglobin 10.5 gm/dL
Hematocrit 34%
MCV 85 fL
Platelets 110,000/mcL
WBC 8,000/mcL
Differential showed:
Neutrophils 76%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 4%. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Splenomegaly
B: Polycythemia vera
C: Primary myelofibrosis
D: Gaucher disease
E: Chronic myelogenous leukemia
Answer: D

Question: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with weakness. He states that it started yesterday and has been progressively worsening. Initially, he noticed blurry vision and some trouble speaking and swallowing but thought he was just coming down with a cold. He then noticed weakness of his facial muscles and shortness of breath. The patient works as a farmer and harvests and cans his own foods. He has had diarrhea recently and a cough prior to these symptoms of weakness. His temperature is 97.9°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 144/94 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a man who seems unable to smile with dysarthric speech. He takes shallow and weak breaths on pulmonary exam. The patient demonstrates 3/5 strength with diminished reflexes in his upper extremities. The patient is subsequently intubated. Which of the following are the best treatment for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Antitoxin
B: Atropine
C: Neostigmine
D: Plasmapheresis
E: Riluzole

Question: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 1 month after undergoing a right total hip arthroplasty for osteoarthritis. She is well and her recovery has been uneventful. After the surgery, she was given phenprocoumon (Coumadin) 5 mg once daily, which she takes every morning. Today, her prothrombin time (PT) is 28 seconds. PT prior to surgery was 10 seconds (therapeutic range: 12–15 seconds). Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Discontinue Coumadin
B: Ask the patient to hold Coumadin and stop taking it for 1 day
C: Ask the patient to take an extra dose of Coumadin tonight
D: Give the patient a single dose of 10 mg vitamin K
E: Give the patient a single dose of 25 mg vitamin K
Answer: D

Question: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of episodes of difficulty swallowing for the past 3 months. He feels solid food getting stuck in his chest behind the sternum when he eats. Drinking does not cause any difficulty swallowing. He has no coughing or nasal regurgitation. He has no hoarseness or weight loss. He has had heartburn for 2 years with no response to high-dose omeprazole. His past medical history is also significant for asthma and eczema. He takes no medications except for omeprazole. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormal findings. Which of the following best explains these findings? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Achalasia
B: Diffuse esophageal spasm
C: Eosinophilic esophagitis
D: Esophageal reflux disease
E: Eosinophilic esophagitis

Question: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of episodes of difficulty swallowing for the past 3 months. He feels solid food getting stuck in his chest behind the sternum when he eats. Drinking does not cause any difficulty swallowing. He has no coughing or nasal regurgitation. He has no hoarseness or weight loss. D: Esophageal reflux disease
E: Eosinophilic esophagitis

Question: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of acute-onset chest pain that radiates to her left arm. The pain began approximately 2 hours ago at rest and has gradually intensified. It is associated with nausea, vomiting, diaphoresis, and dyspnea. On arrival to the emergency department, her vital signs are as follows: temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F), heart rate 110/min, blood pressure 145/90 mm Hg and respirations 18/min. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and clear lungs. Cardiac auscultation reveals a regular tachycardia with no murmurs or gallops. The electrocardiogram indicates ST-elevation in leads V1–V3. Which of the following are the most likely cause of her pain? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Myocardial infarction
B: Pulmonary embolism
C: Pericarditis
D: Aortic dissection
E: Costochondritis
Answer: A,D

Question: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because her left eye has been red and swollen since waking up this morning. She says the redness and swelling are getting worse. She has no difficulty seeing and notes no pain, itching, or sensitivity to light. She also has noted increased tearing in her left eye compared to the right eye. She has no history of eye pain, swelling, or redness, or of any eye procedures or injuries. She is in good health and takes no medications. On examination, her blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and temperature is 37.2°C (99°F). Examination of her eyes reveals conjunctival edema and injection that are most prominent on the left. There is no iritis or corneal injury. Examination of the oropharynx is unremarkable. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Scleritis
B: Acute angle-closure glaucoma
C: Infectious conjunctivitis
D: Grave's disease
E: Episcleritis
Answer: A,B,D

Question: A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Two weeks ago, while visiting Guatemala, she had an emergency appendectomy under general inhalational anesthesia. During the surgery, she received a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F) and blood pressure is 138/76 mm Hg. Examination shows jaundice and tender hepatomegaly. Serum studies show:
Alkaline phosphatase 102 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase 760 U/L
Bilirubin
Total 3.8 mg/dL
Direct 3.1 mg/dL
Anti-HAV IgG positive
Anti-HAV IgM negative
Anti-HBs positive
HBsAg negative
Anti-HCV antibodies negative
Abdominal ultrasonography shows an enlarged liver. A biopsy of the liver shows massive centrilobular necrosis. Which of the following are the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Acalculous inflammation of the gallbladder
B: Virus-mediated hepatocellular injury
C: Trauma to the bile duct
D: Adverse effect of anesthetic
E: Gram-negative bacteria in the bloodstream

Question: A 39-year-old man comes to the office because of right foot pain. The pain began 3 weeks ago after he injured his foot while playing basketball. Examination shows right foot hallux valgus, tenderness, and mild erythema to palpation over the medial aspect of the head of the first metatarsal; the range of motion of the right great toe is normal. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Hallux limitus
B: Hallux rigidus
C: Bunion
D: Osteoarthritis
E: Gout
Answer: A,B,D

Question: A 55-year-old man presents with bloody nasal secretions and shortness of breath. He reports he has lost 4 kg (8.8 lb) in the last two months with no changes in his diet. He has also been suffering from mild to moderate joint pain in the left knee for the last year. His past medical history is unremarkable. His vitals include: blood pressure 120/70 mm Hg, temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉), pulse 70/min, respiratory rate 14/min. Physical examination is significant for nasal ulcers. Diffuse crackles are present over all lobes of the lung bilaterally. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
Hemoglobin 12.9 g/dL
Hematocrit 37.7%
Leukocyte count 5500/mm3
Neutrophils 65%
Lymphocytes 30%
Monocytes 5%
Mean corpuscular volume 82.2 μm3
Platelet count 190,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 35 mm/h
C-reactive protein 14 mg/dL
Creatinine 3.09 mg/dL
The patient is prescribed a corticosteroid nasal spray and oral antibiotics but returns in 2 weeks without any clinical improvement. Which of the following would most likely confirm the diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Anti-citrullinated protein antibodies
B: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
C: Anti-histone bodies
D: Anti-Ro
E: Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies

Question: A 51-year-old male comes to the emergency department because of an unprovoked seizure. He was found lying on his living room floor by his wife. He was taken to the emergency department in an ambulance. He comes from a rural area where he lives in a small house with no running water. He is currently unemployed and has a history of polysubstance abuse, including crack cocaine, alcohol, and methamphetamine. He has a history of hypertension, for which he takes no medications. On physical examination, he is no longer seizing. His pulse is 100/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral rales that may be pneumonia. Examination of the heart shows ejection systolic murmur that is grade 2 of 6 in intensity. The liver is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. A chest x‑ray shows a right upper lobe infiltrate. Laboratory studies show:
WBC count 1900/mm3
Sodium 128 mEq/L
Potassium 2.7 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen 33 mg/dL
Creatinine 9.0 mg/dL
Glucose 85 mg/dL
Albumin 2.1 g/dL
International normalized ratio 1.3
Aspartate aminotransferase 50 IU/L (normal, ≤ 40)
Alanine aminotransferase 30 IU/L (normal, ≤ 40)
Total bilirubin 2.0 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 1.3 mg/dL
Urinalysis:
pH 5.0
Blood 2+
Glucose 1+
Ketones 4+
leukocyte count 1-2/hpf
Which of the following are the most appropriate treatment for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Saline replacement
B: Furosemide
C: Flumazenil
D: Intravenous thiamine
E: Vancomycin
Answer: A,D

Question: A 78-year-old woman had difficulty speaking and understanding others the previous day but woke up this morning unable to speak. She has a medical history of hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation. Her current medications include metoprolol, Losartan, atorvastatin, warfarin, and metformin. She is a former smoker but quit 20 years ago. She does not drink alcohol. Her family history is remarkable for cardiovascular disease and hyperlipidemia. What is the most likely cause of this patient's sudden-onset dysarthria and aphasia?
Options: A: Ruptured cerebral aneurysm
B: Drug and alcohol-induced stroke
C: Ischemic stroke in the distribution of the right middle cerebral artery
D: Hemorrhagic stroke in the distribution of the left middle cerebral artery
E: Transient ischemic attack in the distribution of the right posterior cerebral artery
Answer: D

Question: A 2-day-old infant male is brought to the emergency department with a 5-hour history of vomiting and irritability. He was born at home and had unreliable prenatal care because his parents have been experiencing housing instability. About a day after birth, he started to become lethargic and was feeding poorly. His parents thought that he might just be tired so they put him to bed; however, by the next morning he started to vomit and act extremely irritable. On presentation, he is found to have nuchal rigidity and bulging fontanelles. Based on this presentation, appropriate cultures are obtained and he is placed on empiric antibiotics. After all cultures grow out the same gram-positive bacteria, the patient is narrowed to penicillin G. Which of the following are a characteristic of the most likely organism that is causing this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Enlarges hemolytic area of s. aureus
B: Enlarges hemolytic area of Staphylococcus aureus
C: Produces lipooligosaccharide rather than lipopolysaccharide
D: Produces toxin that increases cAMP levels
E: Enlarges hemolytic area of staphylococcus aureus subsp. anaerobius

Question: A 2-day-old infant male is brought to the emergency department with a 5-hour history of vomiting and irritability. E: Enlarges hemolytic area of staphylococcus aureus subsp. anaerobius

Question: A 55-year-old male with a history of stage I colon cancer status-post left hemicolectomy presents to your office for follow-up. You intend to discuss the results from his recent surveillance colonoscopy, which showed no remaining cancer, no polyps, and a well-healed anastmosis. During your meeting, you note that the patient is exhibiting the defense mechanism of suppression. Which of the following statements from the patient are consistent with your impression? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: "i really haven't thoughts about the colonoscopy until today. worrying before getting the results wasn't going to help anything."
B: "i really haven't thought about the colonoscopy until today. worrying before getting the results wasn't going to help anything."
C: "i really haven't thinking about the colonoscopy until today. worrying before getting the results wasn't going to help anything."
D: "Ever since I had the colonoscopy, I've been having headaches and backaches and just pain all over! I'm sure it's from the cancer."
E: "I really haven't thought about the colonoscopy until today. Worrying before getting the results wasn't going to help anything."

Question: A 35-year-old woman is seen in the infertility clinic because she has been unable to conceive after 1 year of trying. She has never been pregnant. She denies any abnormal vaginal discharge or any change in her menstrual cycle. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing cervix, uterus, and adnexa. A postcoital test shows no sperm in the cervical mucus. A hysterosalpingogram shows that both fallopian tubes are patent. The husband's semen analysis reveals normal sperm counts and motility. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Intrauterine insemination
B: Clomiphene citrate
C: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone
D: In vitro fertilization
E: Hysterectomy
Answer: A,B

Question: A 20-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine checkup. He has been healthy and takes no medications. He is sexually active only with his long-term girlfriend, and he uses no form of contraception. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg, temperature 37°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, and respirations 12/min. His examination is normal. Which of the following is not a cost-effective screening test for this patient?
Options: A: Influenza vaccine
B: PPD
C: Monospot test
D: Hepatitis C antibody
E: HIV antibody
Answer: D

Question: A 62-year-old woman with small-cell lung cancer comes to the physician because of a painful, burning red rash on her face and hands that developed 30 minutes after going outside to do garden work. She wore a long-sleeved shirt and was exposed to direct sunlight for about 10 minutes. The patient is light-skinned and has a history of occasional sunburns when she does not apply sunscreen. Current medications include demeclocycline for malignancy-associated hyponatremia and amoxicillin for sinusitis. Physical examination shows prominent erythema and a papular eruption on her forehead, cheeks, neck, and the dorsum of both hands. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Unspecified cells injuries resulting drug metabolites
B: Formation of drug-induced autoantibodies
C: Obsolete cell inj due drug metabolites
D: Accumulation of porphobilinogen
E: Cell injury due to drug metabolites

Question: A 62-year-old woman with small-cell lung cancer comes to the physician because of a painful, burning red rash on her face and hands that developed 30 minutes after going outside to do garden work. She wore a long-sleeved shirt and was exposed to direct sunlight for about 10 minutes. The patient is light-skinned and has a history of occasional sunburns when she does not apply sunscreen. Current medications include demeclocycline for malignancy-associated hyponatremia and amoxicillin for sinusitis. Physical examination shows prominent erythema and a papular eruption on her forehead, cheeks, neck, and the dorsum of both hands. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Unspecified cells injuries resulting drug metabolites
B: Formation of drug-induced autoantibodies
C: Obsolete cell inj due drug metabolites
D: Accumulation of porphobilinogen
E: Cell injury due to drug metabolites

Question: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of generalized abdominal pain and bloating of 3 years' duration. When she presses on her abdomen, she has mild pain and discomfort. She denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation. She has noticed weight gain around her waist, although her weight has remained the same for the past year. She has a history of hidradenitis suppurativa involving her axillae and buttocks which has been treated with incision and drainage in the past. Examination shows obesity, acne, hirsutism, and hyperpigmentation of the knuckles. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Diet high in refined carbohydrates
B: Deficiency of gonadotropin-releasing hormone
C: Cushing disease
D: Pancreatic insufficiency
E: Polycystic ovary syndrome
Answer: E

Question: A 54-year-old woman presents for a routine follow-up appointment with her endocrinologist. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 5 years ago and has been taking 400 mg of metformin 4 times per day. She reports that her recent blood glucose levels have been high despite the metformin. Her glucose level on examination today is 440 mg/dL. The physician adds pramlintide to her treatment plan. Which of the following is not the most appropriate education given to the patient regarding this medication? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Pramlintide mimics the effects of glucagon.
B: Pramlintide is given before meals.
C: Pramlintide helps prevent metabolic acidosis.
D: Pramlintide increases satiety by slowing gastric emptying.
E: Pramlintide suppresses hyperglycemia.
Answer: A,B,C

Question: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. The patient reports severe pelvic pain. Pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. Current medications include insulin, folic acid, and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The cervix is 100% effaced and 10 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. The fetal heart rate is reactive with no decelerations. Epidural anesthesia is performed and the patient's symptoms improve. Ten minutes later, the patient has dizziness. Her pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following are the most likely underlying cause of the patient's hypotension? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Decreased cardiac contractility
B: Sympathetic block
C: Hypovolemia
D: Acute pulmonary hypertension
E: Aortocaval compression

Question: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department 1 day after his sudden onset of slurred speech, right-sided weakness, and decreased vision in his right eye. Examination shows a right homonymous hemianopia, right facial droop, dysarthria, and right hemiparesis. His past medical history shows he has atrial fibrillation (AF) and coronary artery disease (CAD). A computed tomography (CT) scan of his head is shown. Which of the following conditions are not the most likely cause of this patient's stroke? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Atrial fibrillation
B: Ischemic stroke
C: Cerebral infarction
D: Thrombotic stroke
E: Embolic stroke
Answer: B,C

Question: A 65-year-old woman schedules an appointment with her physician for evaluation of weight loss and weakness. The weakness is more noticeable when climbing stairs and combing hair. The weakness improves after brief exercise. She also has bladder incontinence for the past 4 weeks and was given an anticholinesterase agent with no improvement. What are the most likely cause of the symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Botulism
B: Paraneoplastic syndrome from small cells cancer of lung
C: Hypothyroidism
D: Paraneoplastic syndromes from small cell cancer of lung
E: Paraneoplastic syndrome from small cell carcinoma of the lung

Question: A 24-year-old woman presents to a physician with a history of exposure to a close friend who was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. She was told by her friend that she need to see a physician because she needs to be treated as well, even if she is not having symptoms yet. She currently denies any headaches, vision changes, nausea or vomiting, or neck stiffness. Her physical exam is within normal limits. Her vital signs are stable. She is prescribed rifampin for prophylaxis with specific instructions on when to follow up if symptoms develop. When asked about the possibility of pregnancy, she mentioned that she uses combination oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for contraception. The physician suggested that her husband should use condoms for contraception as she requires antibiotic therapy. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the need for additional contraception? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of estrogens.
B: Rifampin inhibits CYP3A4, which metabolizes progestins.
C: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of progestins.
D: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of estrogens.
E: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of progestins.
Answer: A,C

Question: A 38-year-old male patient is being discharged after 2 days of hospitalization for pneumonia. He is currently receiving intravenous antibiotics and has shown great improvement in his symptoms. Inpatient smoking cessation counseling was attempted, but the patient declined. The patient has had a 25-pack-year history of smoking. He would like to try using nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) to help him quit smoking. Which of the following brands is most likely to be effective in helping him achieve smoking cessation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Nicoderm CQ
B: Nicorette
C: Zyban
D: Wellbutrin
E: Chantix
Answer: A,B,C,E

Question: A 72-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit for shortness of breath and palpitations. A cardiac catheterization is performed and measurements of the left ventricular volume and pressure at different points in the cardiac cycle are obtained. The patient's pressure-volume loop (gray) is shown with a normal pressure-volume loop (black) for comparison. Which of the following are the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Mitral valve regurgitation
B: Increased ventricle wall stiffness
C: Increased ventricular wall stiffness
D: Impaired left ventricular contractility
E: Aortic stenosis

Question: A 70-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with an itchy rash and hives on her trunk and face. Her symptoms began this morning after using perfumed soap that she had not used in the past. She denies any chest pain, shortness of breath, wheezing, or gastrointestinal symptoms. There is no history of similar symptoms. Her vital signs are as follows: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 75 beats/min, blood pressure 165/95 mm Hg, and respirations 18 breaths/min. On examination, the skin over her trunk and face has a raised, itchy rash with red, blanching papules. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which of the following are not the most important diagnostic criteria for this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Rashes on the trunk and face
B: Papules and pruritus
C: Erythema and wheals
D: Known exposure to an allergen
E: Systemic symptoms
Answer: D,E

Question: A 65-year-old male presents to his pulmonologist for a follow-up visit. He has a history of chronic progressive dyspnea over the past five years. He uses oxygen at home and was seen in the emergency room two months prior for an exacerbation of his dyspnea. He was discharged following stabilization. His past medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia and hypertension. He drinks alcohol socially and has a 45 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 140/75 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 22/min. On examination, increased work of breathing is noted. The physician decides to start the patient on an additional medication that has both mucoactive and anti-oxidative properties. What are the primary mechanism of action of this medication in the lungs? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: DNA hydrolysis
B: Disulfide bond cleavage
C: Endothelin-1 antagonism
D: Osmotic hydration of airway lumen
E: Reduction in airway surface tension

Question: A 67-year-old man with a history of hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic for his annual physical exam. On examination, the skin of his axillae and groins is dark, thick, and velvety. Acanthosis nigricans is also noted. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his skin changes?
Options: A: Atopic dermatitis
B: Cushing syndrome
C: Insulin resistance
D: Psoriasis
E: Scleroderma
Answer: C

C,E

Question: A 40-year-old mother of 3 presents to the physician because she has had a bloody vaginal discharge with an odor for the past 4 months. She also reports difficulty emptying her bladder, which started 1 month ago. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. Other than the gynecologic symptoms, she reports constipation for the past few months. On examination, the external genitalia show no abnormalities. A pelvic examination is attempted, but the vagina is completely obstructed by what is believed to be a mass, which prevents visualization of the cervix. Transrectal ultrasound confirms the presence of a mass in the vagina. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 12.0 g/dL (N 12–15 g/dL) Serum creatine 2.1 mg/dL (N 0.6–1.2 mg/dL) Blood urea nitrogen 68 mg/dL (N 6–25 mg/dL) Serum Potassium 4.7 mEq/L (N 3.5–5.0 mEq/L) Urinalysis reveals 2+ protein and 2+ occult blood. Which of the following is not the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Air embolism
B: Pelvic inflammatory disease
C: Recurrent pyelonephritis
D: Squamous cell carcinoma of the vagina
E: Uterine sarcoma
Answer: A,B,C

Question: A 37-year-old woman presents to your office with heartburn. Following an extensive workup, you diagnose her with a duodenal ulcer secondary to H. pylori infection. You prescribe triple therapy of omeprazole, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of omeprazole? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Inhibition of primary active transport
B: Inhibition of primary active transport
C: Inhibition of primary active transport
D: Inhibition of primary active transport
E: Inhibition of 50S ribosomal subunit

Question: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department in respiratory distress. He was in his usual state of health until approximately 2 hours before his presentation when he began to experience chest pain, dyspnea, and cough. He rode his bike for 30 minutes before the onset of symptoms and an hour later, the patient presented to the hospital. He is a known diabetic with a 14-year history of asthma. He occasionally uses a β2-agonist inhaler for asthma. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), blood pressure is 90/46 mm Hg, pulse is 117/min, and respirations are 24/min. Auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds bilaterally with expiratory wheezes. SPO2 is 86% on room air. Laboratory studies show:
Arterial blood gases pH: 7.20, PCO2: 34 mm Hg, PO2: 52 mm Hg
Blood sugar: 225 mg/dL
Electrolytes: normal
Chest x-ray shows bilateral diffuse airspace disease. A nasal swab for COVID-19 testing is obtained. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Nebulized epinephrine
B: Hyaluronidase
C: Telemetry monitoring
D: Nonrebreather mask with 100% oxygen
E: Nebulized albuterol
Answer: B,C

Question: A 61-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive thirst, frequent urination, and partial visual loss in both eyes for 1 day. His family history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus in his mother and cousin. His weight is 112 kg ( 246.9 lb), height 187 cm (6 ft 1 in), blood pressure: 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate: 89/min, respiratory rate: 14/min, and temperature: 36.7℃ (98.4℉). The physical examination is significant for dry skin, a pustular rash over the patient’s shoulders and back, an accentuated second heart sound (S2) best heard in the second intercostal space at the right sternal border, and distal loss of vibration sensitivity in both feet. A fundoscopic examination shows small red dots in the superficial retinal layers suggestive of microaneurysms. The HbA1c is 9% and the urinalysis shows the following:
Color Pale yellow (light/pale-to-dark/deep amber)
Clarity Cloudy
pH 6.6
Specific gravity 1.010
Glucose 199 mg/dl
Ketones None
Nitrites Negative
Leukocyte esterase Negative
Bilirubin Negative
Urinary bilirubin Traces
Red blood cells 3 RBCs
Protein 120 mg/d
RBCs ≤ 2 RBCs/hpf
WBCs 22 WBCs/hpf
Epithelial cells 27 squamous epithelial cells/hpf
Casts 5 hyaline casts/lpf
Crystals Occasional
Bacteria None
Yeast Present
. Which of the following statements best describes the cause of this patient’s glucosuria? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Yeasts metabolize glucogenic amino acids which are filtered in the urine into glucose
B: Secondary active transporter failing to completely reabsorb glucose in the renal tubules
C: Secondary active transporters fail to completely reabsorb glucose in the renal tubules
D: Secondary active transporters fails to completely reabsorb glucose in the renal tubules
E: Secondary active transporters failing to completely reabsorb glucose in the renal tubules

Question: A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with dyspnea. She reports a 1-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion, which gradually worsened to progressive dyspnea at rest over the past 3 days. When lying down, her dyspnea improves slightly, although she is still short of breath. She also reports orthopnea and swelling in her feet and ankles. Her past medical history is significant for 2 premature deliveries. She does not smoke or drink alcohol and uses oral contraceptives for contraception. On physical examination, she is seated leaning forward and using her accessory muscles of respiration. Respiratory rate is 28/min, pulse rate is 98/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. She has increased jugular venous distention, with prominent “a” waves. Cardiac examination reveals a laterally displaced point of maximal impulse (PMI), a third heart sound (S3), and bibasilar rales. Liver is palpable 5 cm below the right costal margin. Her oxygen saturation on 2 L of oxygen is 94% and her weight is 90 kg (198 lb). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Mitral stenosis
B: Mitral regurgitation
C: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
D: Dilatative cardiomyopathy
E: Pericarditis
Answer: D

Question: A 35-year-old woman with a history of depression presents to the clinic today for a medication check. She has been on sertraline for 1 year. For the past 3 months, her depression has been well managed, but she has noticed a significant decline in her sexual desire. She has a 2-year-old child and is married with a male partner and denies any relationship problems. Which of the following statements best addresses this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Serotonin syndrome is not a concern because symptoms only occur at the start of treatment or when the dose is increased
B: This patient may require a higher dose of sertraline to adequately manage her depression
C: Antidepressants can cause hyposexuality and her symptoms should resolve over time
D: This patient should be prescribed dextroamphetamine to improve her mood and sexual desire
E: This patient should be diagnosed with dysthymia and be prescribed a different antidepressant
Answer: C

Question: A 30-year-old woman presents to the physician because of ongoing diarrhea for the past 1 month. She reports that diarrhea has been intermittently present for the past month. The stool is often loose and associated with blood and lower abdominal pain. She denies any recent travel history, and she works at a nursing home as a caretaker. She is not currently on any medications. Clinical examination shows mild tenderness in the suprapubic region, and there is no organomegaly. Findings on colonoscopy include patchy erythema and ulceration in the cecum, ascending, descending, and sigmoid colon. Mucosal biopsy shows colonic crypts with lymphocytic and neutrophilic infiltrates. What are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Ulcerative colitis
B: Crohn’s disease
C: Acute infective colitis
D: Pseudomembranous colitis
E: Irritable bowel syndrome

Question: An 87-year-old woman presents to the office for a follow-up visit 3 months after she was admitted to the hospital because of an asthma exacerbation. She has no history of asthma. She has been using albuterol inhalers and oral corticosteroids. She is afebrile and has a respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min. Pulmonary examination reveals bilateral wheezes. Which of the following treatments is most likely to result in the resolution of her symptoms?
Options: A: Addition of inhaled corticosteroids
B: Addition of a long-acting beta agonist inhaler
C: Addition of a long-acting muscarinic antagonist inhaler
D: Intravenous methylprednisolone
E: Oral prednisone
Answer: A

Question: Ten days after undergoing a cadaveric renal transplant, a 21-year-old man has pain in the right lower abdomen and generalized fatigue. During the past 2 days, he has had decreasing urinary output. He passed 5 liters of urine on the second postoperative day and serum studies showed a creatinine concentration of 2.1 mg/dL. He has adult polycystic kidney disease and was on maintenance hemodialysis for 2 months prior to transplantation. Current medications include azathioprine, cyclosporine, prednisone, and enalapril. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 164/94 mm Hg. Examination shows a healing surgical incision in the right lower abdomen. The graft site shows tenderness to palpation. His blood urea nitrogen concentration is 52 mg/dL, creatinine concentration is 4.1 mg/dL. A biopsy of the transplanted kidney shows tubulitis. C4d staining is negative. Which of the following are the most likely responsible for this patient's findings? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Recipient T-cells in the graft
B: Recipient t-obsolete cell in the graft
C: Recipient t-cell types in the graft
D: Polyomavirus-associated nephropathy
E: Newly formed anti-HLA antibodies
"

Question: A 27-year-old man with no past medical history presents with epigastric pain and a tender mass in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. His symptoms began 1 week ago with diffuse abdominal pain and nausea, and he progressed to vomiting and diarrhea. He has had no fevers, chills, or jaundice. He also noticed a tender and non-mobile mass in the right lower quadrant of his abdomen. The pain radiates to his right flank. The patient has poor oral intake and he has lost 5 kg (11 lb) in 2 weeks. He denies any dysuria, hematuria, or change in bowel habits. On physical examination, the patient is febrile to 38.2°C (100.8°F) with a heart rate of 101/min and a blood pressure of 112/68 mm Hg. His abdomen is tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant and he has rebound tenderness there as well. Abdominal bruit is heard over the right lower quadrant. No other masses are palpable. Rectal examination reveals stool positive for occult blood. Complete blood count shows a hemoglobin of 12 g/dL, hematocrit of 36%, white blood cell count of 11,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 290,000/mm3. The patient's liver function tests are within normal limits. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
Options: A: Ovarian cyst
B: Cecal volvulus
C: Appendicitis
D: Pyelonephritis
E: Preeclampsia
Answer: C

Question: A 30-year-old woman presents to the physician with a 1-week history of progressively worsening right flank pain, nausea, and vomiting. For the past 2 days, she has also felt a burning sensation during urination. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness confined to the right costovertebral angle. Urinalysis reveals 3+ white blood cells, 3+ red blood cells, and 1+ protein. Urine culture grows >105 CFU/mL of Escherichia coli. A renal ultrasound shows a mildly enlarged right kidney with a 2-cm, sonolucent area in the upper pole. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in this patient's care? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Initiate empiric antibiotic therapy
B: Place a nephrostomy tube
C: Perform cystoscopy
D: Continue with current antibiotics
E: Perform percutaneous nephrolithotomy
Answer: B,C,D,E

Question: A 29-year-old female presents to her primary care provider with an aching pain in her left leg that has progressively gotten worse over several days. She recently had an unfortunate sporting incident resulting in large bruises along both legs and lower thighs. An X-ray after the event was negative for fracture. Past medical history is positive for systemic lupus erythematosus. She also has a history of one spontaneous abortion at 12 weeks gestation. Today, her heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, blood pressure is 119/80 mm Hg, and temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical examination, her left leg appears pink and slightly swollen. Homan’s sign is positive. A Doppler ultrasound reveals a thrombus in the left popliteal vein. Her lab results are as follows:
Platelets 250,000/mm3
Prothrombin Time 14 sec
Partial Thromboplastin Time 90 sec
Mixing study (PTT) 89 sec
. What are the most likely cause of the patient’s condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Antibodies directed against phospholipids
B: Antibodies directed against phospholipids
C: Antibodies directed against phospholipids
D: Vitamin K deficiency
E: Disseminated intravascular coagulation

Question: A 34-year-old male who is admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of sickle cell crisis. He has a 15-year history of sickle cell disease. During the crisis, he complains of progressively worsening left lower quadrant abdominal pain. He can provide a complete history, but he is not alert. His temperature is 36.9°C (100°F), heart rate is 114/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased bowel sounds in all 4 quadrants and left lower quadrant tenderness. Which of the following are the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?
Options: A: Acalculous cholecystitis
B: Hepatitis
C: Splenic infarction
D: Cholelithiasis
E: Pancreatitis
Answer: C

Question: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of intermittent flank pain. Over the past 2 years, she has had five urinary tract infections. Her blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral, nontender upper abdominal masses. Serum studies show a urea nitrogen concentration of 29 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 1.4 mg/dL. Renal ultrasonography shows bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple parenchymal anechoic masses. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Medullary sponge kidney
B: Simple renal cysts
C: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
D: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease
E: Obstructive cystic dysplasia

Question: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of intermittent flank pain. Over the past 2 years, she has had five urinary tract infections. B: Simple renal cysts

E: Obstructive cystic dysplasia

C

Question: A 19-year-old man presents to the clinic 6 weeks after suffering severe burns to his face, anterior chest, and hands. His injuries have healed well and he has been pain-free for 2 weeks. He has no history of heart disease or hypertension. His blood pressure is 150/100 mm Hg. Examination of the heart shows no abnormalities. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Renovascular hypertension
B: Hyperthyroidism
C: Pheochromocytoma
D: Renal artery stenosis
E: Cushing syndrome
Answer: A,B,C,D

Question: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of dysuria, increased urinary frequency and urgency, and hematuria. He also reports a 10-kg weight loss over the past 6 months. His blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 15/min. Physical examination shows bilateral costovertebral angle tenderness. The remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits. Urinalysis shows trace proteinuria, 3-5 red blood cells/hpf, and white blood cells are not seen. An abdominal ultrasound shows a 1.5-cm right renal mass. Which of the following are not the most appropriate diagnostic next step? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Urine cytology
B: Renal angiogram
C: MRI of the abdomen
D: IVP
E: Cystoscopy
Answer: B,C,D

Question: A 40-year-old obese man presents to his primary care provider with a history of excessive daytime somnolence and easy fatigability. Upon further questioning, it is found that although his sleeping hours are adequate, he does not feel refreshed in the morning. His wife complains that he snores loudly all night. After ruling out common medical disorders and possible drug abuse, he is advised an overnight polysomnogram that records 12 episodes of apnea and 30 episodes of hypopnea during a 7-hour sleep. Which of the following statements best describes this patient’s condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: This patient's apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) is more than 5.
B: This patient's apneic episodes-slow shallow breathing indexes (ahi) is more than 5.
C: This patient's breathing stops-hypopnoea indexes (ahi) is more than 5.
D: The most common site of a collapse of pharyngeal airway during sleep apnea is at the level of the base of the tongue.
E: This patient's apnoea-hypopnoea indexes (ahi) is more than 5.

Question: A 35-year-old man with a history of asthma comes to the physician because of a worsening dry cough and wheezing. It is his worst attack in years. The patient lost 10 lb in the last 2 weeks. He also notes that he has a poor appetite and is easily fatigued. He says he is not very alert and is havingdifficulty concentrating. On physical examination, the pulse is 115 beats/min, regular, the respirations are 24 breaths/min, and the blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Examination of the lungs shows expiratory wheezing worse on the right side. Examination of the heart shows tachcardia. The patient has pitting edema to the midtibias bilaterally. No ascites or hepatosplenomegaly is present. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Right middle lobe syndrome
B: Right lower lobe pneumonitis
C: Congestive heart failure
D: Right upper lobe syndrome
E: Cardiac syndrome
Answer: A,B,D

Question: An 8-week-old male presents with his mother to the pediatrician for a well visit. The patient has been breastfed since birth, and usually feeds for 30 minutes every 2-3 hours. The patient’s mother is concerned that her milk production is not keeping up with the patient’s nutritional requirements. She reports that about two weeks ago the patient began regurgitating breastmilk through his nose and mouth after some feeds. She reports that he seems mildly upset during the episodes of regurgitation but usually settles down quickly and is hungry again soon afterwards. The patient’s mother has already tried limiting the volume of each feed, which seems to have reduced the frequency of the regurgitation. She denies any diarrhea, hematochezia, or family history of food allergies. Her older son had a similar problem with vomiting that resolved around 12 months of age. Four weeks ago, the patient’s height and weight were in the 40th and 34th percentiles, respectively. His height and weight are now respectively in the 37th and 36th percentiles. On physical exam, the patient is cooing in his mother’s lap and smiles reciprocally with her. He lifts his head and shoulders off the examination table when placed in the supine position. His abdomen is soft, non-tender and non-distended. Bowel sounds are normoactive.

. Which of the following are the best next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Reassurance and counseling services on patient positionings
B: Obtain abdominal ultrasound
C: Reassurance and counseling on positioning
D: Recommend modification of mother’s diet
E: Switch to hydrolyzed formula

Question: A 65-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, presents to a physician for her annual checkup. She remains asymptomatic from her medical issues. Her medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, and pravastatin. Physical examination shows blood pressure of 120/74 mm Hg and heart rate of 82/min. Her most recent hemoglobin A1c was within the goal range of 6.0-7.0%. She had a fasting lipid panel 5 months ago that was also satisfactory. She reveals to the physician that she has been trying to lose weight. She reports that she has been on a diet of 800 kcal/day for the last 13 weeks. On the diet, she has lost a total of 40 lbs. She is concerned about the potential adverse effects of her rapid weight loss and has questions about the safety of her diet. Which of the following is the best advice for this patient?
Options: A: Continue her diet and reassure her that rapid weight loss is safe.
B: Advise her to stop her diet immediately and follow a more gradual weight loss plan.
C: Ask her to gain back half of the weight that she has lost.
D: Start screening for depression and mood disorders.
E: Start her on orlistat to promote continued weight loss.
Answer: B

Question: A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after being stung by a bee in the right upper eyelid. She has a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and chronic low back pain. She is also a smoker and drinks two glasses of wine per night. Her medications include hydrochlorothiazide and simvastatin. She denies any allergies and has never been seen for allergy testing. In the emergency department, she is anxious and reports pain and swelling around the right eye. Her vital signs are as follows: blood pressure of 130/84 mm Hg, heart rate of 88 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals a well-nourished, well-developed woman in mild distress. Examination of the eye shows marked periorbital and eyelid edema surrounding the right eye. The skin is intact and there is no evidence of erythema or warmth. There are no signs of conjunctivitis. An epinephrine autoinjector was administered 1 hour ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Options: A: Start prednisone 20 mg every day
B: Apply cool compresses to the right eye
C: Apply warm compresses to the right eye
D: Give diphenhydramine 25 mg every 6 hours 
E: Give prednisone 1 mg/kg every 8 hours
Answer: D

Question: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He reports that one hour ago he was climbing the stairs in his home when he suddenly developed excruciating chest pain. He describes the pain as ripping and radiating to the back. The patient’s past medical history is significant for a heart murmur that is being followed by his outpatient cardiologist. He takes no medications. The patient works as a carpenter and reports being monogamous with his wife. He denies any history of intravenous drug use or recent travel. In the emergency department, the patient’s temperature is 99.4°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 94/56 mmHg, pulse is 121/min, and respirations are 14/min. On physical exam, the patient appears to be in moderate distress and is clutching his chest. He is tall and has joint hypermobility. His breath sounds are equal and full bilaterally and has weak distal pulses.

. Which of the following are most likely to be found in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Holosystolic, high-pitched blowing murmur at the lower left sternal border
B: Late systolic crescendo murmur at the apex with mid-systolic click
C: Mid-diastolic murmur at the apex with opening snap
D: Mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border
E: Late systolic crescendo murmur at the apex with mid-clicks systolic

Question: A 25-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for pain in his back. The patient describes the pain as feeling worse in the morning. He says it is a general stiffness that improves when he goes to the gym and lifts weights. He also states that his symptoms seem to improve when he leans forward or when he is cycling. The patient is a current smoker and is sexually active. He admits to having unprotected sex with many different partners this past year. The patient has no significant past medical history and is not currently taking any medications. On physical exam, the patient demonstrates notable kyphosis of the thoracic spine and decreased mobility of the back in all 4 directions. The patient’s strength is 5/5 in his upper and lower extremities. The rest of his physical exam is within normal limits. Which of the following findings are associated with this patient’s presentation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Decreased levels of IgA
B: Diminished pulses in the lower extremity
C: Narrowing of the spinal canal when standing upright
D: Pain with elevation of his leg while laying down
E: Punctate bleeding spots when dermatologic scales are removed

Question: A 25-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for pain in his back. The patient describes the pain as feeling worse in the morning. He says it is a general stiffness that improves when he goes to the gym and lifts weights. He also states that his symptoms seem to improve when he leans forward or when he is cycling. Question: A 60-year-old man with bipolar disorder has been receiving lithium and valproate for 20 years. He is being switched to risperidone and gabapentin. His lithium is to be stopped first. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Monitor valproate for increased toxicity
B: Obtain a lithium level and start risperidone
C: Titrate risperidone up slowly every other day
D: Taper lithium over 1 week and start risperidone
E: Taper lithium over 4 weeks and start risperidone
Answer: D,E

Question: A 27-year-old graduate student is bitten by a coral snake while he was hiking alone through the woods and dies 2 hours later from respiratory failure. His body was discovered 7 hours later by a group of campers who promptly called the police. On arrival, the police found his body to be cold and stiff. Which of the following processes are responsible for the rigidity observed? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Inhibition of cross-bridge bicycling
B: Inhibition of cross-bridge bicycl
C: Inhibition of cross-bridge bike
D: Inhibition of cross-bridge cycling
E: Depletion of intracellular calcium

Question: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a 3-hour history of bright red, painless hematuria. He also notes the passage of red blood clots. He reports that the pain began after weightlifting at the gym this afternoon. He denies any history of hypertension, diabetes, or renal disease. He is taking no medications. His vital signs are as follows: temperature 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse 80/min, blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, respirations 12/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Physical examination is within normal limits. Urinalysis shows 4+ blood, 2+ protein, and microhematuria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: IgA nephropathy
B: Bladder cancer
C: Glomerulonephritis
D: Prostate cancer
E: Renal cell carcinoma
Answer: A

Question: A 62-year-old man comes to the clinic because of feet swelling for the past 6 months. He states that he has noticed gradual bilateral swelling of the feet, which has worsened over the past 2 months. The swelling has caused him to have difficulty wearing shoes. The patient does not report recent weight gain, dyspnea, or abdominal pain. He is currently taking furosemide for hypertension. His medical history is significant for long-standing hypertension. He has no history of peripheral arterial disease, deep vein thrombosis, or heart failure. On examination, vital signs are: BP 140/86 mm Hg, heart rate 88 beats/min, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). Respirations are unlabored. There is no jugular venous distension. Examination of the neck is supple without thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rate and rhythm without murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Examination of the lungs reveals clear breath sounds bilaterally with no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. Examination of the abdomen reveals soft, non-tender, non-distended abdomen without hepatosplenomegaly or masses. Examination of the extremities reveals bilateral 1+ pitting edema of the feet and ankles. No calf tenderness is noted. The pulses are palpable in all extremities. Capillary refill is less than 2 seconds. There is no clubbing, cyanosis, or ulceration. Examination of the skin reveals no rashes. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's signs and symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Elevated central venous pressure
B: Fluid retention
C: Right-sided heart failure
D: Hepatic cirrhosis
E: Chronic kidney disease
Answer: D,E

Question: A 16-year-old female presents to her primary care physician due to lack of menstruation. She has never had a period and is anxious that she is not “keeping up” with her friends. She states that her breasts began developing when she was 13, and she had a growth spurt around the same time. Review of systems reveals that she has also been getting headaches every few months over the last year with some photosensitivity and nausea each time. Ibuprofen relieves her symptoms. The patient is a competitive ice skater and has never been sexually active. Her mother has a history of migraine headaches, and her older sister has a history of bipolar disorder. Both underwent menarche at age 15. At this visit, the patient’s temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), pulse is 70/min, blood pressure is 118/65 mmHg, and respirations are 13/min. Her body mass index is 23.8 kg/m^2. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Both breasts are Tanner IV with no expressable discharge. Pelvic and axillary hair growth is also Tanner IV. The patient is unable to tolerate a full pelvic exam, but the part of the vaginal canal that is examined is unremarkable. Laboratory studies are ordered and are below:

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
K+: 4.1 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen: 12 mg/dL
Glucose: 73 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
Ca2+: 9.7 mg/dL
Mg2+: 1.7 mEq/L
AST: 11 U/L
ALT: 11 U/L
Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH): 16.2 mIU/mL (4.7-21.5 mIU/ml)
Estrogen: 240 pg/mL (64-357 pg/mL)

Abdominal ultrasound is performed and shows a normal uterus and ovaries. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Hypothalamic amenorrhea
B: Hyperprolactinemia
C: Vaginal septum
D: Vaginal septum
E: Normal development
