Question: A 23-year-old man presents to the emergency room with a 1-week history of fever, chills, and cough. The patient was feeling well until about 1 week ago when he awoke with fever and chills. He started to develop low-grade fever (37.8°C [100°F]) which has persisted ever since. He has had rigors on 3 occasions over the past several days. He notes chills and diaphoresis with the rigors. He also has a cough that is worse at night, but which has been worsening over the past several days. He has not had any shortness of breath. His cough is productive of greenish-colored sputum. The patient has also noted a progressive headache for the past several days. He denies any nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. He does note that he has been very thirsty over the past couple of weeks. He has had 2 to 3 liters of water per day. He denies any recent trauma. The patient is a dental assistant and was recently in Hawaii on vacation. He returned from Hawaii about 2 weeks ago. The patient lives with his wife who is currently experiencing a similar illness but is not as ill as the patient. The patient's medical history is remarkable only for occasional allergies, which are treated with over-the-counter antihistamines. He takes no prescribed medications. He has no known drug allergies. Social history is significant for occasional social alcohol use and occasional social cannabis use. On review of systems, the patient denies any recent weight loss. He reports that he had a flu immunization this past fall, but is uncertain whether he has ever received a pneumococcal immunization. On physical examination, the patient is afebrile (36.9°C [98.4°F]), blood pressure is 104/72 mmHg, heart rate is 102 beats/min, respirations are 18 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% while breathing room air. Examination of the head and neck reveals mild injection of the conjunctivae bilaterally. The oropharynx is diffusely erythematous. Examination of the lungs reveals a few inspiratory rales at the right lung base. The cardiovascular examination is unremarkable with no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. The patient has no peripheral edema. Examination of the abdomen reveals no hepatosplenomegaly or tenderness. Neurological examination reveals a normal mental status and intact cranial nerves. Examination of the skin reveals no rashes or petechiae. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Influenza A infection
B: Streptococcal pneumoniae pneumonia
C: Legionnaires' disease
D: Walking pneumonia
E: Staphylococcal aureus pneumonia
Answer: C

Question: A 59-year-old woman presents to the clinic to after 36 hours of progressively worsening right upper quadrant abd pain with radiation to her right shoulder. She was seen by her primary care provider yesterday who treated her with a single dose of intramuscular diclofenac. The pain returned and has been associated with right sided appetite loss and nausea. Her medical history includes Factor V Leiden thrombophilia, for which she takes warfarin. She is afebrile. Review of systems is positive for severe epigastric pain and right-sided shoulder pain. Physical examination shows reduced breath sounds at the right lung base and tenderness in the right upper quadrant. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows moderate right pleural effusion, gallstones with sludge, and a large calculus in the common bile duct. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy
B: Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography
C: Percutaneous transhepatic gallbladder drainage
D: Administer IV antibiotics
E: Perform endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography 
Answer: D

Question: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of his sense of smell. Two days ago, his mother found that he had left the gas on in the kitchen, and he was unable to smell the odor of the gas. As a child, he was consistently in the 40th percentile for height; now he is in the 15th percentile. He had bilateral orchidopexy for cryptorchidism as an infant. The patient is unable to identify several common odors when presented with them. Physical examination shows sparse axillary and pubic hair and Tanner stage 1 genitals. Which of the following are the most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Impaired migration of GnRH neurons
B: Impaired migration of GnRH neurons
C: Impaired migration of GnRH neurons
D: Impaired migration of GnRH neurons
E: Decreased thyroxine production

Question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a routine evaluation. Her past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes and dyslipidemia. Examination shows acanthosis nigricans and 2 skin tags on her neck. Acanthosis nigricans is a dark, thickened, velvety skin discoloration that is commonly seen with diabetes and obesity. Which of the following are the most likely underlying cause of these skin changes? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Somatotropin
B: Insulin
C: Insulin
D: Prolactin
E: Somatostatin
Answer: C,D

Question: A 63-year-old female complains of weakness, light-headedness, palpitations, and soreness of the tongue. She has a past medical history of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. Her hematocrit is 29%. On peripheral blood smear, you notice neutrophils with 7 lobes and large oval-shaped red blood cells. On physical exam, you notice the patient has decreased position sense and a loss in vibratory sensation in her lower extremities. Which of the following are most likely present in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Itrinsic factor ab
B: Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies
C: Decreased methylmalonic acid levels
D: Antithrombotic state
E: Intrinsic factor antibody

Question: A 63-year-old female complains of weakness, light-headedness, palpitations, and soreness of the tongue. She has a past medical history of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. Her hematocrit is 29%. On peripheral blood smear, you notice neutrophils with 7 lobes and large oval-shaped red blood cells. On physical exam, you notice the patient has decreased position sense and a loss in vibratory sensation in her lower extremities. Which of the following are not most likely present in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Itrinsic factor ab
B: Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies
C: Decreased methylmalonic acid levels
D: Antithrombotic state
E: Intrinsic factor antibody

Question: An 88-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because of a 3-week history of a nonproductive cough, diffuse bilateral pulmonary infiltrates seen on chest x-ray, and diarrhea. He has smoked since he was 18 years old, but he quit 2 days before his current illness began. He also reports recent weight loss and a 2-week history of diarrhea. His vital signs are: Respiratory Rate 18 breaths/min; Temperature 100.5°F, Heart Rate 100 beats/min; and a Blood Pressure 128/72 mm Hg. Examination of the respiratory system indicates inspiratory crackles at the lung bases bilaterally. Examination of the heart reveals a regular rate and rhythm. Examination of the abdomen is negative for hepatosplenomegaly and abdominal tenderness. On auscultation, there are no abnormal bowel sounds. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies reveal:
White blood cell count: 6,000/mm3
Serum sodium: 130 mEq/L
Serum potassium: 5.0 mEq/L
Serum bicarbonate: 25 mEq/L
Arterial pH: 7.39
Albumin: 3.0 g/dL
Total protein: 5.0 g/dL
Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Determine stool osmolality
B: Obtain stool culture
C: Determine serum amylase
D: Obtain a CT scan of the chest
E: Obtain chest X-ray
Answer: A,D

Question: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because he has excessively dry skin. His mother says that he has had dry, scaly skin since he was 6 months old. She says it is worse in winter and better in summer. There is no associated itching, redness, or discharge. Examination reveals generalized fine scales with coarse skin all over the body, except in the skin creases of the neck and in the cubital and popliteal fossae (see image). There are multiple papular elevations at the base of hair follicles and darkening of the palmar and plantar creases. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Psoriasis
B: Ichthyosis vulgaris
C: Ichthyosis vulgaris
D: Pityriasis versicolor
E: Ichthyosis vulgaris

Question: A 3-year-old girl presents with her mother to a pediatrician. She has a history of eczema since infancy, which has worsened over the past 2 months. She has not experienced sweating, skin dryness, muscle weakness, abdominal pain, or red urine. On physical examination, she has a pruritic, dry, erythematous rash in the antecubital fossae, popliteal fossae, and neck. On further questioning, her mother reports that the girl drinks 3 cups of 1% milk and eats 1 cup of yogurt daily. She also consumes 2 slices of cheddar cheese and 3 cups of broccoli per week. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Options: A: Avoid cow’s milk and cheese
B: Increase fluid intake
C: Begin phototherapy
D: Apply a topical corticosteroid once daily
E: Avoid foods high in calcium
Answer: A

Question: A 62-year-old woman presents to the physician because of a 6-day history of diplopia. She also reports nausea, vomiting, and hoarseness. Over the last 2 months, she has noticed that her right eyelid has been drooping. She has also had some difficulty swallowing hard foods. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications she takes include captopril, glyburide, simvastatin, and aspirin. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows right upper eyelid ptosis, right lateral rectus palsy, incomplete adduction of the right eye, decreased gag reflex, and a soft palate that moves poorly on phonation. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Vestibular schwannoma
B: Meningioma
C: Pituitary adenoma
D: Craniopharyngioma
E: Thyroid cancer
Answer: E

Question: A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department with confusion. His symptoms started a few days ago and have been gradually worsening. Initially, the patient had a fever and a cough which has progressed to abdominal pain, diarrhea, and confusion. His temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical exam is notable for localized crackles and decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung field. The patient is confused and is answering questions inappropriately. Laboratory studies are ordered as seen below.

Hemoglobin: 12 g/dL

Question: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because he has diarrhea and abdominal pain every time he eats lactose-containing foods. He denies any milk allergies, food sensitivities, or anorexia. He has a family history of lactose intolerance. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination is unremarkable. Stool examination shows 20 fecal leukocytes per high-power field and no pathogens. Lactose tolerance testing shows a blood glucose of 74 mg/dL at fasting and of 70 mg/dL at 2 hours. Which of the following are the most effective treatment option for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Gluten-free diet
B: Lactose-free diet
C: Gluten-restricted diet
D: Galactose-free diet
E: Elemental diet

Question: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a severe headache. She states it is 10/10 in intensity and states that it is associated with chewing. She describes it as a dull pain over the sides of her head. The patient is otherwise healthy and is not currently taking any medications. Her temperature is 97.0°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 111/74 mmHg, pulse is 83/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for pain and tenderness over the mandibular and temporal region that is worsened when the patient opens and closes their mouth. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Temporomandibular joint dysfunction
B: Temporomandibular joint dysfunction
C: Temporal arteritis
D: Temporomandibular joint dysfunction
E: Tension headache

Question: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of severe muscle and joint pain for 5 months. The pain varies in location and intensity. Question: A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of gradually worsening shortness of breath. He has a history of COPD for which he receives corticosteroids and nebulized bronchodilators. He says that his symptoms started as a slight cough 1 week ago. He also has a history of hypertension for which he takes a diuretic and an ACE inhibitor. Which of the following is the most likely complication of the patient's COPD? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Right-sided heart failure
B: Pulmonary embolus
C: Respiratory acidosis
D: Atelectasis
E: Cardiac tamponade
Answer: A,B,C

Question: A 39-year-old woman presents with frequent watery diarrhea of 5 days' duration. She has had 10 to 12 bowel movements a day with minimal abdominal pain, flatulence, or nausea. She denies vomiting, fever, blood in the stool, or recent travel. Она is afebrile and has no abdominal tenderness or distension. Bowel sounds are active. There is a large amount of clear fluid in the rectal vault. The leukocyte count is 10,000/mm3, the hematocrit is 36%, and the electrolytes are:
Sodium 130 mEq/L
Potassium 3.6 mEq/L
Chloride 96 mEq/L
Bicarbonate 19 mEq/L
Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Salmonella species
B: Vibrio cholerae
C: Staphylococcus aureus
D: Norwalk-like virus
E: Yersinia enterocolitica
Answer: C,E

Question: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of left knee pain as well as stiffness upon waking for about 10–15 minutes. The pain is worse after standing a lot at work and when she climbs stairs. There is no history of trauma. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Her mother died of metastatic breast cancer 15 years ago, at the age of 65 years. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include atorvastatin, labetalol, and aspirin. Over the past 2 months, she has been taking over-the-counter ibuprofen as needed for the joint pain. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31.8 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mm Hg. Examination of the left knee shows tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial joint line; there is crepitus and pain with full flexion and extension. Serum uric acid concentration is 8.0 mg/dL and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h. Which of the following are the most likely finding on imaging of the left knee? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Osteophytes with joint-space narrowing on x-ray
B: Calcification of synovia and cartilage on ultrasound
C: Exostoses with narrowing of joint spaces on x-rays
D: Joint effusion and pannus on ultrasound
E: Fluid-filled pouch on ultrasound

Question: A 22-year-old woman returns to the clinic for evaluation of abnormal laboratory results. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 6 weeks ago and started on metformin 500 mg once daily. Her HbA1c at that time was 10.1%, fasting plasma glucose was 210 mg/dL, and blood pressure was 135/85 mm Hg. Her current laboratory results show the following:
HbA1c 11.0%
Fasting plasma glucose 230 mg/dL
Blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg
Body mass index 25.0 kg/m2
Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Increase metformin to 500 mg twice daily
B: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily
C: Add a short-acting insulin analogue before meals
D: Start a basal insulin analogue
E: Add a sulfonylurea
Answer: A,C

Question: A 67-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of fatigue and dizziness for the past 2 months. He reports that he gets tired easily compared to his baseline and feels dizzy when he exerts himself (e.g., when he walks long distances). His past medical history is significant for hypertension that is controlled with lisinopril. A physical examination demonstrates moderate hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy. His laboratory studies are shown below.

Lactate dehydrogenase: 45 U/L

A subsequent flow cytometry test demonstrates CD20+ cells. What are the most likely finding you would expect in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Presence of smudge cell
B: Presence of smudge the cell

D: Presence of smudge cells set

Question: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a 1-day history of blurred vision and photophobia. Her past medical and surgical histories are unremarkable, and she is not taking any medications. On review of systems, she reports recently urinating more frequently than normal. Physical examination shows decreased visual acuity bilaterally, as well as conjunctival hyperemia. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
Options: A: Syphilis
B: Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome
C: Malaria
D: Lyme disease
E: Chlamydia
Answer: A

Question: A 13-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with severe knee, hip, and groin pain. The patient has a past medical history notable only for obesity and asthma. His temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 124/65 mmHg, pulse is 128/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an inability of the patient to bear weight on his left leg and limited range of motion of the left hip. Which of the following are the best management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Casting and crutches
B: Surgical pinning of the femoral heads
C: Supportive therapy and observation
D: Surgical drainage of the hip
E: Surgical pinning of the femoral head

Question: A 67-year-woman with non-Hodgkin lymphoma comes to the physician because of progressively increasing numbness and tingling in her fingers and toes. Her last cycle of chemotherapy with vincristine was 1 week ago. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch in all distal extremities. Knee and ankle deep tendon reflexes are decreased. Which of the following are the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s peripheral neuropathy? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Inhibition of beta-tubulin polymerization
B: Creation of free radicals that unwind DNA
C: Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase
D: Response inhibition of beta-tubulin polymerization

Question: A 22-year-old woman presents to your ob/gyn clinic for a preconception counseling visit. She is generally healthy and has no significant medical history. She is taking combination oral contraceptives for contraception. She has a 2-pack-year history of smoking cigarettes and drinks 2 glasses of wine on the weekends. On physical examination, her vital signs are normal. The uterus is anteverted and non-tender, and the adnexa are normal bilaterally. No other masses or tenderness are noted. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in the preconception care of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Obtain a Pap smear
B: Start folic acid supplementation
C: Recommend lifestyle modification counseling
D: Obtain a mammogram
E: Obtain a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level
Answer: B,C

Question: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at the grocery store and losing consciousness for 1 minute following a sudden onset of palpitations. He has no chest pain or dizziness. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and is currently being treated as an outpatient for pneumonia. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and azithromycin. He has no sign of injury, and he appears well. During the examination, he loses consciousness again. Telemetry shows polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with cyclic alteration of the QRS axis, which spontaneously resolves after 30 seconds. Which of the following are the most likely underlying cause of this patient's syncope? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Hypomagnesemia
B: Long qt syndrome
C: Prolonged QT interval
D: Accessory conduction pathway
E: Hyperkalemia

Question: A previously healthy 24-year-old man comes to the physician 1 day after the onset of burning pain, swelling, and multiple blisters over the left index finger. He is sexually active with one female partner, and they do not use condoms. His father has a history of thromboangiitis obliterans. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. He drinks two to four beers on social occasions. Vital signs are within normal limits. Options: A: Oral acyclovir
B: Incision and drainage of the pulp space
C: Oral acyclovir
D: Smoking cessation
E: Po acyclovir

Question: A 22-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a 1-month history of polyuria and polydipsia. She recently changed jobs and increased her physical activity to 5 days a week. Question: A 21-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of new-onset polyuria and polydipsia. He has noticed headaches and blurred vision, and he has been more tired than usual. Options: A: Posterior pituitary insufficiency
B: Diabetes insipidus
C: Type 1 diabetes mellitus
D: Diuretic phase of acute tubular necrosis
E: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
Answer: B,D

Question: A 36-year-old man presents to a physician after having a transient loss of consciousness while resting after dinner the previous night. His symptoms only lasted for a few seconds and resolved spontaneously. This is the third time he experienced such an episode. He says that he recently started having nightmares. His father died of sudden cardiac death at the age of 45 years without a history of hypertension or any chronic cardiac disorder. A complete physical examination was normal. A 12-lead electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevations in V1, V2, and V3, and the presence of incomplete right bundle branch block (RBBB). After a complete diagnostic evaluation, Brugada syndrome was diagnosed. He has prescribed a class I anti-arrhythmic drug, which is a sodium channel blocker that slows phase 0 depolarization in ventricular muscle fibers. The drug also blocks potassium channels and prolongs action potential duration, but it does not shorten phase 3 repolarization. The drug also has mild anticholinergic and alpha-blocking activity. If taken in high doses, which of the following are the most likely side effects of the drug? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Headache and tinnitus
B: Pulmonary fibrosis and corneal deposits
C: Dyslipidemia and hypoglycemia unawareness
D: Pedal edema and flushing
E: Hypothyroidism and phototoxicity

Question: A 19-year-old woman presents to the physician with a 3-month history of progressive diffuse abdominal bloating, abdominal pain, and weight loss. She has also noticed increased frequency of urination and nocturia. She denies dysuria or urinary incontinence. Her past medical history is remarkable for Crohn disease diagnosed at the age of 16 years, which is currently in remission. She has a history of one episode of intra-abdominal abcesses and had a colectomy. She currently takes mesalamine 800 mg three times a day. She is a college student and works part-time as a waitress. Her mother has Crohn disease. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, the pulse is 70/min, and the respirations are 14/min. Urinalysis shows glycosuria. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Chemotherapy-induced diabetes mellitus
B: Steroid-induced diabetes mellitus
C: Type I diabetes mellitus
D: Type II diabetes mellitus
E: Gestational diabetes mellitus
Answer: B

Question: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with dyspnea and palpitations. He does not smoke cigarettes or consume alcohol, and past medical history is insignificant. Blood pressure is 115/75 mmHG and heart rate is 125/min. Heart rhythm is irregularly irregular. After initial treatment with IV digoxin the patient's heart rate drops to 85/min and remains irregular. Which of the following best explains the effect of digoxin in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Blockade of beta-adrenergic receptors
B: Calcium channel blockade
C: Blockade of Na-K-ATPase on cardiac myocytes
D: Vagal stimulation
E: Increased ventricular contractility

Question: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with dyspnea and palpitations. He does not smoke cigarettes or consume alcohol, and past medical history is insignificant. Question: A 21-year-old woman who is 30 weeks pregnant reports to her physician with a 2-week history of vague abdominal pain and nausea. She has had occasional episodes of heartburn for many years. She had an upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy 2 years ago that showed a 3-cm hiatal hernia. The pain in her abdomen radiates to her back. Which of the following is most likely cause of her current symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Perforated peptic ulcer
B: Cholecystitis
C: Hiatal hernia
D: Pancreatitis
E: Gastritis
Answer: C

Question: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after experiencing severe abdominal pain that started suddenly 1 hour ago. She localizes the pain to the epigastric region. She denies any history of previous abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, or melena. She has a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes (HbA1c of 10.6%) and hypertension. Her medications include metformin, lisinopril, and aspirin. On physical examination, her vital signs are as follows: pulse 120/min, respirations 26/min, BP 180/110 mm Hg, and temperature 37.6°C. Abdominal examination reveals diffuse tenderness with rebound to palpation in all quadrants. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. Rectal examination reveals melena. A plain abdominal x‑ray is shown. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Bowel infarction
B: Appendicitis
C: Cholecystitis
D: Intestinal obstruction
E: Pancreatitis
Answer: B,D

Question: A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his father because of altered mental status. According to the father, the patient was unable to get out of bed that morning and has become increasingly confused over the past several hours. The father also noticed it was “pretty cold” in his son's apartment because all of the windows were left open overnight. He has a history of hypothyroidism, schizoaffective disorder, type 2 diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, and hypertension for which he takes medication. Ten days ago, he was started on a new drug. He appears lethargic. His rectal temperature is 32°C (89.6°F), pulse is 54/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg. Examination shows weakness in the lower extremities with absent deep tendon reflexes. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the upper extremities. The pupils are dilated and poorly reactive to light. Throughout the examination, the patient attempts to remove his clothing. Which of the following drugs are the most likely cause of these findings? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Lisinopril
B: Fluphenazine
C: Tolbutamide
D: Levothyroxine
E: Atorvastatin
"

Question: A 19-year-old previously healthy man presents to the emergency department with complaints of a pruritic rash that has been present for the past 3 weeks. Over the past 2 days, he has noticed that the rash has begun to form ulcers. He states that the rash began as small, red, itchy circular lesions on his abdomen and chest. These lesions have since spread to involve his back, legs, arms, and face. He denies any constitutional symptoms. Of note, the patient has recently returned from a trip to the Caribbean. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals multiple circular, erythematous, crusted lesions with central clearing on the patient's abdomen, chest, back, arms, and legs. Multiple ulcers are also noted. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Perform an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for Lyme disease
B: Prescribe oral prednisone
C: Apply a wet compress of 1:10,000 potassium permanganate for 15 minutes 2 times a day
D: Start treatment with oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
E: Administer a single dose of 250 mg of ketoconazole
Answer: D

Question: A 37-year-old woman presents with a history of exposure to a close friend who was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. She was told by her friend that she need to see a physician because she needs to be treated as well, even if she is not having symptoms yet. She currently denies any headaches, vision changes, nausea or vomiting, or neck stiffness. Her physical exam is within normal limits. Her vital signs are stable. She is prescribed rifampin for prophylaxis with specific instructions on when to follow up if symptoms develop. When asked about the possibility of pregnancy, she mentioned that she uses combination oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for contraception. The physician suggested that her husband should use condoms for contraception as she requires antibiotic therapy. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the need for additional contraception? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of estrogens.
B: Rifampin inhibits CYP3A4, which metabolizes progestins.
C: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of progestins.
D: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of estrogens.
E: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of progestins.
Answer: B

Question: A 58-year-old man with hypertension and dyslipidemia comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He says he feels well. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 103 kg (227 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His BMI last year was 27 kg/m2. When asked about his diet, he says, “Being overweight runs in my family. Rather than fight it, I just try to enjoy myself and eat what I want.” . Which of the following defense mechanisms best describes the patient's response to the physician? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Rationalization
B: Rationalization
C: Rationalization
D: Distortion
E: Rationalization

Question: A 20-year-old woman presents to the physician with a 2-week history of dysuria, increasing urgency, and increased frequency of micturation. On examination, her bladder is full. Laboratory results are as follows:
Urinalysis: pH 9.0, protein-negative, glucose-negative, ketones-negative, bilirubin-negative, urobilinogen-moderate, leukocyte esterase-positive, nitrite-positive, red blood cells 3/hpf, white blood cells 15/hpf, bacteria numerous, epithelial cells rare. Urine microscopy shows white blood cells and bacteria. Which of the following antimicrobial agents are not the most likely to be effective for the treatment of this patient's symptoms?
Options: A: Amoxicillin
B: Nitrofurantoin
C: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
D: Ciprofloxacin
E: Augmentin
Answer: B

Question: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of a painless, nonpruritic skin lesion on her right thigh. She initially thought it was an insect bite, but it has slowly increased in size over the past weeks. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule. When the skin lesion is squeezed, the surface retracts inwards. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Dysplastic nevus
B: Dermatofibroma
C: Dermatofibroma
D: Actinic keratosis
E: Seborrheic keratosis

Question: A 37-year-old woman is seen in the clinic for a follow-up after having a miscarriage at 8 weeks gestation. Her pregnancy test result today is negative. She had a Dilatation and Curettage (D&C). While reviewing her prenatal labs, it is discovered that she has a positive Screen for Rhesus factor (Rh) sensitization (IgG Alloantibody) at 1:16. The patient is Rh-negative. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Rh(D) immune globulin 300 μg IV
B: Rh(D) immune globulin IV 1250 μg IV
C: Rh(D) immune globulin 500 μg IM
D: Rh(D) immune globulin 300 μg IM
E: Rh(D) immune globulin 400 μg IV
Answer: C,D,E

Question: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with nausea, vomiting, fever, and pain in the right upper quadrant of his abdomen for the past 18 hours. He mentions that he has been experiencing intermittent episodes of pain at the same location over the last 3 months and that these episodes usually occur after a heavy meal and subside within 1 or 2 hours. On physical examination, his temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. On examination of the abdomen, tenderness is present over the right upper quadrant; palpation over the area produces an inspiratory pause. An urgent bedside ultrasonogram shows a dilated common bile duct stone, but no stone in the common bile duct or in the gallbladder. Laboratory results show the following:
Hemoglobin 15.4 g/dL (9.56 mmol/L)
Total leukocyte count 14,000/mm3 (17.4 x 10*9/L)
Segmented neutrophils 70%
Lymphocytes 25%
Monocytes 4%
Eosinophils 1%
Basophils 0%
Platelet count 32,0000/mm3 (320 x 10*9/L)
Serum bilirubin (total) 1.8 mg/dL (30.78 μmol/L)
Serum bilirubin (direct) 1.1 mg/dL (18.81 μmol/L)
Serum alanine aminotransferase 96 U/L
Serum aspartate aminotransferase 88 U/L
Serum alkaline phosphatase
350 U/L (5.83 μkat/L)
. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Urgent ercp (ecrp)
B: Urgent endosc retro cholangiopa (ecrp)
C: Medical management followed by elective open cholecystectomy
D: Urgent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ECRP)
E: Urgent erp (ecrp)

Question: A 48-year-old woman with a known history of chronic kidney disease stage 4 and hypertension presents to the emergency room with the sudden onset of severe, acute chest pain and shortness of breath. On exam, blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 28 breaths/minute, heart rate is 90 beats/minute, and oxygen saturation is 90% on 2 liters by nasal canula. Auscultation of the lungs reveals increased expiratory wheezing bilaterally. The patient's electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia with occasional premature ventricular contractions. Which of the following medications leads to the adverse effects described above?
Options: A: Calcium channel blockers
B: Beta blockers
C: Loop diuretics
D: Thiazide diuretics
E: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
Answer: C

Question: A 47-year-old man with a 4-year history of hypertension presents to the clinic for follow-up. His blood pressure is 150/96 mm Hg on multiple readings. He denies chest pain, dyspnea, or angina. He takes hydrochlorothiazide 50 mg and lisinopril 10 mg, both taken once daily. Physical examination reveals a BMI of 38 and a grade II/VI systolic murmur. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
Options: A: Begin therapy with a beta-blocker
B: Increase the dose of hydrochlorothiazide to 100 mg once daily
C: Add a long-acting calcium channel blocker
D: Add a second-generation angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor
E: Increase the dose of lisinopril to 20 mg once daily
Answer: C

Question: A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to your office with dysphagia and halitosis. If this patient is also found to have cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction, which of the following are the most likely cause of his presenting symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Esophago pharyngeal diverticula
B: Zenkers diverticulum
C: Glossopharyngeal nerve damage
D: Hypopharyngeal diverticulum
E: Zenker's diverticulum

Question: A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to your office with dysphagia and halitosis. If this patient is also found to have cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction, which of the following are not the most likely cause of his presenting symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.

Question: A 20-year-old gravida 1, para 0 woman, at 38 weeks' gestation, presents to the physician because of the sudden onset of blurred vision in her left eye. She says the vision loss began while she was sitting at her desk doing office work. She denies any previous history of ocular symptoms. Her medical history is remarkable for type 1 diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled, diagnosed at the age of 10 years. Her last eye examination was 5 years ago, and the results were normal. On examination, her blood pressure is 170/98 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 96 beats/min. Examination of the left eye shows BCVA of 20/200, a normal pupillary examination, and a macula-disk ratio of 1.0 with no areas of exudate, hemorrhage, or cotton wool spots. The optic nerve is swollen with evidence of pallor. The vitreous fluid is clear. Examination of the right eye shows 20/20 BCVA and no abnormalities. Her HbA1c is 6.8%. Random serum glucose is 105 mg/dL. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Central retinal vein occlusion
B: Optic neuritis
C: Retinal detachment
D: Diabetic retinopathy
E: Vitreous detachment
Answer: B

Question: A 55-year-old woman presents to the office because she has been feeling weak. For the past 2 years, she has been urinating a considerable volume every time she goes to the bathroom. She has no past medical history. Her heart rate is 86/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), and blood pressure is 111/79 mm Hg. Laboratory studies are significant for the following:
Calcium 13.8 mg/dL
PTH 230 pg/mL
Her complete metabolic panel is otherwise within normal limits. Imaging studies show subperiosteal resorption and osteoporosis. Scintigraphy reveals the most common pathologic condition associated with the patient’s diagnosis. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Adenoma
B: Carcinoma
C: Decreased calcitriol concentration
D: Adenoma
E: Adenoma

Question: A 75-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents to the office for a routine checkup. For the past 2–3 days, he has had new pain and swelling in the left leg. He also has dyspnea that is worse with walking and that wakes him from sleep at night. He says that his legs swell throughout the day. His vital signs are blood pressure 158/80 mm Hg, heart rate 80/min, and respiratory rate 18/min. Examination reveals mild swelling bilaterally in the legs and feet. Mild pitting edema is present in the left leg. He has rales at the left lung base. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Heparin
B: Niacin
C: Propranolol
D: Propranolol
E: Lasix
Answer: D,E

Question: A 54-year-old man with esophageal cancer undergoes an esophagectomy [esophagus removal] and radical mediastinal lymphadenectomy. After surgery, he experiences increased esophageal secretions, nausea, and vomiting. Which of the following medications would be most helpful to reduce inflammation and inhibit gastric acid secretion in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Sumatriptan
B: Omeprazole
C: Cefazolin
D: Metoclopramide
E: Diphenhydramine
Answer: B,D

Question: A 36-year-old man undergoes open reduction and internal fixation of a left femur fracture sustained after a motor vehicle collision. Three days after the surgery, he develops fever and redness around the surgical site. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F). Physical examination shows purulent discharge from the wound with erythema of the surrounding skin. Wound culture of the purulent discharge shows gram-positive cocci in clusters. Treatment with oral dicloxacillin is initiated. Four days later, the patient continues to have high-grade fever, pain, and purulent discharge. Which of the following characteristics of the infecting organism best explains the failure to improve with antibiotic therapy? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Adaptation in binding proteins
B: Presence of an impenetrable outer membrane
C: Ability to cleave β-lactam rings
D: Development of efflux pumps
E: Adaptation in binding proteins

Question: A 35-year-old man is evaluated for fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, and lower extremity edema of 3 months duration. He has no history of heart disease or hypertension. Fifteen years ago he had a heart murmur, which was told to be innocent. Examination shows JVD, heaves, and crackles bilaterally at the lung bases. His lungs are clear to auscultation. The first heart sound is normal; a murmur is present. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Endomyocardial biopsy
B: Cardiac MRI
C: Pacemaker
D: Renal angiography
E: Cardiac echo

Question: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a change in his personality. The mother reports that over the past 7 months her son has become increasingly withdrawn; he has not answered any phone calls or visited his family and friends. He had always been a quiet boy, who needed some time on his own, but he used to meet with friends at least once a week. The patient says that he cannot leave the house because aliens are watching him and “stealing his thoughts”. He does not drink alcohol. He used to smoke marijuana occasionally but quit 1 year ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, it is impossible to follow the patient's sequence of thoughts. He is anxious and has a flat affect. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Schizophrenia
B: Delusional disorder
C: Schizophrenia
D: Schizophrenia
E: Schizophrenia

Question: A medical student is preparing a patient for an appendectomy. He is asked by the surgeon to disinfect the patient’s skin with a chlorhexidine-isopropyl alcohol solution before the procedure. Recent studies have shown that this solution substantially reduces the risk of surgical site infections compared with a povidone-iodine preparation without alcohol in clean-contaminated surgery. Which of the following mechanisms best describes the mechanism of action of chlorhexidine? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Its activity depends on ph and is greatly reduced in the presence of organic matter
B: Protein coagulation/denaturation
C: Cell wall damage by free radical release
D: Attack of free-sulfur amino acids, nucleotides, and fatty acids within the bacteria
E: Its activity depends on pH and is greatly reduced in the presence of organic matter

Question: An 11-month-old male infant is brought to his pediatrician by his mother. She is concerned about his leg and his inability to stand. He was born vaginally to a 33-year-old woman (gravida 3, para 2) from an uncomplicated pregnancy at 39 weeks. He has met all developmental milestones and is up to date on all vaccinations. His mother explains that he can normally stand without help and can walk briefly on his own. However, he hit his right leg against a chair 2 days ago. The area became edematous and bruised overtime and the infant became unable to stand or crawl and cries when he puts weight on it. The mother denies any child abuse from her family or child care. The patient’s vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 80/40 mm Hg, heart rate 137/min, respiratory rate 25/min, and temperature 36.7°C (97.0°F). His length and weight are both between the 15th and 25th percentile. On physical examination, blue-grayish discoloration of the sclerae are noted. Respiratory, cardiovascular, and abdominal examinations are within normal limits for his age. There is joint hypermobility and decreased tone in both upper and lower extremities. The patient’s right calf appears slightly deformed, edematous, and warm to the tough. The patient begins to cry loudly when the physician palpates his leg. The patient’s X-ray shows an incomplete fracture of the right tibial diaphysis. What are the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Child abuse
B: Insufficient production of procollagen type 1
C: Mutation in the gene encoding fibrillin-1
D: Insufficient production of procollagen kind 1
E: Insufficient production of procollagen type 1

Question: A 26-year-old woman presents to the office with a 4-week history of progressive lower extremity weakness, slurred speech, and difficulty swallowing. She also has been experiencing frequent urination, excessive thirst, and a 15-pound weight loss. On examination, the patient has muscle weakness in the extremities and decreased reflexes. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be elevated in the patient's blood?
Options: A: Anti-double-stranded DNA antibody
B: Anti-Ro (SSA) antibody
C: Anti-HIV antibody
D: Anti-nuclear antibody
E: Anti-streptolysin O antibody
Answer: B

Question: A 3-day-old male is evaluated in the hospital nursery for delayed passage of meconium. His mother is breastfeeding and has started to produce milk. The patient has been feeding well every two hours and is urinating over eight times per day. The patient was born at 35 weeks gestation to a 27-year-old gravida 4. The patient is of Ashkenazi Jewish descent, and the patient’s parents denied all prenatal genetic testing. The pregnancy was uncomplicated until the patient’s mother had spontaneous rupture of membranes at 35 weeks gestation. The patient’s three older siblings are all healthy. In the hospital nursery, the patient’s temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 48/32 mmHg, pulse is 164/min, and respirations are 48/min. On physical exam, he appears to be in moderate distress. He has no dysmorphic features, and his abdomen is distended and non-tender. Bowel sounds are absent.

. Which of the following are the best next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Abdominal CT
B: Abdominal radiograph
C: Contrast enema
D: Upper gastrointestinal series
E: Sweat testing

Question: A woman is seen in the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. She is pregnant at 27 weeks gestational age. The emergency department physician notes a small laceration repair site on her forehead and diagnoses a concussion with loss of consciousness of less than 1 minute. The patient was not wearing a seatbelt at the time of the accident. She denies abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and contractions. On pelvic examination, the uterine fundus is palpated at the umbilicus and the cervix is closed. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Admit the patient to the hospital.
B: Administer IV fluids bolus.
C: Obtain an MRI of the fetus.
D: Obtain fetal heart rate monitoring

Question: An 8-year-old boy presents to a physician with a 2-week history of an itchy genital rash and dysuria. His mother thought it was a diaper rash; however, the rash has not improved with topical diaper rash cream. Physical examination shows erythema and edema of the penis and scrotum. Options: A: Candida albicans
B: Herpes simplex virus
C: Chlamydia trachomatis
D: Trichomonas vaginalis
E: Neisseria gonorrhea
Answer: A,B,C

Question: A 46-year-old woman presents to her physician for an annual physical examination with complaints of occasional nausea, early satiety, and epigastric pain. Her symptoms have been present for the past 3 months and are worsening. She has no history of weight loss, hematemesis, melena, or hematochezia. Question: A 60-year-old female presents with dizziness, lightheadedness, and intermittent syncope. Symptoms are worse when she stands. She also experiences difficulty concentrating. Question: A six-year-old boy with a history of asthma currently uses an albuterol inhaler as needed to manage his asthma symptoms. Question: The parents of a 16-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes mellitus present requesting information about the drug, exenatide, an injectable drug that only needs to be administered once a week. The patient’s blood glucose levels have been difficult to control on his current insulin regimen due to poor adherence to recommended therapy, and he has had difficulty putting on weight despite eating copiously. The patient is afebrile and his vital signs are within normal limits. His body mass index (BMI) is 19 kg/m2. Which of the following best describes why the patient should not be switched to exenatide? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Insulin production by the pancreas is insufficient for exenatide to be effective.
B: Exenatide suppresses glucagon secretion, which increases the risk of hypoglycemia.
C: Suppression of appetite makes it even harder for him to gain weight.
D: Soluble insulin production by the pancreas is insufficient for exenatide to be effective.
E: Insulin product production by the pancreas is insufficient for exenatide to be effective.

Question: A 36-year-old woman with a history of symptomatic iron deficiency anemia is seen in the clinic today, complaining of fatigue and pica. The patient is currently receiving oral iron therapy. Physical exam and laboratory findings are shown below.

Physical Exam:
Temperature: 36.8°C (98.2°F)
Respiratory rate: 16 breaths/min
Heart rate: 78 beats/min
Blood pressure: 122/74 mm Hg
BMI: 18.3 kg/m2

Laboratory findings:
ESR: 30 mm/hr (N: 0-20 mm/hr)
Hgb: 10.5 g/dL (N: 12-15 g/dL)
Hct: 30.1% (N: 36-48%)
Ferritin: < 1.0 ng/mL (N: 12-300 ng/mL)
TIBC: 580 µg/dL (N: 250-450 µg/dL)

Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options:
A: Obtain a stool sample for occult blood
B: Increase oral iron therapy to 200 mg twice daily
C: Begin IV iron therapy
D: Begin pulsatile iron therapy
E: Obtain an upper endoscopy
Answer: C

Question: A 68-year-old man with a history of a 30 pack-year smoking history and frequent alcohol use over the past 40 years presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of shortness of breath and generalized body weakness. His current medications include acetylsalicylic acid 81 mg daily, atorvastatin 40 mg once daily, and lisinopril 20 mg once daily. Physical examination shows his blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 25/min with an oxygen saturation of 88% on 2 L of nasal cannula oxygen. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are unremarkable. His abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended. Extremities show 1+ pitting edema bilaterally in his lower extremities. Laboratory studies show:
WBC 3.6 103/mL (normal: 4.5–11.0)
Hemoglobin 13.0 g/dL (normal: 13.5–17.5)
Platelets 130 103/µL (normal: 150–450)
Creatinine 1.5 mg/dL (normal: 0.8–1.2)
Total bilirubin 1.8 mg/dL (normal: 0.2–1.2)
Glutamate-oxaloacetic transaminase (GOT) 40 U/L (normal: 5–30)
Glutamate-pyruvate transaminase (GPT) 50 U/L (normal: 5–35)
Alkaline phosphatase 102 U/L (normal: 40–150)
Serum albumin 3.1 g/dL (normal: 3.5–5.0)
International normalized ratio 1.1
Urinalysis:
pH 7.5
Specific gravity 1.015
Glucose negative
Protein 1+
Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Hepatocellular carcinoma
B: Secondary hypertension
C: Alcoholic cirrhosis
D: Chronic lung disease
E: Hypertension
Answer: B,D

Question: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath and a non-productive cough for 2 months. She has been unable to perform her daily activities. She has had malaise and bilateral ankle pain during this period. She noticed her symptoms after returning from a vacation to Arizona. She is a research assistant at the university geology laboratory. She is originally from Nigeria and visits her family there twice a year; her last trip was 3 months ago. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is no palpable cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Her left eye is notable for ciliary injection and photophobia. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Sarcoidosis
B: Pulmonary tuberculosis
C: Sarcoidosis
D: Sarcoidosis
E: Sarcoidosis

Question: A 27-year-old woman presents to a physician with a history of exposure to a close friend who was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. She was told by her friend that she need to see a physician because she needs to be treated as well, even if she is not having symptoms yet. She currently denies any headaches, vision changes, nausea or vomiting, or neck stiffness. Her physical exam is within normal limits. Her vital signs are stable. She is prescribed rifampin for prophylaxis with specific instructions on when to follow up if symptoms develop. When asked about the possibility of pregnancy, she mentioned that she uses combination oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for contraception. The physician suggested that her husband should use condoms for contraception as she requires antibiotic therapy. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the need for additional contraception? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of estrogens.
B: Rifampin inhibits CYP3A4, which metabolizes progestins.
C: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of progestins.
D: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of estrogens.
E: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of progestins.
Answer: A,B,C

Question: A 59-year-old woman with a history of diabetes and hypertension is evaluated for dyspnea and fatigue. On physical examination, there is jugular venous distension and bilateral crackles on auscultation of the lung bases. ECG demonstrates sinus tachycardia. A chest x-ray is shown.

His vitals are a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg, pulse of 78/min, and respiratory rate of 12/min. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with shifting dullness on percussion. In addition, multiple purple spider web-like lesions are present on the chest and arms, which blanch when pressure is applied. Fecal occult blood test is negative. On anoscopy, a non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion is noted superior to the pectinate line. Which of the following are most likely true about this patient’s current symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: The blood vessels bulging drain into the superior recto venous vessel.
B: The vascular protrusion drains into the superior rectal vein.
C: The blood-vessels protruding drain device into the superior rectal venous tree organ part.
D: The blood vessel trunk protrusion drain into the superior recto veined.
E: Fecal leukocytes and a stool culture are required for diagnosis.

D: The blood vessel trunk protrusion drain into the superior recto veined.
E: Fecal leukocytes and a stool culture are required for diagnosis.

Question: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of fatigue, dyspepsia, and bloating after meals for the past several months. She denies any history of anorexia, weight loss, abdominal pain, or nausea. She has been otherwise healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her abdomen is slightly tender to palpation without hepatomegaly or splenomegaly. A blood smear shows mild macrocytosis with oval red blood cells. Which of the following laboratory tests will most likely confirm the diagnosis?
Options: A: Serum gastrin
B: Transferrin saturation
C: Schilling test
D: Serum ferritin
E: Serum folate
Answer: D

Question: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 4-week history of dry cough which is worse at night, fever, and chills. She also reports unintentional weight loss and loss of appetite. She denies night sweats. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 20 years. Her respirations are 20 breaths per minute, temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), heart rate is 100 beats/minute, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs reveals decreased breath sounds at the right base. Laboratory studies show:
Leukocytes 6000/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 62%
Lymphocytes 13%
Platelet count 310,000/mm3
Hemoglobin 9.9 mg/dL
Chest  
X-ray findings are shown in the image. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Tuberculosis
B: Congestive heart failure
C: Staphylococcal pneumonia
D: Bacterial pneumonia
E: Lung cancer
Answer: B

Question: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe dyspnea, wheezing, and palpitations. His symptoms began approx. 20 minutes after being stung by a bee on the left arm. Past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he takes labetalol. While being questioned, the patient becomes obtunded. His vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F); blood pressure 85/55 mm Hg; pulse 110/min; respiratory rate 31/min; and oxygen saturation 90% on room air. On physical examination, an area of severe edema and erythema is noted on the extensor surface of the left forearm, and there is severe angioedema of the face and neck. The patient is intubated, and aggressive fluid resuscitation and intramuscular epinephrine are administered. A repeat blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg, despite these efforts. Which of the following are the next best step in the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Administer glucagon
B: Administer glucagon
C: Administer glucagon
D: Administer diphenhydramine and ranitidine
E: Administer glucagon

Question: A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife. He has been coughing for 3 days, but today he also started having chest pain and shortness of breath. The chest pain is pleuritic in nature and is worse with coughing or inspiration. He denies any hemoptysis, nausea, or vomiting. Vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 130/82 mm Hg; heart rate 100/min; respiratory rate 26/min; and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. Physical exam reveals bilateral rales, dullness to percussion, and decreased breath sounds in both lung fields. Which of the following are the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Chest radiography
B: Computed tomography of the chest
C: Pleural fluid cytology
D: Lung biopsy
E: Needle aspiration of the lung
Answer: A

Question: A 67-year-old man presents to the physician because of recent episodes of light-headedness. He also mentions that he has noticed swelling of both his ankles and difficulty breathing when lying flat. His body weight has increased by 20 lb (9.1 kg) over the past year. His blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distension, and there are bibasilar rales. The liver is palpable 5 cm below the costal margin. The patient has 3+ pitting edema in both feet and ankles, and the skin over the shins is thin and shiny. Which of the following is not the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
Options: A: Hyperthyroidism
B: Inflammatory cardiomyopathy
C: Ischemic cardiomyopathy
D: Congestive heart failure
E: Myocarditis
Answer: A

Question: A 53-year-old man presents to his physician’s office with a persistent cough which he has had over the last few months. He was diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) the previous year and since then has been on a short-acting β-agonist to help alleviate his symptoms. Since his diagnosis, he has quit smoking, a habit which he had developed about 30 years ago. He used to smoke about 2 packs of cigarettes daily. Today, he has come in with an increase in his symptoms. He tells his physician that he has been having a fever for the past 3 days, ranging between 37.8°–39°C (100°F–102.2°F). Along with this, he has a persistent cough with copious amounts of greenish-yellow sputum. He has also been having difficulty breathing. On examination, his temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), the respirations are 22/min, the blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, and the pulse is 115/min. Slight crackles and respiratory wheezes are prominent in the lower lung fields. His FEV1 is 57% of his normal predicted value. He is started on oxygen and a dose of oral prednisone. At this time, which of the following should also be considered as a treatment option? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Doxycycline
B: Doxycycline
C: Erythromycin
D: Piperacillin
E: Antibiotics would not be appropriate at this time

Question: An 8-month-old girl is brought by her parents to the emergency department because she has had a fever of 39.4°C (103°F) for 2 hours. She normally has 1–2 episodes of loose stools daily, but this has increased to 5–6 episodes of watery green stools over the past 4 hours. She has also been irritable and refuses to eat. She was born at 40 weeks' gestation with a birth weight of 3400 grams and has been meeting her developmental milestones. Her only recent change was that she started attending day care 1 month ago. Examination shows mild dehydration. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 140/min, and respirations are 25/min. Capillary refill time is 3 seconds. The anterior fontanelle is soft and sunken. Her neck is supple. Her pharynx is mild red and edematous. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Her heart has regular rate and rhythm. Abdomen is soft and non-tender with hypoactive bowel sounds. Rectal examination is negative. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Stool culture
B: Urine culture
C: Blood culture
D: Hospital admission
E: Intravenous fluids
Answer: D,E

Question: A 62-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine visit. She is postmenopausal. She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. She is prescribed both lisinopril and metformin. She has occasional headaches and has noticed that she has mild intermittent diarrhea. She drinks alcohol socially and does not smoke. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of this patient's intermittent diarrhea?
Options: A: Metformin
B: Lisinopril
C: Metformin
D: Lisinopril
E: Lisinopril
Answer: C

Question: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she has not had a menstrual period. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 57 kg (125 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the breasts shows a secondary mound formed by the nipple and areola. Pubic hair is sparse and lightly pigmented. Abdominal examination shows bilateral firm, nontender inguinal masses. Pelvic examination shows a blind-ended vaginal pouch. Ultrasonography does not show a uterus or ovaries. Which of the following are the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Castration surgical
B: Gonadectomy
C: Testosterone therapy
D: Vaginal dilatory therapy
E: Prednisolone therapy

Question: A 68-year-old woman presents with a history of 2 months of unintentional weight loss of 15 pounds. She has not increased her physical activity. She also has been experiencing abdominal pain, anorexia, and fatigue. On physical examination, her vital signs are within normal limits, and there is right upper-quadrant abdominal tenderness. Results of a liver function test are as follows:
Total bilirubin is 0.8 mg/dL (range 0.1-1.2 mg/dL)
AST is 150 IU/L (range 10-40 IU/L)
ALT is 176 IU/L (range 10-40 IU/L)
Alkaline phosphatase is elevated at 75 IU/L (range 30-120 IU/L)
Which of the following are the most appropriate next steps in the evaluation of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Liver biopsy
B: Computerized tomography (CT) scan of the liver
C: Erythropoietin level
D: Hepatitis B serology
E: Hepatitis C serology
Answer: B,D,E

Question: A 32-year-old woman with chronic myeloid leukemia comes to the physician with complaints of pancytopenia, fatigue, night sweats, and abdominal pain. A peripheral blood smear demonstrates 70% myeloblasts. On bone marrow aspiration, 80% myeloblasts are noted. Cytogenetic analysis shows a translocation of the ABL1 gene, resulting in the Philadelphia chromosome. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Gene therapy
B: Interferon therapy
C: Radiation therapy
D: Chemo-immunotherapy
E: Bone marrow transplant
Answer: A,B,C,D,E

Question: A 40-year-old male presents to your office complaining that he is too weak to climb stairs or brush his hair. He denies any headaches or change in vision. A muscle biopsy reveals CD8+ lymphocyte infiltration in the endomysium. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Polymyositis
B: Scleroderma
C: Polymyalgia rheumatica
D: Polymyositis
E: Polymyositis

Question: A 26-year-old man is seen in the emergency department with 1 day of altered mental status. He is reportedly a chronic alcoholic and was found by a friend unresponsive at home. His physical examination is notable for hypotension (80/50 mm Hg), crusting of his lips, and asterixis. His laboratory testing shows:
Glucose 75 mg/dL
Sodium 130 mEq/L
Potassium 3.5 mEq/L
Chloride 100 mEq/L
HCO3- 11 mEq/L
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
AST 101 U/L
ALT 65 U/L
Total bilirubin 6.4 mg/dL
Albumin 2.5 g/dL
Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's central nervous system (CNS) abnormality? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Ethanol drip
B: Intravenous fluids
C: Antipsychotics
D: Propranolol
E: Glucagon
Answer: B

Question: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. He has noticed that it is easier for him to climb the stairs after he has exercised. He has also had a 4.6-kg (10.1-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremity is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. His achilles reflex is 1+. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Polymyalgia rheumatica
B: Myasthenia gravis
C: Myopathic myasthenic syndrome of lambert eaton
D: Hypothyroidism
E: Lambert-Eaton syndrome

Question: A 32-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a 3-day history of pain in the right upper quadrant (RUQ) of the abdomen. She says the pain arose spontaneously and gradually worsens. She has had nausea but no vomiting. She was diagnosed with gallstones 3 years ago and has been treated with conservative therapy. On physical examination, the physician finds right upper quadrant pain to palpation. Lab results include the following:
Bilirubin, total: 2.9 mg/dL
AST: 264 IU/L
ALT: 225 IU/L
ALP: 95 IU/L
Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Hepatic ultrasound
B: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast
C: MRI of the abdomen
D: Helicobacter pylori (H pylori) breath test
E: Gastric juice analysis
Answer: A

Question: A 36-year-old multigravida presents to the labor department at a hospital because her bag of waters broke 2 hours ago. She is 38 weeks gestation. She denies any difficulty breathing or chest pain. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), her pulse is 105/min, and her blood pressure is 160/102 mm Hg. On pelvic examination, she is 4 cm dilated, 90% effaced, and -1 station. Her cervix is soft and anterior. The fetal presentation is cephalic, and the fetal heart rate is 135 beats/min. Which of the following tests is not indicated at this time?
Options: A: Urine culture
B: Blood culture
C: Intravenous pyelogram
D: Continuous electronic fetal monitoring
E: Group B streptococcal screening
Answer: C

Question: A 56-year-old man comes to the clinic for a check-up. He presents with a 1-year history of worsening shortness of breath and weight loss. He is a former construction worker, and worked in a steel mill when he was in high school. He is an active smoker with a 36-pack-year smoking history. The blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg, pulse rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, and the BMI is 31 kg/m2. The patient is afebrile and the oxygen saturation at rest is 95% on room air. The pulmonary examination reveals a mildly prolonged expiratory phase, and no wheezing or crackles are auscultated. A pulmonary function test is recommended for the patient, and 2 weeks later he returns with a report that shows an FEV1/FVC ratio of 60% and FEV1 of 50% of the predicted value. The lung volumes show a total lung capacity of 110% of predicted value, a residual volume of 115% of predicted value, and a DLCO of 60% of predicted value. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Asbestosis
B: Obesity hypoventilation syndrome
C: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
D: Bronchiectasis
E: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

Question: A 26-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a follow-up after undergoing a colonoscopy 2 weeks ago. The colonoscopy had shown a 6 cm tumor of the ascending colon. She has had no prior history of abdominal pain or changes in bowel habits. On physical examination, she has no palpable abdominal mass, and the remainder of the examination is within normal limits. Laboratory studies show a lactic acid level of 3.5 mmol/L (N < 1.7 mmol/L) and a bicarbonate level of 20 mEq/L (N 28–30 mEq/L). Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Crohn disease
B: Ulcerative colitis
C: Myocardial infarction
D: Diabetic ketoacidosis
E: Colon cancer
Answer: E

Question: A 56-year-old woman comes to the clinic today for a postoperative follow-up of breast cancer surgery. She feels that the scar from surgery is healing nicely and states that she has some mild pain that is relieved with acetaminophen. Her current vital signs are: temperature 37°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, respiratory rate 16/min, and blood pressure 120/80 mm Hg. On examination, there is a well-healed scar on the left breast. Your physical exam is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Perform a mammogram of the right breast
B: Order a mammogram of the affected breast
C: Perform routine mammograms every 6–12 months
D: Continue to prescribe acetaminophen for pain relief
E: Prescribe adjuvant chemotherapy
Answer: B,C,E

Question: Three patients present to the pediatrician for routine well-child visits. The first child’s mother reports that he seems to be breastfeeding well and voids at least eight times per day. His stools are a yellow color, and he does not seem to be straining. In the office, he can lift his head and chest when in the prone position, and he can track an object with his eyes to the midline. His hands remain fisted 50% of the time.

The second child’s parents report that she is doing well at home and seems to enjoy playing with her older brother. In the office, she can roll from supine to prone and can transfer her rattle from hand to hand. She cannot yet say any words.

The third child’s father reports that he is starting to explore the world around him. He has begun taking independent steps at home. In the office, he seems to recognize the name of several objects, but he cannot follow the direction to “grab the ball.” All three children are assessed as developmentally normal.

. Which of the following represents these patient's respective ages? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Ages 1 month, 4 months, and 9 months
B: Ages 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months
C: Ages 2 months, 4 months, and 12 months
D: Advanced glycation endproducts 2mo, 6 months, and 12mo
E: Ages 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months

Question: A 24-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks' gestation presents with a 1-week history of shortness of breath, cough, and dyspnea. She denies any fever, chills, or weight loss. Her vital signs are as follows:
Temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F)
Pulse 105/min
Respirations 24/min
Blood pressure 120/80 mm Hg
Oxygen saturation 96% on room air
On physical examination, she is in respiratory distress with an expiratory wheeze bilaterally. Chest x-ray shows bilateral infiltrates in a perihilar distribution. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
B: Legionella pneumophila pneumonia
C: Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia
D: Herpes simplex virus pneumonia
E: Hepatitis B reactivation
Answer: B,C

Question: A 30-year-old man arrived at the emergency department after being stung by a brown recluse spider on his right lower extremity. On arrival, his pain is sever. Examination reveals a dusk lesion on the extremity. His vital signs include a temperature of 39.1°C (102.3°F), a heart rate of 125 beats/min, and a BP of 80/65 mm Hg. Which of the following is not the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's condition?
Options: A: Admit the patient to the ICU
B: Administer antivenom and pain medication
C: Order an electrocardiogram (ECG)
D: Elevate the lower extremity
E: Apply a cold compress to the extremity

Question: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion, generalized fatigue, and irritability for the past week. She has been unable to recall her husband's name or their address. She has had insomnia and daytime sleepiness during this period. Her last bowel movement was 3 days ago. One month ago, she underwent a transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt (TIPS) placement. She has alcoholic liver cirrhosis. Current medications include spironolactone and furosemide. She used to drink over a pint of vodka daily but quit 2 months ago. She is oriented to place and person. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 102/64 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice. There are several telangiectasias over the chest and back. Palmar erythema is present. The abdomen is mildly distended and nontender. She completes the number connection test slower than the age-normalized standard. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Reversal of TIPS
B: Paracentesis
C: Administer IV ceftriaxone
D: Administer lactulose
E: Administer lactulose measurement

Question: A 22-year-old male patient presents to a physician with a history of intermittent chest pain for the past 3 days. He is an active smoker, has a 30-year history of asthma and occasional use of inhaled albuterol inhaler, and takes cyclosporine for a renal transplant. His mother has a history of CAD. On examination, there is a grade 2/6 systolic murmur. An EKG shows sinus tachycardia with ST-elevation in leads 2 and 3. What is the most appropriate next step in management at this time?
Options: A: Analgesia
B: Aspirin
C: Angioplasty
D: Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)
E: Dipyridamole
Answer: B

Question: A 63-year-old man from the countryside presents with leg swelling and right upper abdominal tenderness. He reports a history of myocardial infarction 4 years ago, but he has no supporting documentation. At the moment, his only medication is aspirin. He also stated that he used to have ‘high blood sugars’ when checked in the hospital 4 years ago, but he did not follow up regarding this issue. He works as a farmer and noticed that it became much harder for him to work in the last few days because of fatigue and syncope. He has a 24-pack-year history of smoking and consumes alcohol occasionally. The vital signs include: blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate 83/min, respiratory rate 16/min, and temperature 36.5℃ (97.7℉). On physical examination, the patient is pale and acrocyanotic. There is a visible jugular vein distention and bilateral lower leg pitting edema. The pulmonary auscultation is significant for occasional bilateral wheezes. Cardiac auscultation is significant for a decreased S1, S3 gallop, and grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border in the 4th left intercostal space. Abdominal percussion and palpation are suggestive of ascites. The hepatic margin is 3 cm below the right costal margin. Hepatojugular reflux is positive. Which of the following are the most likely clinical finding observed in this patient on an echocardiogram? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Augment peak tricuspid valve incompetence
B: Increased peak tricuspid regurgitation
C: Augmented peak tricuspid valve regurgitation
D: Abnormal left ventricular relaxation
E: Increased peak tricuspid valve regurgitation
