Question: A 60-year-old male was seen in the outpatient clinic for evaluation of a 1-year history of progressive forgetfulness. He had been working as a technician at a steel plant for the last 20 years but has been gradually retiring from work. He is not taking any medications. The vital signs are stable. Neurological examination shows marked memory impairment and poor concentration. There are no abnormalities in cranial nerve examinations. Deep tendon reflexes are normal and bilateral plantar responses are flexor. Additional investigations were done as part of his work-up.
Which of the following test findings are not likely to be observed? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Endogenous IgG antibodies to cholesterol
B: Hyperlipidemia
C: Hypocarotenemia
D: Intracellular vacuoles in his skin characteristic of the storage of solid material
E: Reduced cerebrospinal fluid protein
Answer: E

Question: A 55-year-old man presents to a rheumatologist with bilateral wrist and knee pain that has been present for the last 10 years. The patient was a professional athlete who retired at age 50. He also notes morning stiffness in his joints that lasts approx. 50 minutes. He denies joint swelling, color changes in his digits, dryness of mucous membranes, and constitutional symptoms such as fever and chills. On physical exam, the physician notes several non-tender nodules on the left 1st, 3rd, and 4th distal interphalangeal joints. There is also tenderness with palpation at the base of both thumbs. The patient’s knees are enlarged, bilaterally, and he has pain and crepitus on passive range of motion. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Arthritis osteoarthritis
B: Rheumatoid arthritis
C: Hypertrophic arthritis
D: Osteoarthritis
E: Oa

Question: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a learning disability. His teachers have reported hyperactivity during class, difficulties with social interaction, and poor scores on reading and writing assessments. Molecular analysis shows an increased number of CGG trinucleotide repeats. Which of the following findings are most likely to be seen on physical examination of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Long face and large everted ears
B: Long face and large everted ears
C: Long face and large everted ears
D: Flat facies and protruding tongue
E: Long face and large everted ears

Question: A 78-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of 2 weeks of dark yellow urine and bright yellow skin. She reports a good appetite and no weight loss or anorexia. She has had constipation with dark tarry stools for the past 7 days. She denies fevers or chills. She admits to experiencing abdominal pain that comes and goes, but it is worse with eating. Physical exam reveals an oriented and alert woman in no acute distress. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. There is a mild jaundice tint of her skin and sclera. Her liver edge is palpable about 4 cm below the right costal margin. Her spleen is not palpable. The remainder of the physical examination findings are unremarkable. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13 g/dL (N 12‑15 g/dL)
Total bilirubin 9 mg/dL (N < 1 mg/dL)
Direct bilirubin 2 mg/dL (N < 0.2 mg/dL)
AST 130 U/L (N < 40 U/L)
ALT 190 U/L (N < 50 U/L)
Alkaline phosphatase 150 U/L (N 35‑135 U/L)
Extended liver panel is normal.
Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Cholangiocarcinoma
B: Whipple's disease
C: Chronic hepatitis
D: Primary biliary cholangitis
E: Acute hepatitis
Answer: C,E

Question:  A 61-year-old man was started on rosuvastatin 40 mg 8 weeks ago and presents today for a follow-up. He complains of pain in his legs and general weakness. On physical exam, he has full range of motion of his extremities but complains of pain. His blood pressure is 126/84 mm Hg and heart rate is 74/min. The decision is made to stop the statin and return to the clinic in 2 weeks to assess any changes in symptoms. After stopping the statin, his muscular symptoms resolve. What are the next best course of action to take regarding his LDL control? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Restart rosuvastatin at a lower dose
B: Initiate fenofibrate
C: Initiate a different statin
D: Initiate fish oils
E: Restart rosuvastatin a little t super little a lower dosage

Question: A 46-year-old female presents to the urgent care clinic with an itchy rash on her hands and wrists. She reports that she has been gardening this morning and this rash appeared afterwards. She feels that the rash is getting worse and her hands are starting to swell. She also has a headache and feels lightheaded. She denies any nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, chest pain, shortness of breath, or changes in urination. On examination, she is afebrile, has a blood pressure of 112/78 mmHg, a pulse of 84 bpm, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. She has a pruritic erythematous rash on her hands and wrists along with some swelling. Which of the following is NOT an appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Give her oral diphenhydramine
B: Apply calamine lotion
C: Give her an intramuscular injection of epinephrine
D: Offer her hydrocortisone cream
E: Monitor her airway and oxygenation status
Answer: C

Question: A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On presentation, he is found to have scalp and trunk lacerations that are still actively bleeding. He has no past medical history and does not take any medications. On presentation, his temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 110/74 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, and respirations are 17/min. On physical exam, he is found to be anxious but does not have any visible injuries other than the lacerations. Which of the following processes would most likely be seen in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Increases norepinephrine at the sinus node of keith and flack
B: Augmented norepinephrine at the pacemaker cardiac
C: Increased acetylcholine at the sinoatrial node
D: Increased atrial natriuretic peptide release
E: Increased norepinephrine at the sinoatrial node

Question: A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On presentation, he is found to have scalp and trunk lacerations that are still actively bleeding. Question: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being stabbed in the right chest. On examination, there is a 3-cm laceration in the 2nd intercostal space in the right anterior axillary line and he has shortness of breath. Pulses are present in all 4 extremities are weak. Respirations are labored and he is tachypneic. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Breath sounds are decreased in the left hemithorax. On chest x-ray, there is a pneumothorax in the left hemithorax and mediastinal shift to the right. Which of the following diagnostic test will be the most useful in determining the extent of the patient's injury? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Electrocardiogram
B: Pulmonary angiogram
C: Mediastinoscopy
D: Thoracentesis
E: Echocardiography
Answer: C

Question: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive dysphagia. She has no heartburn, regurgitation, or odynophagia. She denies nausea, vomiting, and chest pain. She has lost 5 kg (11 lb) within the past month. She has no history of ethanol or tobacco use. Her father was diagnosed with esophageal adenocarcinoma at age 60 years. On examination, her heart rate is 80 beats/minute, blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and respirations are 16 breaths/minute. The results of a physical examination are normal. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in evaluation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Upper endoscopy
B: Colonoscopy
C: Esophageal manometry
D: Computed tomography of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis
E: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
Answer: A,C

Question: A 67-year-old man is hospitalized after several days of fever and increasing shortness of breath. Respiratory viral panel returns positive for influenza A and the patient is started on a standard five day course of oseltamivir. Despite therapy, his shortness of breath continues to worsen and his oxygen saturation decreases to the point where ICU transfer and intubation are required. Chest radiograph shows bilateral infiltrates. Clinical criteria are consistent with development of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). After several weeks of supportive therapy, the patient improves with lung function returning to near normal. Which of the following processes are involved in the regeneration of alveolar lining after damage to alveoli occurs? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Proliferation of surfactant-cellular secretion cellula
B: Sweeping of debris out of the alveoli by ciliated cells
C: Excess mucus production by goblet cells
D: Proliferation of surfactant-secreting cells
E: Proliferation of club cells

Question: A 67-year-old man is hospitalized after several days of fever and increasing shortness of breath. D,E

Question: A 36-year-old woman was evaluated in the clinic for recurrent strep throat. She has had multiple episodes of strep over the past few winters. Her physical examination revealed no abnormalities. A rapid strep test is positive. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Observation
B: Treat with penicillin V
C: Reassure no therapy
D: Treat with penicillin G
E: Perform serology
Answer: B,D

Question: A 21-year-old female presents to the office after a health screening in which she was found to have high blood pressure. At the office, the blood pressure is 168/114 mm Hg. You have seen the patient in the past for amenorrhea and infertility issues, but she denies taking any medication at this time. On examination, the patient is short and normal weight but has a webbed neck. Which of the following are the most likely cause of the elevated blood pressure? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Central fusion of the inferior poles of the kidneys 
B: Genetic predisposition to essential hypertension
C: Neuroendocrine tumor of the adrenal gland
D: Oral contraceptive use
E: Central location fusion of the inferior poles of the kidney bilateral

Question: A 30-year-old male presents with an itchy, erythematous rash on the penis. He denies recent sexual contact. He did notice a couple of small vesicles on the corona of the penis 2 days before the onset of the rash. He has no history of herpes. The patient has oily skin and acne. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
Options: A: Syphilis
B: HIV infection
C: Genital herpes
D: Tinea corporis
E: Contact dermatitis
Answer: D

Question: A 65-year-old man presents to a physician for a follow-up visit regarding his symptoms of confusion and memory loss. Fifteen years ago, he was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease and has been taking donepezil for 10 years. He lives with his wife, who has recently noted a worsening of his forgetfulness and mood changes. She reports that he has difficulty performing common activities of daily living (ADLs), such as cooking and eating. His wife also notes that he sleep for 14 hours a day and no longer cares about social interactions. The patient reports that he is tired, but he denies depression. On physical examination, the patient has anterograde memory problems, verbal fluency issues, and restlessness. Vital signs are normal. Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) score is 10/30. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Reduce donepezil dose by half and reevaluate in 2 weeks
B: Switch from donepezil to rivastigmine
C: Switch from donepezil to memantine
D: Add bupropion to donepezil
E: Evaluate for a urinary tract infection
Answer: A,C

Question: A 38-year-old woman undergoes a partial thyroidectomy for an enlarged thyroid gland compressing the trachea. During surgery, a young surgeon ligates the inferior thyroid arteries as close to the poles as possible to prevent intraoperative hemorrhage. 2 weeks later, the patient presents to the outpatient clinic with hoarseness. What could be the most likely cause of her hoarseness? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Internal laryngeal nerve injury
B: Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury
C: Phrenic nerve damage
D: External laryngeal nerve injury
E: Laryngeal edema

Question: A 38-year-old woman undergoes a partial thyroidectomy for an enlarged thyroid gland compressing the trachea. During surgery, a young surgeon ligates the inferior thyroid arteries as close to the poles as possible to prevent intraoperative hemorrhage. 2 weeks later, the patient presents to the outpatient clinic with hoarseness. What could not be the most likely cause of her hoarseness? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Internal laryngeal nerve injury
B: Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury
C: Phrenic nerve damage
D: External laryngeal nerve injury
E: Laryngeal edema

B,E

Question: A 52-year-old male presents with a 6-week history of cough, fevers, and night sweats. He denies productive cough, hemoptysis, or wheezing. He has a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes. He is allergic to penicillin. On examination, dry inspiratory crackles are heard at the right base. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Transbronchial lung biopsy
B: Bronchoscopy with lavage
C: Sputum culture
D: Thoracentesis
E: Echocardiography
Answer: B

Question: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a low-grade fever, worsening fatigue, and mild intermittent abdominal pain that is not affected by eating. He reports that over the last 6 months he slept a lot more than usual and lost 14.9 kg (33 lbs) without trying to lose weight. He also complains of chest pain and shortness of breath that is worse when he is working and in the yard. There is no significant family history. His long-standing male partner passed away 2 years ago in a fatal car accident. His blood pressure is 145/75 mm Hg, the pulse is 90/min, the respiratory rate is 23/min, and the temperature is 38°C (100.5°F). On physical examination, he has pale mucous membranes, conjunctival hemorrhages, and petechiae on his lower extremities. There is a new-onset high-pitched blowing diastolic murmur best heard over the right upper sternal border. His head bobs with each heartbeat. There are small, painless, red macules on both palms. His spleen is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin. His laboratory results are shown below.
Hemoglobin 8.4 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 72 µm3
Platelet count 400,000/mm3
Leukocytes 6,000/mm3
Serum ferritin 8 ng/mL
Serum iron 27 µg/dL
Total iron-binding capacity 450 µg/dL
Colonoscopy with biopsy is later performed showing a neoplastic growth in the descending colon. Which of the following are the most likely explanation for his cardiac findings? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Viridans streptococci
B: Treponema pallidum
C: Group D streptococci
D: Group D streptococci
E: Group D streptococci

Question: A 28-year-old woman sees her primary care physician because of swelling of the right parotid gland. The swelling began 3 weeks ago and has become much larger in the last 2 days. It is painless and firm to palpation. It is non-erythematous and non-tender. There is no oral pain. She denies recent dental work. She denies fevers, chills, weight loss, or night sweats. Her medical history is significant for anxiety for which she takes lorazepam. She is afebrile. Heart rate is 78/min, respiratory rate is 10/min, and blood pressure is 112/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is a 3 cm round, firm mass in the right parotid gland. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy is performed, which shows benign hyperplasia of the salivary gland. Which of the following are the most appropriate next steps in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Cisplatin
B: Parotidectomy
C: Radiation therapy
D: Reassurance
E: Wait and watch
Answer: E

Question: A 22-year-old man with sickle cell disease is brought to the emergency room for acute onset facial asymmetry and severe pain. He was in school when his teacher noted a drooping of his left face. His temperature is 99.9°F (37.7°C), blood pressure is 122/89 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for facial asymmetry and 4/5 strength in the patient's upper and lower extremity. A CT scan of the head does not demonstrate an intracranial bleed. Which of the following are the most appropriate treatment for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Alteplase
B: Exchange transfusion
C: Heparin
D: Hydroxyurea
E: Warfarin

Question: A 22-year-old man with sickle cell disease is brought to the emergency room for acute onset facial asymmetry and severe pain. He was in school when his teacher noted a drooping of his left face. His temperature is 99.9°F (37.7°C), blood pressure is 122/89 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Which of the following are not the most appropriate treatment for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.

B: Exchange transfusion

E: Warfarin

Question: A 41-year-old female presents to the office with complaints of urinary frequency, nocturia, and hesitancy for the past 2 months. Her symptoms have progressively worsened and she now has urgency as well. She also reports incontinence several times per day. Her menstrual periods occur 28 days apart and last 5 days with minimal dysmenorrhea. She has no history of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and denies any vaginal discharge or dyspareunia. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, her heart rate is 80 bpm, and her respiratory rate is 16 bpm. Her pelvic examination is normal. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Perform a cystoscopy
B: Perform a barium enema
C: Perform a voiding cystourethrogram
D: Perform a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain
E: Perform a transrectal ultrasound
Answer: C

Question: A 57-year-old male presents to the clinic for evaluation of edema and hypertension. His medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus type 2, and hypertension. Current medications include atorvastatin and hydrochlorothiazide. Physical examination includes blood pressure 160/90 mmHg, and examination of the cardiovascular system shows regular rate and rhythm. General examination shows 1+ lower extremity edema. Urinalysis shows proteinuria, and serum creatinine is 1.2 mg/dL. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in the evaluation and management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Captopril
B: Echocardiography
C: Renal ultrasonography
D: Kidney biopsy
E: Atenolol
Answer: A,B,C,D

Question: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine visit. His psychiatric history is significant for major depression with psychotic features. He was diagnosed after his wife died from pancreatic cancer four years earlier. Three years ago, he deliberately overdosed on sleeping pills. Today, he feels well but still wakes up frequently at night and cannot sleep through the night. He lives alone in his apartment and has no children. He does not possess a firearm at home but has access to weapons at a local hunting club. The patient currently denies suicidal thoughts or thoughts of self-harm. He takes sertraline and olanzapine. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Which of the following are the strongest risk factor for suicide in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Previous suicide attempt
B: History of psychosis
C: Access to firearms
D: Sleeping disorder
E: Previous suicide attempt

Options: A: Previous suicide attempt
B: History of psychosis
C: Access to firearms
D: Sleeping disorder
E: Previous suicide attempt

Question: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 7-day history of fever, dry cough, and malaise. He denies shortness of breath, chills, rhinorrhea, sore throat, or myalgia. He has no medical history and takes no medications. On examination, his temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 85/min, respiratory rate is 16/min., and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. His oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs reveals decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung field. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for evaluating this patient's pneumonia? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Chest x-ray
B: Computed tomography scan of the chest
C: Pneumothorax
D: Sputum culture
E: Transthoracic echocardiogram
Answer: A,D

Question: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother for worsening wheezing and shortness of breath over the past day. He has not had a fever, cough, vomiting, or diarrhea. He has asthma and eczema. He uses a glucocorticoid inhaler and an albuterol inhaler but has missed his medications for the past week while on vacation. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 100/80. Expiratory and inspiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. There are moderate intercostal and subcostal retractions and a decreased inspiratory to expiratory ratio. Nebulized albuterol and ipratropium treatments and intravenous methylprednisolone are given in the emergency department for a presumed asthma exacerbation. One hour later, the child is limp and lethargic. Magnesium sulfate is administered. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/70. No wheezing is heard on repeat pulmonary examination. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Intubate with mechanical ventilation
B: Intubate with mechanical breathing assisted
C: Perform bronchoscopy
D: Intubate with mechanical respiratory assist
E: Provide additional dose of methylprednisolone

Options: A: Intubate with mechanical ventilation
B: Intubate with mechanical breathing assisted

E: Provide additional dose of methylprednisolone

Question: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because she is concerned about exposure to a tick. The boy is well appearing. He developed a rash 2 days earlier. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min. He is alert and oriented. A round, red, erythematous lesion measuring 4 cm in diameter is noted on the right buttock. An eschar is present in the center of the lesion. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Acyclovir
B: Clarithromycin
C: Cefuroxime axetil
D: Doxycycline
E: Rifampin
Answer: D

Question: A 24-year-old man presents with shortness of breath, and elevated jugular pressure. His liver is enlarged and tender. He has a non-productive cough, and some chest pain. He denies any syncope, or hematemesis. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 78/min, blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 22/min. Examination of the respiratory system shows decreased breath sounds at the right base. Examination of the cardiovascular system shows elevated jugular venous pressure, a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, and cardiomegaly on chest X-ray. Examination of the gastrointestinal system shows hepatomegaly and epigastric tenderness. Examination of the endocrine system shows gynecomastia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this man's symptoms?
Options: A: Conстриctive pericarditis
B: Hepatitis
C: Right-sided heart failure, chronic
D: Pulmonary embolism
E: Coronary artery disease
Answer: A

Question: A 49-year-old female with a history of alcoholism was found lying unconscious on a bench at a local park and rushed to the emergency department. Upon arrival, the patient regained consciousness and complained of intense bilateral flank pain and a recent decrease in urination. Urine microscopy demonstrated abundant square crystals of calcium oxalate that looked like “folded envelopes." . Which of the following findings are most likely to be seen in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Anion gap cellular metabolic process acidosis
B: Anion gap metabolic acidosis
C: Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis
D: Respiratory acidosis
E: Respiratory alkalosis

Question: A 49-year-old female with a history of alcoholism was found lying unconscious on a bench at a local park and rushed to the emergency department. Upon arrival, the patient regained consciousness and complained of intense bilateral flank pain and a recent decrease in urination. Urine microscopy demonstrated abundant square crystals of calcium oxalate that looked like “folded envelopes." . Which of the following findings are not most likely to be seen in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Anion gap cellular metabolic process acidosis
B: Anion gap metabolic acidosis
C: Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis
D: Respiratory acidosis
E: Respiratory alkalosis

B

Question: A 17-year-old boy presents for a routine physical examination. His physical exam is unremarkable. He reports no illnesses or injuries. Which of the following immunizations should this patient receive? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Live-attenuated zoster vaccine
B: Hepatitis A vaccine
C: Hepatits B vaccine
D: Influenza vaccine
E: Meningococcal vaccine
Answer: A,B,C,D,E

Question: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, nausea, and vomiting. The patient states that his symptoms started last night and have persisted to this morning. He has a past medical history of asthma, and his current medications include albuterol and fluticasone. His temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg, pulse is 95/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, the patient seems uncomfortable. He requests that the lights in the room stay turned off during the physical exam. The patient's cardiac exam demonstrates a normal rate and rhythm, and his pulmonary exam is clear to auscultation bilaterally. Musculoskeletal exam reveals diminished mobility of the neck in all four directions, with flexion of the neck causing the patient discomfort. Lumbar puncture is performed and results are seen below.

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF):
Cell count: 175/mm^3
Cl-: 119 mEq/L
Glucose: 49 mg/dL
Pressure: 150 mmH2O
Total protein: 55 mg/dL

. Which of the following are the best treatment for this patient's most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Intravenous (iv) fluid and monitoring
B: Amphotericin and 5-flucytosine
C: Ceftriaxone
D: Ceftriaxone and vancomycin
E: IV fluids and monitoring

Question: A 53-year-old man with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity is evaluated in the clinic. He notes that his current symptoms began about 7 years ago when he first became awoken from sleep by episodes of shortness of breath, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Over the past 6 months, he has noticed increased dyspnea on exertion. He has not seen any significant swelling in his lower extremities. Although he has never smoked, he does have occupational history of exposure to organic solvents as a cabinet maker for 20 years. His vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 170/90 mm Hg, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, heart rate 92 beats/min, and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. On physical exam, breath sounds are diminished bilaterally, although there is no wheezing or rales. He does have bilateral lower extremity edema up to the knees with 2+ pitting edema bilaterally. Which of the following are the possible conditions that this patient has? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Primary hypertension
B: Pulmonary arterial hypertension
C: Valvular heart disease
D: Diabetes
E: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
Answer: B,D,E

B

Question: A 65-year-old man presents with left-sided weakness, numbness, and difficulty speaking. He is afebrile. Neurological examination demonstrates a left hemiparesis with dysarthria and left hemianopia. Blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. A CT scan demonstrates a left-sided intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH). The patient undergoes surgical evacuation of the hematoma. His neurological status does not change. On day 5 after surgery, the patient suddenly becomes agitated and diaphoretic and the heart rate increases to 130/min. Blood pressure increases to 200/120 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals fever and nuchal rigidity. Lumbar puncture reveals cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis with neutrophilic predominance. What is the most likely organism to be causing this infection?
Options: A: Candida
B: Listeria
C: Streptococcus pneumoniae
D: Staphylococcus aureus
E: Pseudomonas auruginosa
Answer: D

Question: A 14-year-old obese boy presents with severe right hip and knee pain. The patient says that he has been limping with mild pain for the past three weeks, but the pain acutely worsened today. He describes the pain as severe, non-radiating, sharp and aching in character, and localized to the right hip and knee joints. The patient denies recent illness, travel, trauma, or similar symptoms in the past. No significant past medical history and no current medications. The patient is not sexually active and denies any alcohol, smoking or drug use. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, pulse 72/min, respiratory rate 15/min, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is alert and cooperative. The right leg is externally rotated, and there is a limited range of motion in the right hip. Strength is 4 out of 5 at the right hip joint and 5 out of 5 elsewhere. There is no tenderness to palpation. No joint erythema, edema or effusion present. Sensation is intact. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Laboratory tests are unremarkable. Plain radiographs of the right hip joint are significant for displacement of the right femoral head inferoposterior off the femoral neck. Which of the following are the most appropriate course of treatment for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Surgical service pinning of the right hip region
B: Surgical service pinning of the r hip
C: Services surgical pinning of the right hip
D: Pavlik harness
E: Surgical pinning of the right hip

Question: A 21-year-old woman presents to the health care provider with a complaint of fatigue, fever, arthralgias, and myalgias, which began 1 week ago. She has had no recent insect bites or travel. Physical examination shows no rash and an erythematous throat. Laboratory tests show:
• Leukocyte count 12,000/mm3
• Neutrophils 80%
• Red blood cell count 4×106/mm3
• Hemoglobin 13 g/dL
• Platelets 140,000/mm3
• Negative - Mono spot test
• Negative - Streptococcal antibody test
Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in diagnostic evaluation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Reassure the patient that no further testing is necessary.
B: Start therapy with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid (Augmentin).
C: Perform a nasal swab for culture.
D: Order a blood culture.
E: Obtain a viral isolation panel.
Answer: C, D, E

Question: A 55-year-old man presents to a clinic for a routine checkup. His vital signs are normal. On physical examination, a non-tender, firm, and fixed 2-cm mass is found in the left lobe of the thyroid. The patient denies dysphagia, hoarseness, weight changes, or swelling in the neck and reports a 2-year history of dry mouth. His TSH is 1.44 mIU/L (reference range, 0.35 to 5.5 mIU/L). He has never smoked and denies alcohol consumption. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Perform fine-needle aspiration
B: Refer to a surgeon for thyroidectomy
C: Observe clinically
D: Perform radioactive iodine scan of the thyroid
E: Obtain a thyroid ultrasound
Answer: B

Question: An investigator is studying the cell morphologies of the respiratory tract. He obtains a biopsy from the mainstem bronchus of a patient. On microscopic examination, the biopsy sample shows uniform squamous cells in layers. Which of the following best describes the histologic finding seen in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Metaplasia
B: Metaplasia
C: Dysplasia
D: Hyperplasia
E: Metaplasia

Question: An investigator is studying the cell morphologies of the respiratory tract. He obtains a biopsy from the mainstem bronchus of a patient. On microscopic examination, the biopsy sample shows uniform squamous cells in layers. Which of the following do not best describes the histologic finding seen in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Metaplasia
B: Metaplasia
C: Dysplasia
D: Hyperplasia
E: Metaplasia

Question: A 29-year-old female presents to the clinic for a regular check-up. She has no specific complaints. Vital signs include: blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, heart rate is 76/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F). Her physical examination is within normal limits. The woman’s complete blood count shows an absolute increase in the cells shown in the first image. Which of the following are true regarding these cells? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: These cells transform to macrophages when they migrate to peripheral tissues.
B: These the cell transform to macrophages when they migrate to peripheral tissues.
C: These cells express CD25 on their surfaces.
D: These cells normally constitute 25–40% of total leucocyte count.
E: These cells have lymphoid origin.

Question: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of a rash that has been present for 3 weeks. He is otherwise well. The rash began as small, red, pruritic macules on his right leg and has since spread to both legs and his back. Examination shows numerous red, 5‑mm macules with a few papules, scattered over both legs and the back. There is no scaling. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Pemphigus vulgaris
B: Bullous pemphigoid
C: Lichen planus
D: Herpes zoster
E: Atopic dermatitis
Answer: C

Question: The first 24 hours after delivery, a 2888 g (6.37 lb) male newborn is not feeding well, has a high-pitched cry, and is diaphoretic. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, after an uncomplicated labor and delivery. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother did not receive prenatal care. She takes codeine syrup frequently for dry cough. The infant's temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 165/min, and blood pressure is 83/50 mm Hg. Examination shows hyperreflexia, tremors, and an excessive startle response. The baby is swaddled to prevent excoriations, and fluid resuscitation is initiated. Complete blood count and serum levels of glucose, bilirubin, and calcium are within normal limits. What are the most appropriate next step in treatment of this newborn? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Oral morphine therapy
B: Oral clonidine therapy
C: Intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin combination therapy
D: Orally morphine therapeutic procedure
E: Dextrose infusion

Question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent skin lesions. The episodes of lesions started at the age of 2 months and multiple treatment options have been attempted without success. He has also had several episodes of respiratory tract infections, enlarged lymph nodes, and recurrent fevers since birth. The boy attends daycare. His older brother has asthma. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. He appears ill. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows several raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groins, and extremities; some secrete pus. Cervical and axillary lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Chronic granulomatous disease
B: Chronic granulomatous disease
C: Chronc graft-vs-host dis granulomatous disease
D: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
E: Chronic graft versus host disease granulomatous disease

Options: A: Chronic granulomatous disease
B: Chronic granulomatous disease
C: Chronc graft-vs-host dis granulomatous disease
D: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
E: Chronic graft versus host disease granulomatous disease

Question: A 59-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed seizure that lasted for 5 minutes. She is alert and fully oriented. A neurologic examination shows no focal deficits. Her blood pressure is 134/86 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 12/min. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F). Electrolytes, BUN, and creatinine are normal. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm. The patient denies a history of any medical problems. She takes no medications and drinks 1–2 glasses of wine daily. She has no family history of seizures. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Obtain a head CT scan.
B: Obtain transcranial Doppler ultrasonography.
C: Obtain repetitive nerve stimulation studies.
D: Obtain serologic tests for HTLV-1.
E: Obtain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain.
Answer: A

Question: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of vaginal bleeding, intermittent lower abdominal pain, and decreased urinary output. Menstrual periods have been regular in the past. Her last period was 8 months ago. She has had 2 previous children. She has never smoked or used drugs. She had gonorrhea 5 years ago. She admits to occasional alcohol use but denies any current or past IV drug abuse. She is sexually active with 1 male partner who has had multiple sex partners. She has tried showering but her symptoms persist. She had a hysteroscopy 1 week ago that showed the presence of a cervical polyp and multiple endometrial polyps, which were removed. The polyps were biopsied and were found to be benign. She has continued to have vaginal bleeding since the procedure. On physical examination, she is afebrile and in no acute distress. Examination of the abdomen shows a benign, slightly tender mass on the lower left side. Examination of the external genitalia shows no abnormalities. A vaginal examination shows a severely atrophic vagina and multiple polyps seen protruding from the cervix. Cervix is fixed and tender. A Pap smear is obtained. Which of the following is the most appropriate explanation for this patient's current findings?
Options: A: Radiation therapy
B: Carcinosarcoma
C: Atrophic vaginitis
D: Endometrial cancer
E: Cervical cancer
Answer: C

Question: A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of worsening upper abdominal pain for the past 8 hours. She reports that the pain radiates to her back and is associated with nausea. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which she takes enalapril, furosemide, and simvastatin. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 84/58 mm Hg, and pulse is 115/min. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Examination shows abdominal distention with epigastric tenderness and guarding. Bowel sounds are decreased. Extremities are warm. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 48%
Leukocyte count 13,800/mm3
Platelet count 175,000/mm3
Serum  
Calcium 8.0 mg/dL
Urea nitrogen 32 mg/dL
Amylase 250 U/L
An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following are the most likely underlying cause of this patient's vital sign abnormalities? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Abnormal coagulation and fibrinolysis
B: Capillary leakage
C: Decreased cardiac output
D: Capillary leakage
E: Capillary leakage

Question: A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of worsening upper abdominal pain for the past 8 hours. Question: A 38-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of severe, watery diarrhea that started 1 day ago. She had been traveling in Mexico for the past 2 weeks. 36 hours prior to symptoms onset, she ate raw oysters on a half shell. Her anorexia is not improved with adequate fluid intake. She notes several episodes of vomiting that began 12 hours ago. She has chills and reports a body temperature of 38.8°C (101.8°F) at home. She has no abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal tenderness. Her stool is watery and green in color. Laboratory studies show the presence of occult blood and leukocytes in stool. Examination of a stool sample shows numerous Gram-negative comma-shaped organisms with tufts of flagella on one end. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Ciprofloxacin
B: Doxycycline
C: Levofloxacin
D: Ethambutol
E: Vancomycin
Answer: C,D

Question: A 19-year-old woman presents with a recent diagnosis of type 1 diabetes. She is seen in the clinic for diabetes education. She is instructed about the management of her condition, including regular blood glucose monitoring, insulin administration, and adjustment of her insulin regimen based on her blood glucose results. The nurse provides the patient with a blood glucose monitor and demonstrates how to use it. The patient is also given a logbook to record her blood glucose readings and insulin doses. Prior to the patient's discharge from the clinic, the nurse reviews the patient's understanding of her diabetes management plan. Which of the following statements by the patient indicate that she understands the teaching? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: "I should check my blood glucose before each meal."
B: "The first thing I do in the morning is check my blood glucose."
C: "I should keep track of my blood glucose readings and insulin doses in my logbook."
D: "I should adjust my insulin dose if my blood glucose is too high or too low."
E: "If my blood glucose is high, I should exercise to lower it."
Answer: A,C,D

Question: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with crushing chest pain (10/10 in severity), radiating to the left side of the neck and the left arm. His symptoms started 20 minutes ago while shaving. He also feels nauseated, lightheaded and short of breath. He has had type 2 diabetes for 27 years and essential hypertension for 19 years. He has smoked 20–30 cigarettes per day for the past 35 years. Family history is irrelevant. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), the blood pressure is 115/72 mm Hg and the pulse is 107/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. ECG is shown in the image. Troponins are elevated. The patient is admitted to a unit with continuous cardiac monitoring. Aspirin, clopidogrel, sublingual nitroglycerin, and morphine are given immediately and the patient now rates the pain as 4–5 out of 10. Which of the following are the best next step in the management of this patient condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Percutaneous coronary intervention
B: Percutaneous coronary interventions
C: Coronary artery bypass graft
D: Percutaneous coronary intervention
E: Oral eplerenone

Question: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with crushing chest pain (10/10 in severity), radiating to the left side of the neck and the left arm. His symptoms started 20 minutes ago while shaving. He also feels nauseated, lightheaded and short of breath. He has had type 2 diabetes for 27 years and essential hypertension for 19 years. He has smoked 20–30 cigarettes per day for the past 35 years. Family history is irrelevant. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), the blood pressure is 115/72 mm Hg and the pulse is 107/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. ECG is shown in the image. Troponins are elevated. The patient is admitted to a unit with continuous cardiac monitoring. Aspirin, clopidogrel, sublingual nitroglycerin, and morphine are given immediately and the patient now rates the pain as 4–5 out of 10. Which of the following are not the best next step in the management of this patient condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Percutaneous coronary intervention
B: Percutaneous coronary interventions
C: Coronary artery bypass graft
D: Percutaneous coronary intervention
E: Oral eplerenone

Question: A 37-year-old man presents to the physician with a history of edentulism associated with poor oral hygiene. His skin examination reveals erythematous, vesiculobullous plaques over the dorsal surface of both hands in a butterfly pattern. The patient has a history of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome for which he takes warfarin. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's skin lesions? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Pemphigus vulgaris
B: Lupus erythematosus
C: Bullous pemphigoid
D: Dermatitis herpetiformis
E: Pemphigus foliaceus
Answer: B

Question: A 21-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her mother because she is having difficulty walking. She has a history of anxiety disorder and depression, which are currently in remission. She was fine yesterday, and her mother does not recall any particular event that may have precipitated these symptoms. Her mother noticed that she seemed agitated and was having difficulty talking earlier in the morning. On arrival, she is afebrile with blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg, pulse of 84/min, and respirations of 20/min. The physical examination reveals hyperactive reflexes, and hypertonia. Initial laboratory results are as follows:
Sodium 133 mEq/L (N 135-145 mEq/L)
Potassium 4.2 mEq/L (N 3.5-5.0 mEq/L)
Glucose 110 mg/dL (N 70-110 mg/dL)
Blood urea nitrogen 12 mg/dL (N 10-20 mg/dL)
Creatinine 0.63 mg/dL (N 0.40-1.00 mg/dL)
Serum calcium 9.2 mg/dL (N 8.4-10.2 mg/dL)
Magnesium 2.3 mg/dL (N 1.7-2.4 mg/dL)
Phosphate 4.4 mg/dL (N 2.4-4.1 mg/dL)
Which of the following laboratory evaluations are not the most appropriate for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Serum ammonia
B: Urine pH
C: Urine specific gravity
D: Serum osmolality
E: Serum protein electrophoresis
Answer: B,C,E

Question: A 23-year-old man presents with swelling of the left knee. He noticed the swelling a day ago while preparing for the college basketball game. He has had approximately 10 different sexual partners in the past 3 months. Synovial fluid tap shows a WBC count of 90,000 cells/mm3. What are the mechanism of action of the drug which is indicated for the treatment of this patient’s most likely condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Metabolic inhibitor
B: Cell wall inhibitor
C: Neutrophil migration inhibitor
D: Prostaglandin inhibitor
E: Uric acid synthesis inhibitor

Question: A 23-year-old woman presents to the hospital for elective surgery. However, due to an unexpected bleeding event, the physician had to order a blood transfusion to replace the blood lost in the surgery. After this, the patient became irritable and had difficulty breathing, suggesting an allergic reaction, which was immediately treated with epinephrine. This patient is otherwise healthy, and her history does not indicate any health conditions or known allergies. The physician suspects an immunodeficiency disorder that was not previously diagnosed. If serum is taken from this patient to analyze her condition further, which of the following would be expected? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Low iga, normal capillary refill time igg and igm
B: Low IgA, high IgG, normal IgE
C: Low IgA, normal IgG, and IgM
D: Low iga, normal capillary refill time ab.igg & igm
E: Low iga, normal igg and igm

Question: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He endorses diffuse abdominal tenderness. His past medical history is notable for diabetic nephropathy, hypertension, dyslipidemia, depression, and morbid obesity. He also is currently being treated for an outbreak of genital herpes. His temperature is 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 184/102 mmHg, pulse is 89/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an obese man in no acute distress. A CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is performed and is unremarkable. The patient is admitted to the observation unit for monitoring of his pain. Notably, the patient's abdominal pain improves after an enema and multiple bowel movements. The patient's evening laboratory values are ordered and return as seen below.

Serum:
Na+: 141 mEq/L
Cl-: 99 mEq/L
K+: 4.8 mEq/L
HCO3-: 11 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 177 mg/dL
Creatinine: 3.1 mg/dL

. Which of the following are the most likely etiology of this patient's laboratory derangements? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Acyclovir
B: Metformin
C: Insulin
D: Metformin
E: Metformin

Question: A 51-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain. She denies a history of angina. She states she had a respiratory tract infection 15 days ago. Examination reveals poor perfusion, cardiovascular rate of 110/min, respiratory rate of 28/min, and oxygen saturation of 92% via room air. Her lungs are clear. Auscultation of the heart is remarkable for an S4 gallop and a mid-diastolic murmur. A chest x-ray reveals mild pulmonary congestion. An echocardiogram shows an ejection fraction of 40% and mild mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Acute rheumatic fever
B: Myopericarditis
C: Dressler syndrome
D: Streptococcal pharyngitis
E: Myocarditis
Answer: A,B,D

Question: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of periodic painful double vision for 3 days. Her symptoms occur only when looking sideways. She has myopia and has been wearing corrective lenses for 10 years. Ten days ago, she lost her balance and fell off her bike, for which she went to a hospital. A CT scan of the head at that time showed no abnormalities and she was released without further treatment. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Her best corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in each eye. She has an adduction deficit in the right eye and nystagmus in the left eye when looking left; she has an adduction deficit in the left eye and nystagmus in the right eye when looking right. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral disc hyperemia. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's findings? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus
B: Compressive tumor of the pons
C: Oxidative damage due to thiamine deficiency
D: Subdural hematoma extending into the orbit
E: Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus

Question: A 17-year-old girl comes to the office for a routine gynecologic examination. She has had her menarche 3 years ago and menses are occurring regularly every 28–31 days with 5–6 days of bleeding. She has had no prior pregnancies. She has recently been sexually active with her boyfriend, who has agreed to wears condoms during intercourse. She requests birth control pills and wants to make sure they are effective. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Counsel her on barrier methods of contraception
B: Obtain a urine pregnancy test
C: Start her on an oral contraceptive within 7 days of her next menstrual period
D: Prescribe a progesterone-only pill immediately
E: Offer her diaphragms for use with spermicide
Answer: B,C

Question: A 30-year-old man comes to the clinic with a 6-month history of fatigue, malaise, weight loss, and loss of appetite. He notes bilateral painless enlargement of his lymph nodes. He reports no night sweats, fevers, or chills. His medical history is unremarkable. Family history is notable for an older brother who died at age 14 of a T-cell lymphoma. On physical exam, his temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Numerous palpable lymph nodes are noted in the cervical, axillary, and inguinal regions. The nodes are firm, mobile, and nontender. The rest of the examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.8 g/dL
Hematocrit 38.2%
Platelet count 120,000/mm3
Leukocytes 15,000/mm3 (normal differential)
Serum sodium 136 mEq/L
Potassium 4.9 mEq/L
Chloride 100 mEq/L
Bicarbonate 23 mEq/L
BUN 19 mg/dL
Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL
Glucose 99 mg/dL
Calcium 9.3 mg/dL
AST 33 U/L
ALT 66 U/L
Total bilirubin 0.6 mg/dL
Albumin 3.2 g/dL
Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Sarcoidosis
B: Hodgkin disease
C: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
D: Lupus
E: Miliary tuberculosis
Answer: D,E

Question: A 47-year-old female undergoes a thyroidectomy for treatment of Graves' disease. Post-operatively, she reports a hoarse voice and difficulty speaking. You suspect that this is likely a complication of her recent surgery. What are the embryologic origin of the damaged nerve that is most likely causing this patient's hoarseness? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: 1st pharyngeal arch
B: 2nd pharyngeal arch
C: 3rd pharyngeal arch
D: 4th pharyngeal arch
E: 6th pharyngeal arch

Question: A 47-year-old female undergoes a thyroidectomy for treatment of Graves' disease. Post-operatively, she reports a hoarse voice and difficulty speaking. Question: A 62-year-old male is seen for evaluation of shortness of breath. He reports that he is unable to perform simple tasks, such as walking up the stairs, without shortness of breath. He has noticed that he has bilateral swelling of his feet at the end of the day. He reports that his urine is foamy. He is being treated with atorvastatin for hypercholesterolemia. Physical examination demonstrates blood pressure of 174/86 mm Hg in both arms, pulse 96/min, respiratory rate 18/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.7°F). Examination of the heart reveals a laterally displaced point of maximal impulse and an S4 gallop. Examination of the abdomen reveals a normal examination without hepatosplenomegaly or ascites. Examination of the lower extremities reveals 1+ pitting edema bilaterally. The remainder of the examination is normal. An echocardiogram reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction of 45% and a small pericardial effusion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Prescribe a calcium channel blocker
B: Prescribe a diuretic
C: Prescribe an ACE inhibitor
D: Prescribe digoxin
E: Prescribe a beta-blocker
Answer: B,C

Question: A 7-day-old infant boy presents to an emergency department due to poor feeding. His parents are recent immigrants to the United States. He was born in a traditional home birth and has never seen a medical provider. Mom had no prenatal care, has no medical issues, and is unvaccinated. The baby had been breastfeeding well until 24 hours ago when mom noticed he started having trouble latching. In the last 12 hours, he has completely refused to feed. He has had a decreased number of wet diapers and has stooled twice in the last 24 hours. His temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mmHg. On exam, the infant has increased tone, a clenched jaw, no head lag, and clenched hands. Initial screening bloodwork is normal. What are the most likely organism causing this infant's presentation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Clostridium botulinum
B: Clostridium tetani
C: Escherichia coli
D: Group B streptococcus
E: Listeria monocytogenes

Question: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because he has had a fever and productive cough for the past 3 days. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which he takes lisinopril and simvastatin, respectively. On examination, his temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, and blood pressure is 155/100 mm Hg. Examination of the lungs reveals dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lower lobe. WBC count is 15,000/mm3 (15 × 109/L) with 84% neutrophils. Chest x-ray reveals consolidation of the right lower lobe. Which of the following antibiotics is most appropriate for initial therapy of community-acquired pneumonia in a patient with these characteristics?
Options: A: Co-amoxiclav
B: Clarithromycin
C: Piperacillin-tazobactam
D: Levofloxacin
E: Vancomycin
Answer: D

Question: A three-day-old, full-term infant born by uncomplicated vaginal delivery is brought to a pediatrician by his mother, who notes that her son's skin appears yellow. She reports that the child cries several times per day, but sleeps 7-8 hours at night, uninterrupted. She has been breastfeeding the infant but feels the latch has been poor and is unsure how much milk he has been consuming but feels it is not enough. A lactation consult was called for the patient and it was noted that despite proper instruction the observed latch was still poor. When asked the mother stated that the baby is currently making stools 2 times per day. Which of the following are the most likely etiology of the patient's presentation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Breast milk jaundice
B: Breastfeeding jaundice
C: Sepsis
D: Crigler-Najjar syndrome
E: Physiologic hyperbilirubinemia

Question: A 34-year-old man status post a liver transplant 2 months ago presents to your clinic with a complaint of shortness of breath, particularly on exertion, and right upper quadrant pain. On physical examination, he is noted to have a jugular venous pressure of 10 cm H2O at rest and peripheral edema in his lower extremities. His blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg, his heart rate is 100 bpm, and his respiratory rate is 28/min. Laboratory results from today are as follows:
Sodium: 132 mmol/L
Chloride: 110 mmol/L
Bicarbonate: 28 mmol/L
Potassium: 4.3 mmol/L
Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
Total bilirubin: 0.5 mg/dL
AST: 34 U/L
ALT: 35 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase: 150 U/L
INR: 1.1
Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Treat with diuretics to improve pulmonary venous congestion
B: Treat with corticosteroids to improve renal function
C: Monitor with serial liver function tests
D: Refer to a specialist for surgical intervention
E: Perform magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the liver to evaluate for tumor recurrence
Answer: A

Question: A 67-year-old woman presents from home hospice with a change in her mental status. She has seemed more confused lately and is unable to verbalize her symptoms. Her temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 117/65 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a right upper quadrant mass that elicits discomfort when palpated. Ultrasound is notable for pericholecystic fluid and gallbladder wall thickening without any gallstones. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Acalculous cholecystitis
B: Calculous cholescystitis
C: Acalculous gallbladder inflammation
D: Emphysematous cholecystitis
E: Hepatic adenoma

Question: A 67-year-old woman presents from home hospice with a change in her mental status. She has seemed more confused lately and is unable to verbalize her symptoms. Question: A 57-year-old male is referred to the ED by his physician for dyspnea and worsening left-sided chest pain he has been experiencing for the last 4 days. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He denies any smoking, alcohol, or illicit drug use. He takes amlodipine, metoprolol, and simvastatin. His temperature is 97.9°F (36.6°C), heart rate is 100 bpm, respiratory rate is 22 breaths/min, blood pressure is 158/89 mmHg, oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. HEENT exam is within normal limits. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Cardiac exam reveals a regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. There are no rashes, lesions, or scars. Peripheral pulses are symmetric and equal. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. An ECG does not show any acute changes. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Acute myocardial infarction
B: Cardiac tamponade
C: Aortic dissection
D: Pneumonia
E: Pulmonary embolism
Answer: B,D,E

Question: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of irregular menstrual bleeding. Menses have occurred at 45- to 90-day intervals since menarche at the age of 15 years. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. The patient reports that she was too embarrassed to discuss this issue with anyone until now. Over the past two years, she was unable to become pregnant despite having unprotected sexual intercourse with her husband on a regular basis. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 29.4 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows oily skin and severe facial acne. There is abnormal pigmented hair on the upper lip and around both nipples. The patient wishes to have children. In addition to recommending lifestyle modifications, which of the following are the most appropriate step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: In vitro fertilization with patient's egg
B: Progesterone therapy
C: Bromocriptine therapy
D: Clomiphene therapy
E: Clomiphene therapeutic technique

Question: A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of pain in his right hip and thigh. The pain is worse with weight-bearing, and he has difficulty walking for more than 5 minutes without stopping. He denies any history of joint swelling, redness, or warmth. He has no history of trauma to his hip. His medical history includes hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He takes lisinopril, simvastatin, and metformin. Physical examination of the hip reveals decreased range of motion, tenderness to palpation over the greater trochanter, and pain with resisted abduction. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: MRI of the hip
B: Injection of hyaluronic acid into the hip joint
C: Ceftaroline 600 mg IV once daily
D: X-ray of the hip
E: Rituximab 1 g IV every other week for 4 doses
Answer: D

Question: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider concerned that she may be pregnant. She has a history of regular menstruation every 4 weeks that lasts about 4 days with mild to moderate bleeding, but she missed her last period 2 weeks ago. A home pregnancy test was positive. She has a 6-year history of hyperthyroidism that is well-controlled with daily methimazole. She is currently asymptomatic and has no complaints or concerns. A blood specimen is taken and confirms the diagnosis. Additionally, her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is 2.0 μU/mL. Which of the following are the next best step in the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Continue methimazole
B: Discontinue methimazole, start propylthiouracil
C: Discontinue methimazole, start propylthiouracil
D: Add propranolol
E: Refer for radioiodine therapy

Question: A 54-year-old male presents with a 3-month history of progressive weakness and numbness of the right upper and lower extremities. He has also been experiencing slurred speech, difficulty with swallowing, and dysphagia. On examination, the patient exhibits decreased sensation to pinprick in the right upper and lower extremities, dysmetria, and intention tremor on the right side. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Parkinson disease
B: Subcortical dementia
C: Multiple sclerosis
D: Alzheimer disease
E: Huntington disease
Answer: C

Question: A 20-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue for the past year. She reports drinking 6 to 8 cans of regular soda every day for the past 3 years. She has not had any weight loss or night sweats. Physical examination reveals a weight of 102 kg (225 lb) and a height of 1.65 m (5 ft 5 in). Her blood pressure is 134/88 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and pulse is 82/min. Her tongue is red and smooth, and her nails are brittle and spoon-shaped. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Vitamin B1 deficiency
B: Vitamin C deficiency
C: Iron deficiency
D: Vitamin D deficiency
E: Vitamin A deficiency
Answer: A,D,E

Question: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath for 6 hours. For the past 5 days, he has had intermittent stabbing pain in the middle of his chest that worsens with lying down or taking deep breaths. He has also had a runny nose and a dry cough for the past 2 weeks. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. His current medications include atorvastatin, enalapril, and hydrochlorothiazide. He appears pale and sweaty. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 25/min. Blood pressure is 107/72 mm Hg during expiration and 86/65 mm Hg during inspiration. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's findings? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Accumulation of fluids in the pericardial space
B: Fluid accumulation in the pericardial space
C: Occlusion of a coronary artery
D: Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space
E: Accumulation fluid in the pericardial space

Question: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath for 6 hours. For the past 5 days, he has had intermittent stabbing pain in the middle of his chest that worsens with lying down or taking deep breaths. He has also had a runny nose and a dry cough for the past 2 weeks. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. His current medications include atorvastatin, enalapril, and hydrochlorothiazide. He appears pale and sweaty. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 25/min. Blood pressure is 107/72 mm Hg during expiration and 86/65 mm Hg during inspiration. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's findings? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Accumulation of fluids in the pericardial space
B: Fluid accumulation in the pericardial space
C: Occlusion of a coronary artery
D: Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space
E: Accumulation fluid in the pericardial space

Question: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of lethargy and confusion. His wife reports that he has been unwell for 3 weeks with loss of appetite, nausea, and vomiting. Examination shows that he is warm, dehydrated, and slightly jaundiced. He is slow to respond to questions. His blood pressure is 99/62 mm Hg, pulse is 93/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. Abdominal examination shows a prominent liver with hepatic tenderness. Liver function tests show elevated liver function tests including serum bilirubin of 6 mg/dL. Serum albumin is 2.3 g/dL. Urine studies show 6–10 red blood cells and 2–4 white blood cells per field. Renal function studies are normal. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's findings? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Chronic hepatitis
B: Primary hepatitis
C: Viral hepatitis
D: Acute hepatitis
E: Hepatitis A
Answer: D

Question: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the office for the evaluation of dysphagia. She explains that she has had difficulty swallowing foods over the past 3 months. Initially, she felt that her food was hanging up in the center of her throat. More recently, she has also had dysphagia to liquids. She denies any associated pain or odynophagia, heartburn, or nausea. She has a history of asthma, seasonal allergies, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). She takes fluticasone inhaler twice per day as needed and pantoprazole 40 mg once per day. She has had acne vulgaris since adolescence and has used topical retinoids sporadically over the past several years. She is not currently using any retinoids. She is a social drinker of alcohol, and she does not use illicit drugs or smoke cigarettes. Her physical examination shows facial erythema and telangiectasias. Her oral mucosa shows mucosal erythema and white plaques on her buccal mucosa. Neck exam shows slight thyroid enlargement but no tenderness. Auscultation of the chest is normal. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's dysphagia? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Dermatomyositis
B: Lichen planus
C: Esophageal eosinophilia
D: Achalasia
E: Chemical injury
Answer: D

Question: Six days after undergoing an aortic valve replacement surgery, a 68-year-old woman has bluish discolorations around the peripheral intravenous catheters and severe right leg pain. She has a history of hypertension and major depressive disorder. She drinks 3 beers daily. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, prophylactic unfractionated heparin, and fluoxetine. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 118/92 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple hematomas on the upper extremities around the peripheral intravenous access sites. There is a healing sternal incision. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows an aortic click. The right calf is tender, erythematous and swollen. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 9,900/mm3
Platelet count 48,000/mm3
Prothrombin time 15 seconds
Activated partial thromboplastin time 40 seconds
Serum
Urea nitrogen 19 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 33 U/L
AST 26 U/L
ALT 33 U/L
γ-Glutamyl transferase 45 U/L (N=5–50 U/L)
. Which of the following are the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Deficiency of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors
B: Phagocytosis of autoantibody-opsonized platelets
C: Deficiency of von Willebrand factor
D: Excess circulating thrombin
E: Autoantibody-mediated platelet activation

Question: A 68-year-old man undergoes a prostatectomy for removal of adenocarcinoma. Prostatic capsule invasion is noted on histopathologic examination. Four hours after the procedure, he experiences acute urinary retention. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Insert a Foley catheter
B: Treat with antibiotics
C: Insert an indwelling catheter
D: Apply a pressure dressing
E: Perform a rectal examination
Answer: A,C

Question: A 67-year-old man presents with feelings of nervousness and anxiety. He mentions that lately, he has been feeling increasingly restless and is unable to control feelings of nervousness pertaining to all his daily tasks. He noticed that these feelings were more prominent in the last 2 months but have been present on and off for the last year. On many occasions, his mind will be racing with thoughts that keep him up at night. During these moments, he finds his heart racing and feels light-headed and dizzy to the point of blacking out. He has also been experiencing back and neck pain with increased muscle tension in these areas. The patient reports no smoking or alcohol use but mentions that he had tried cocaine and heroin in his 20s and 30s. Which of the following would be the best course of treatment for this patient’s symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Buspirone
B: Zolpidem
C: Buspirone
D: Buspirone
E: Alprazolam

Question: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic due to a stye in his left eye. He notes that his eye has been red and swollen for the past week. His eyesight is unaffected. He denies any drainage from the eye. He appears to be in mild discomfort. On examination, there is localized swelling and erythema of the left upper lid. On eversion of the lid, a small hordeolum is noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Options: A: Oral prednisone
B: Warm compresses and topical antibiotic ointment
C: Topical anesthetic eye drops
D: Oral phenylephrine and oxymetazoline
E: Irrigation of the eye with sterile saline
Answer: B

Question: A 31-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with fevers, chills, and night sweats. After a physical exam and a series of laboratory tests, the patient undergoes a lymph node biopsy (Image A). Three days later, while awaiting treatment, he presents to his physician complaining of generalized swelling and is found to have 4+ protein in his urine. Which of the following pathological findings are most likely to be found on renal biopsy in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Rapidly progresive glomerulonephritis
B: Minimal changed disease
C: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
D: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
E: Minimal change disease

Question: An 82-year-old woman presents to the physician with a slowly progressive rash involving most of her body. The rash began 1 year ago as a small, itchy patch on her left arm. Currently, the rash has spread to involve all extremities and the trunk. It is not associated with fever, chills, or weight loss. The patient has a history of peripheral arterial disease, coronary artery disease, and dementia. She is taking metoprolol and simvastatin. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Her physical exam is notable for a maculopapular rash involving her trunk and extremities. Her skin is warm and dry. Results of laboratory studies and radiography are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Options: A: Triamcinolone cream
B: High-potency topical steroid
C: Clobetasol ointment
D: Dimeticone cream
E: Salicylic acid lotion
Answer: B

Question: A 26-year-old female complains of frequent, large volume urination. This negatively affects her sleep, as she has to frequently wake up at night to urinate. She also complains of increased thirst. Her past medical history is significant for bipolar disorder that is treated with lithium for 3 years. Serum osmolality is 425 mOsm/kg, and urine osmolality is 176 mOsm/kg. Which of the following best explains this patient’s serum and urine osmolality? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Hypothalamic over-production of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)
B: Decreased production of ADH
C: ADH resistance in the renal collecting ducts
D: Increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion
E: Adh resistance in the ren collecting ducts

Question: A 19-year-old Caucasian male presents to your office with hypopigmented skin. He undergoes a skin biopsy and is found to have an absence of melanocytes in the epidermis. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Tinea versicolor
B: Albinism
C: Vitiligo
D: Solar lentigo
E: Melanoma

Question: A 70-year-old obese male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and cough of sudden onset. The patient states that his symptoms came on while he was sleeping. The patient has a past medical history of type II diabetes and is currently taking lisinopril, metformin, insulin, and fish oil. On physical exam, you note bipedal edema and jugular venous distention (JVD). An EKG and chest radiographs are obtained (Figures A and B). The patient is started on BIPAP and medical therapy and his symptoms improve rapidly. Lab values are as follows.

Serum:
Na+: 137 mEq/L
K+: 3.2 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
HCO3-: 31 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 120 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.9 mg/dL

. Which of the following are the best explanation of this patient's current presentation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Furosemide
B: Hydrochlorothiazide
C: Hydrochlorothiazide
D: Renal tubular acidosis type II
E: Renal tubular acidosis type IV
