Question: A 58-year-old male with a history of HIV and chronic kidney disease presents to follow up with his HIV specialist. The patient was recently discharged from the hospital after developing lower extremity cellulitis and skin and soft tissue infection. The patient received intravenous antibiotics during admission. Prior to his admission, the patient was virally suppressed on a regimen of emtricitabine, tenofovir, and efavirenz. At follow up, the patient is newly started on dolutegravir, lamivudine, and emtricitabine for treatment of HIV. His CD4 count is 250 cells/μL. Of the following, which is the most likely adverse effect of this newly prescribed regimen?
Options: A: Headache
B: Peripheral neuropathy
C: Diarrhea
D: Nephrotoxicity
E: Hepatotoxicity
Answer: D

Question: A 26-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents to the primary care clinic with complaints of a painful right ear for 3 days. He reports that he has been unable to hear out of his right ear since the pain began. He denies any recent upper respiratory infection. Physical examination shows a temperature of 101°F, right ear swelling and tenderness, and a bulging tympanic membrane with decreased mobility. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Cefdinir
B: Amoxicillin-clavulanate
C: Myringotomy
D: Prednisone
E: Acetaminophen
Answer: D

Question: A 39-year-old man is brought to the emergency department unconscious following 2 episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. According to the attendants, he has complained of recurrent headaches for the past 2 weeks. There is no history of fever, head trauma, or a seizure disorder. The patient does not smoke cigarettes but reportedly drinks 2 glasses of wine daily. He has multiple sexual partners and history regarding the contraceptive use is unavailable. The patient’s vitals include: blood pressure 137/88 mm Hg, temperature 37.2°C (99.0°F). On physical examination, he is obtunded. He grimaces on pain and localizes in response to pain in both upper extremities. Pupils are bilateral 3-mm in diameter and equally round and reactive. Laboratory tests are within normal limits. An MRI of the brain with contrast is shown in the exhibit (see image). A brain biopsy is performed that reveals perivascular clusters of lymphocytes. Which of the following are most associated with this patient’s condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Epstein-Barr virus
B: Human herpes virus
C: Human papilloma virus
D: Epstein-Barr virus
E: Epstein-Barr virus

Question: A 50-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 6-month history of episodes of dizziness that occur during prolonged standing or walking. She denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. She is a nonsmoker and consumes alcohol only socially. She takes lisinopril 10 mg and hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg once daily for hypertension. Her blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg and heart rate is 69/min. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. Echocardiogram shows an ejection fraction of 40% and normal-size chambers. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in her evaluation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Manage her symptoms with beta-blockers
B: Exercise stress test
C: Transesophageal echocardiogram
D: Holter monitor
E: Coronary angiography
Answer: B,C,D

Question: A 34-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents to the physician because of abdominal pain. She reports 3 days of right-sided abdominal pain and now notices a painless, slightly pruritic rash. On physical examination, the rash is erythematous and macular, sparing the dorsal hands and feet. Her blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg, and the pulse is 85/min. Fetal heart rate is 145/min. Which of the following is the most likely next step in management?
Options: A: Obtain a serum protein electrophoresis
B: Perform a liver biopsy
C: Prescribe prednisone
D: Prescribe cholestyramine
E: Start a course of antibiotics 
Answer: C

Question: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. He was at work as a construction worker when his coworkers found him down at the work site. The patient recently underwent anesthesia for an appendectomy several months ago. He also has a past medical history of schizophrenia well controlled with haloperidol and is currently taking phenytoin for epilepsy. He is also currently taking propranolol for anxiety and hyperthyroidism. His temperature is 106°F (41.1°C), blood pressure is 109/62 mmHg, pulse is 170/min, respirations are 23/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an altered man with a Glasgow Coma Scale of 10. He has minimal muscle tone and is incoherent when answering questions. The patient is covered in sweat and dirt. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Exertional heat stroke
B: Malignant hyperthermia
C: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
D: Exertional heat stroke
E: Thyroid storm

Question: A 65-year-old woman with a 3-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the physician for a routine examination. Her past medical history is also significant for a right-sided cerebrovascular accident 15 years ago. Her medications include metformin and hydrochlorothiazide. On examination, her blood pressure is 150/94 mm Hg, her body mass index is 26 kg/m2, and her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F). Examination reveals a normal retinal examination, decreased vibratory perception in the right lower extremity, normal bowel and rectal examinations, and no monofilament sensory deficits in the feet. Her HbA1c is 7.2%. When discussing her current medications, which one should be discontinued?
Options: A: Hydrochlorothiazide
B: Cimetidine
C: Metformin
D: Lisinopril
E: Torsemide
Answer: A

Question: A 54-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at home. Her husband states that she has had intermittent bouts of vomiting and diarrhea for the past 24 hours. Her regular medications include albuterol for asthma and insulin for type 2 diabetes. She has a history of hypertension but discontinued her medication 6 months ago. In the emergency department, she is afebrile, heart rate is 104/min, respiratory rate 22/min, and blood pressure 98/60 mm Hg. Her capillary blood glucose is 300 mg/dL. Her examination is notable for dry mucous membranes and poor skin turgor. Decreased urine output and hyperglycemia are consistent with which of the following? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Diabetic coma
B: DKA
C: HHS
D: Diabetic ketoacidosis
E: Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic nonketotic syndrome
Answer: C,D,E

Question: A 60-year-old man with severe persistent asthma since the age of 14 presents with an acute exacerbation of shortness of breath, wheezing, and coughing over the last several days. His asthmatic symptoms are usually well controlled with regular high-dose inhaled triamcinolone, but over the last week or so he has developed a nocturnal cough and mild wheezing despite good compliance with controller medications. A review of several spirometry reports suggest of bronchial asthma with a partial irreversible airway obstruction. Which of the following are most likely to be associated with the recent loss of asthma control in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Airway epithelial shedding
B: Airway smooth muscle atrophy
C: Airway remodeling
D: Airway inflammation
E: Airway hyperresponsiveness

Question: A 60-year-old man with severe persistent asthma since the age of 14 presents with an acute exacerbation of shortness of breath, wheezing, and coughing over the last several days. Question: A 54-year-old man comes to the office with a 5-day history of dysuria and frequency. He reports that his urine is cloudy and has a foul odor. His symptoms started the day after he had sexual intercourse with a new partner. He denies any recent dysuria, frequency, or urgency. He does not report any flank pain or abdominal pain. He is otherwise healthy. On physical examination, vital signs are normal, and his abdomen is nontender. There is no suprapubic tenderness or flank pain. His urinalysis shows a pH of 6, specific gravity of 1.015, trace protein, moderate leukocyte esterase, and many leukocytes and bacteria. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this man's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Bacterial prostatitis
B: Candida urethritis
C: Chlamydia urethritis
D: Escherichia coli pyelonephritis
E: Herpes simplex virus urethritis
Answer: C

Question: A 40-year-old man is referred to an optometrist. He complains of mild vision impairment over the last 6 months. His vision has continued to slowly deteriorate and his condition is now affecting his night driving. Past medical history is significant for well-controlled schizophrenia. He takes a low-potency typical antipsychotics and a multivitamin every day. He has been compliant with his medication and has regular follow-up visits. What are the best first step in the management of this patient’s symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Decrease medication dosage
B: Reassurance
C: Ocular examination under anesthesia
D: Refer to ophthalmologist
E: Slit-lamp examination

Question: A 65-year-old male was brought to the ED by EMS after he was found unresponsive by family members at home. EMS reported that the patient had a witnessed generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The patient was initially responsive to questions, but became somnolent during transport. Blood pressure is 165/96 mm Hg, heart rate is 78 beats/min, respiratory rate is 19 breaths/min, and temperature is 37.0°C. Physical examination reveals a small subdural hematoma on the right side of the cranium. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) in the treatment of nicotine addiction? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Substitution of a safer form of nicotine
B: Increased activation of spinal cord GABAergic pathways
C: Amelioration of withdrawal symptoms
D: Stimulation of dopamine release
E: Reduction in NMDA receptor activity
Answer: A,C

Question: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for sleeping problems and the inability to concentrate for 3 months. She says she is worried because she and her husband have been trying to conceive for more than a year with no success. Conception by in vitro fertilization was attempted once 3 months ago but was unsuccessful. Analysis of her husband's semen has shown normal sperm counts and morphology. She has a 6-year-old daughter who was born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. She has no history of severe illness and tries to stay healthy by going to the gym an hour per day. Her menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 to 6 days; her last menstrual period started 2 days ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's inability to conceive? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Diminished ovarian reserve
B: Diminished ovarian reserve
C: Diminished ovarian reserve
D: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
E: Diminished ovarian reserve

Question: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for sleeping problems and the inability to concentrate for 3 months. Question: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has noticed a small, hard mass in the right breast. She is asymptomatic and denies recent trauma to the breast. She does not complain of any nipple discharge or breast pain. She is postmenopausal and has a regular menstrual cycle. Physical examination shows the mass is located at the 10 o'clock position, 1 cm from the nipple. The skin over the mass is intact. The mass is hard and fixed to the chest wall. Nipple discharge and axillary examination are normal. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Reassurance
B: Examine of core tissue
C: Breast MRI
D: Mammogram
E: Routine screening
Answer: A,C,E

Question: A 17-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. The patient was an unrestrained driver in a head-on collision. He has a past medical history of asthma, depression, and anxiety. He is not currently taking any medications. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient's cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. The patient is breathing on his own and has strong distal pulses. Ultimately, the patient is discharged with follow up instructions after no significant fractures or injuries are found. The patient then presents 4 months later to his primary doctor with weakness. The patient's strength in his upper extremities is 1/5. He has reduced sensation in his upper extremities as well. The patient's lower extremities reveal 5/5 strength with intact sensation. A chest radiograph and basic labs are ordered. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Syringomyelia
B: Intracranial hemorrhage
C: Syringomyelia
D: Brachial plexopathy
E: Conversion disorder

Question: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to a laceration to his right index finger. The laceration extends from the proximal interphalangeal joint to the distal interphalangeal joint. The patient states that he cut his finger with a knife while preparing dinner. The patient denies any numbness, tingling, or pain in his finger. Examination of the finger reveals that 2 tendons have been transected. Sensation distally to the laceration is intact. The distal pulses in the finger are palpable. A 3-mm gap is present between the ends of the tendons. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Options: A: Immobilization of the finger
B: Perform superficial tendon repair
C: Avoid surgery
D: Refer the patient to a hand surgeon
E: Perform deep tendon repair
Answer: D

Question: An otherwise healthy 49-year-old woman has a routine full blood count complete prior her elective cholecystectomy. The lab test results are as follows:
Laboratory test
Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)
85 μm3
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)
47%
Reticulocyte count
3.4 %
White blood cell count
9700/mm3
Platelet count
229,000/mm3
A peripheral blood smear reveals spherocytes. The Coombs test is negative. The physical examination is remarkable for scleral icterus and moderate splenomegaly. Which of the following are the most appropriate diagnostic test of this patient’s underlying disorder? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Eosin-5-maleimide binding test
B: Flow cytometry for CD55/CD59
C: Anti parvovirus B19 antibodies
D: Eosin-5-maleimide binding test
E: Eosin-5-maleimide binding test

Question: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and a rash on her legs for the past 8 weeks. The rash and fatigue are worse in the morning. She denies fever, chills, or joint pain. Her past medical history includes chickenpox at age 12 years and hysterectomy at age 30 years. She is sexually active. Her medications include oral contraceptive pills. She has a younger sister with systemic lupus erythematosus. Examination shows diffuse follicular facial edema, oral mucosal ulcers, and erythematous macules and papules over her lower extremities. A complete blood count shows anemia and leukopenia. Which of the following are the most appropriate diagnostic test for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies
B: Anti-Sm antibodies
C: Anti-ribonucleoprotein antibodies
D: Anti-Ro (SS-A) antibodies
E: Anti-La (SS-B) antibodies
Answer: A,B,C,D,E

Question: A 32-year-old man presenta to the physician because of an itchy rash that started 4 days ago. The rash began as a few red bumps on his right shoulder and has since spread to his neck, abdomen, and legs. He denies any fever, chills, or night sweats. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 80 beats/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Examination reveals a maculopapular rash, predominantly on his trunk and extremities. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Psoriasis
B: Pityriasis rosea
C: Erythema multiforme
D: Herpes simplex
E: Systemic lupus erythematosus
Answer: A,B,D

Question: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department by her mother due to a fall. Tearfully, the patient’s mother describes witnessing her child fall from the changing table. The patient was born prematurely at 36 weeks estimated gestational age via vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery. The patient is afebrile. Her vital signs include: blood pressure of 94/60 mm Hg, pulse 200/min, and respiratory rate 70/min. Physical examination reveals a subconjunctival hemorrhage in the left eye and multiple bruises on the chest and back. Which of the following are the best initial step in management of this patient’s condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: CT scan of the head
B: Involvement of social services
C: Informing the police
D: X-ray computerized tomography of the hcd
E: C a t scan of the head of caudate nucleus

Question: A 24-year-old woman with secondary amenorrhea presents to the physician. She has had no menstrual periods for the past 3 months. She is a long-distance runner and has been trying to lose weight. Her past medical history is notable for a diagnosis of hypothyroidism, which is well controlled with thyroid hormone replacement therapy. She has no history of vaginal bleeding or discharge. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and her pulse is 60/min. Physical examination is significant for a weight of 50.0 kg (110.2 lb). Her body mass index is 16.0 kg/m2. Examination of the external genitalia is unremarkable. On pelvic examination, the uterus and ovaries are unremarkable, and the vagina is dry. Laboratory evaluation shows the following:
Total T3 1.3 ng/mL (N 1.0-2.5 ng/mL)
Free T4 0.9 ng/dL (N 0.8-1.8 ng/dL)
TSH 0.2 mcIU/mL (N 0.4-4.0 mcIU/mL)
PRL 10 ng/mL (N 2-29 ng/mL)
LH 15 IU/L (N 5-25 IU/L)
FSH 20 IU/L (N 5-20 IU/L)
Estradiol < 20 pg/mL (N 25-220 pg/mL)
Progesterone < 1 ng/mL (N 1-3 ng/mL)
Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of this patient's amenorrhea?
Options: A: Excessive estrogen has suppressed the release of LH and FSH.
B: Excessive calorie intake has suppressed the release of LH and FSH.
C: Excessive exercise has led to loss of subcutaneous tissue, which has decreased the conversion of androgens to estrogens.
D: Excessive exercise has led to decreased secretion of LH and FSH from the pituitary.
E: Excessive exercise has led to increased secretion of LH and FSH from the pituitary.
Answer: D

Question: A 28-year-old woman with a 4-year history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma is admitted to the emergency department with complaints of fatigue and shortness of breath. She has been febrile (39°C [102.2°F]) for 2 days. She has no productive cough. Her past medical history is significant for non-Hodgkin lymphoma and for a lung transplant that she received 7 months ago due to pulmonary complications. Since the transplant, she has been chronically immunosuppressed with tacrolimus and mycophenolate. Physical examination reveals breath sounds that are diminished at the bases. White blood cell count is 12,000/mm3 with a shift to the left. Blood cultures are obtained. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following are not the best initial choice for empiric therapy? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Vancomycin and ceftriaxone
B: Vancomycin and gentamicin
C: Vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, and metronidazole
D: Piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin
E: Meropenem and tazobactam
Answer: C,E

Question: A 50-year-old man visits his physician after 20 years of not seeking any medical care. He is concerned about his health after a colleague recently had a heart attack. The patient has no active complaints and says he feels healthy; however, he does not exercise regularly and lives a sedentary lifestyle. He is employed as an administrative position at a local college, and is seated at a desk most of the day. His father had a heart attack at age 54 and his mother is still alive with no health concerns. He does not smoke, only drinks socially, and does not use drugs. Today, his blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination reveals an obese male with no significant findings. An ECG shows no abnormalities, and laboratory testing shows the following:
Laboratory test
Serum glucose (fasting)  105 mg/dL
Serum electrolytes 
Sodium  142 mEq/L
Potassium 3.9 mEq/L
Chloride 101 mEq/L
Serum creatinine 0.8 mg/dl
Blood urea nitrogen 10 mg/dl
Cholesterol, total 250 mg/dL
HDL-cholesterol 35 mg/dL
LDL-cholesterol 186 mg/dL
Triglycerides 170 mg/dL
Urinalysis 
Glucose  negative
Ketones negative
Leucocytes negative
Nitrites negative 
Red blood cells (RBC) negative 
Casts negative 
. Which of the following lab abnormalities in thare patient is an indication for treatment? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Elevated beta-lipoprotein cholesterol
B: Patient’s weight
C: Highly low density lipoprotein cholesterol
D: High LDL-cholesterol
E: Serum glucose level

Question: A 25-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a 2-year history of diarrhea with loose stools 3 times/day, especially after meals. The symptoms are worse with stress and he now avoids going to social events. He reports fatigue. His last Pap smear showed normal results. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a thin man with mild pallor. Abdominal examination reveals mild tenderness to deep palpation in the right lower quadrant. There is no adenopathy. Rectal examination shows normal-appearing stool with no blood or mucus. A stool sample is taken for culture. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's diarrhea? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Helicobacter pylori
B: Giardia lamblia
C: Campylobacter jejuni
D: Salmonella
E: Adenovirus
Answer: B

Question: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of pallor and increasing lethargy for 2 days. One week ago, he experienced abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea that have since subsided. The patient's father states that they returned early from a 6-week roadtrip in Mexico because of these symptoms. His parents have been giving him oral rehydration solution. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears pale. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 95/50 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 94 μm3
Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3
Platelet count 45,000/mm3
Prothrombin time 12 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 34 sec
Serum
Urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL
Bilirubin
Total 2.5 mg/dL
Direct 0.1 mg/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase 1658 U/L
A blood smear shows schistocytes. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
B: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura
C: Hemolytic uremic syndrome
D: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura
E: Hemolytic uremic syndrome

Question: A woman in her 20s presents to the physician because of recurrent headaches for the past 2 months. She denies blurred vision, nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or diplopia. She reports severe throbbing pain, and headaches lasting 3-4 hours that are becoming more frequent. Her review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. She has no personal or family history of migraines, seizures, or other neurological disorders. She takes acetaminophen 0.5 g 3 times daily as needed for headaches. She doesn't use tobacco, alcohol, or drugs. She has no known allergies. On examination, her vital signs are within normal limits. Neurological examination is normal including intact motor, sensory, and coordination exams. She has severe nonradiating left-sided frontal and temporal pain with palpation. Fundoscopic examination of the optic discs is normal. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices?
Options: A: Perform MRI of the head
B: Order a complete blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate
C: Trial of over-the-counter migraine therapy
D: Begin treatment with triptans
E: Perform CT scan of the head
Answer: C,D

Question: A 42-year-old woman has been seen for the evaluation of abnormal uterine bleeding and pelvic pain for the past 8 weeks. She has a normal Pap test result. A transvaginal ultrasound of the uterus and adnexa demonstrated a 4-cm highly vascular mass on the posterior wall of the uterus, consistent with a leiomyoma. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in treatment for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Endometrial biopsy
B: Hysterectomy
C: Endometrial ablation
D: Myomectomy
E: MRI or ultrasound for confirmation
Answer: D,E

Question: A 56-year-old man with a history of pancreatic cancer presents to the surgical intensive care unit following a pancreaticoduodenectomy. Over the next 3 days, the patient's drainage output is noted to exceed 1 liter per day. In the early morning of postoperative day 4, the nurse states that the patient is difficult to arouse. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 107/88 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. His skin and mucous membranes are dry on physical exam. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Serum:
Na+: 154 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 27 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 99 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL

. Which of the following are the best next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: 0.9% saline IV
B: 0.9% saline IV
C: 5% dextrose IV
D: 5% dextrose IV with 0.45% saline IV
E: Oral free water replacement

Question: A 19-year-old woman presents to the physician with a history of a 3-day headache and nausea. The headache is constant and worse with coughing. She also has had some lightheadedness. Her menstrual history is significant for her last menses being 6 weeks ago. The remainder of her history is unremarkable. Her blood pressure is 210/110 mm Hg, the pulse is 65/min, the respirations are 15/min, and the temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Examination shows mild nuchal rigidity. There are 3+ deep tendon reflexes. A CT scan of the head shows subarachnoid hemorrhage. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Aneurysm
B: Brain tumor
C: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
D: Meningitis
E: Cerebral hemorrhage
Answer: A,C

Question: A 25-year-old woman develops petechiae and ecchymosis on the arms and legs 1 week after beginning therapy with a newly prescribed medication. She is otherwise well. Her laboratory evaluations include the following:

Hemoglobin: 11.8 g/dL
Hematocrit: 35%
Platelet count: 150,000/μL
Prothrombin time: 12 seconds
Partial thromboplastin time: 29 seconds
International normalized ratio: 1.1
Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of her symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Ampicillin
B: Gentamicin
C: Ibuprofen
D: Clindamycin
E: Vancomycin
Answer: C

Question: A 38-year-old woman is being evaluated by her primary care physician for chronic, widespread pain that started around 5 months ago. This pain has been accompanied by sleeping issues. Her friend recommended that she try yoga to relieve the pain, but she says this has not helped her at all. Se says the symptoms have begun to impact her daily functions and keep her from doing things she used to enjoy. Past medical history includes generalized anxiety disorder, for which she currently takes no medication. The patient had been previously medicated with paroxetine for 5 years. On physical examination, several areas of point tenderness are found on the occipital region, elbows, and medial surface of both knees. Laboratory work up is unremarkable. What are the best treatment option for the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Paroxetine
B: Paroxetine
C: Paroxetine
D: Paroxetine
E: Gabapentin

Question: A 32-year-old male presents to clinic with a chief complaint of a "severe migraine." He was not aware that he had a migraine until he had a workup by his primary care physician and got a CT scan that showed "a cluster of white spots" in his brain. The patient denies headache, nausea, or any other neurologic symptoms. He denies any history of migraines or seizures. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and drinks 3-4 beers on the weekend. He first began having these headaches about 2 months ago. They last about 2 days and he typically takes 2 Ibuprofen tablets and goes to sleep. He works as a heavy equipment operator. On physical exam, he is alert and oriented. There are 3-4 white spots on the roof of his oral mucosa. His sclerae are anicteric. His cardiovascular examination is normal. His lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. His neurologic examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line therapy for this patient's migraine headaches?
Options: A: Lisinopril
B: Topiramate
C: Metoprolol
D: Lisinopril
E: Sumatriptan
Answer: E

Question: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic for her annual Pap smear screening. She is a smoker, uses alcohol 2–3 days a week, and had her last Pap test 6 months ago. She currently has mucopurulent vaginal discharge and sharp, stabbing vaginal pain. She has tried various feminine hygiene products in an attempt to relieve the symptoms. Her pregnancy test is negative. On pelvic examination, the cervix is red and edematous with several friable strawberry-type lesions. There is no cervical motion tenderness or adnexal tenderness. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Apply triamcinolone acetonide 0.5% cream to the cervix twice daily
B: Dilute vinegar to water in a 1:1 ratio and apply to the cervix once daily
C: Recommend the use of tampons instead of pads during menses
D: Place an artificial sweetner containing yogurt into the vagina at bedtime
E: Apply 5% acetic acid once daily
Answer: C,D

Question: A 22-year-old man from Nepal presents to the emergency department complaining of swelling and pain in his right testicle. The patient states that he just arrived in the United States to live with his wife, with whom he is monogamous. The patient denies painful urination or urethral discharge, but admits that 10 days ago he “felt like he had a fever” and the right side of his face was swollen and painful. Which of the following are characteristic of the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Preventable by a live attenuated vaccine
B: Preventable by a live live attenuated vaccine
C: Preventable by a live vaccine live
D: Cause buboes in the inguinal lymph nodes
E: Is a common cause of septic arthritis in this patient’s age group

Options: A: Preventable by a live attenuated vaccine
B: Preventable by a live live attenuated vaccine
C: Preventable by a live vaccine live
D: Cause buboes in the inguinal lymph nodes
E: Is a common cause of septic arthritis in this patient’s age group

Question: A 25-year-old female presents to the ED with anxiety. She complains of muscle spasms, flushing of the skin, increased urination, and palpitations. She is unaware of any snacks or meals she has eaten in the last 24 hours. She denies alcohol intake. Her blood pressure is 160/80 mm Hg. On physical exam she is agitated and tachypneic. Her mucous membranes are dry. Her skin is warm and dry with no rashes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Panic attack
B: Hyperthyroidism
C: Hypoglycemia
D: Drug-induced anxiety
E: Alcohol withdrawal
Answer: C

Question: A 33-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with bilateral joint pain. She says that the pain has been slowly worsening over the past 3 days. Otherwise, she complains of fatigue, a subjective fever, and a sunburn on her face which she attributes to gardening. The patient is an immigrant from Spain and works as an office assistant. She is not aware of any chronic medical conditions and takes a multivitamin daily. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 125/64 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals bilateral redness over the maxillary prominences. Which of the following are most likely to be seen in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Decreased anti-dsDNA antibodies
B: Decreased complement levels
C: Diminished complement levels
D: Increased anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies
E: Diminish complement levels

Question: A 22-year-old student presents to the clinic complaining of a cough productive of white sputum, shortness of breath, and right-sided chest pain pleuritic in nature. Symptoms began approximately 3 days ago. He denies fevers or chills. The patient was recently in the mountains on a camping trip and notes the onset of symptoms following his return from the trip. He had no animal exposures or tick bites. His past medical history is significant for childhood asthma. He reports taking albuterol as needed and denies any other medications. On examination, his vital signs are as follows: temperature 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 120/70 mm Hg, respirations 22/min, and pulse 108/min. Pulmonary examination reveals diffuse inspiratory and expiratory wheezes bilaterally. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is not the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Influenza A infection
B: Exacerbation of asthma
C: Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection
D: Community-acquired pneumonia
E: Acute bronchitis
Answer: A,C

Question: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever, generalized fatigue, and chills for 1 week. She has been having dull right-side abdominal pain during this period. She has nausea. She has no history of travel outside the United States. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and an oral contraceptive. She appears ill. Her temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 118/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. On examination, the liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin and is tender. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 17,100/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 74%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 5%
Serum
Glucose 79 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 180 U/L
AST 69 U/L
ALT 100 U/L
A right upper quadrant ultrasound is shown. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Perform percutaneous drainage
"
B: Obtain hepatoiminodiacetic acid scan
C: Perform endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
D: Administer metronidazole
E: Perform percutaneous drainage
"

Question: A 28-year-old woman is evaluated for upper gastrointestinal symptoms, including dysphagia, heartburn, and regurgitation. This is the second time she is seen by the physician. She was initially seen 2 weeks earlier and diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) based on her symptoms. The physician prescribed pantoprazole, a proton-pump inhibitor (PPI), but she has not taken the medication due to concerns about side effects. On examination, there is no thrush, and the remainder of her physical examination is within normal limits. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is performed. A biopsy is obtained from the patient's esophagus. A microscopic view of the biopsy is shown. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management?
Options: A: Start treatment with a histamine-2 receptor antagonist
B: Prescribe a twice-daily dose of a PPI
C: Prescribe a four-times-daily dose of a PPI
D: Prescribe antibiotic therapy
E: Perform a manometry study
Answer: C

Question: A 69-year-old man with Parkinson disease presents with progressive weakness, lethargy, and delirium. He has been seen by his neurologist until recently when the neurologist retired. His wife informs you that he has no history of psychiatric illness. Examination shows mild parkinsonism, bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor. Mental status examination shows disorientation to time, place, and person; poor attention; impaired memory; and decreased speech output. Laboratory studies show:
Na 133 mEq/L
K 4.2 mEq/L
Cl 98 mEq/L
BUN 16 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL
AST 15 U/L
ALT 10 U/L
Glucose 108 mg/dL
White blood cell count 6000/mm3
Hemoglobin 13.0 g/dL
Platelet count 250,000/mm3
Thyroid-stimulating hormone 1.5 mIU/L
Free T4 1.2 ng/dL
Cortisol 5 μg/dL
Which of the following are not the most likely causes of this patients clinical features? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Lewy body dementia
B: Psychosis
C: Brain hemorrhage
D: Depression
E: Multiple sclerosis
Answer: C,D,E

Question: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after his wife noticed during breakfast that the left side of his face was drooping. He had difficulty putting on his shirt and shoes before coming to the hospital. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. His current medications include metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He drinks one glass of wine daily. He is alert and oriented to time, place and person. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min and blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Examination shows equal and reactive pupils. There is drooping of the left side of the face. Muscle strength is decreased in the left upper and lower extremities. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left side. Speech is dysarthric. There is a bruit on the right side of the neck. Fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count, coagulation profile, and serum concentrations of glucose and electrolytes are within the reference range. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Transmission computed tomography of the head of caudate nucleus
B: Scan ct of the caput nuclei caudati
C: Duplex ultrasonography of the neck
D: Ct x ray of the head
E: CT scan of the head

Question: A 58-year-old woman is seen in the office for worsening abdominal pain and diarrhea over the past 3 months. The patient is afebrile. She developed this condition approximately 1 week after completing a course of ciprofloxacin for a urinary tract infection. She has no other past medical history. She takes no prescription medications and has no known allergies. A colonoscopy is performed, and the pathologist reports that the biopsy results are negative for infectious processes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
Options: A: Crohn's disease
B: Ulcerative colitis
C: Diverticulitis
D: Irritable bowel syndrome
E: Celiac disease
Answer: D

Question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother after she found him somnolent at home next to multiple open pill bottles. The boy had seemingly opened several different pill bottles that were in a cabinet in his parent’s bathroom. The mother has brought the empty bottles to the emergency room, and they include aspirin, metoprolol, acetaminophen, levothyroxine, and lorazepam. The boy has no past medical history and takes no medications. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 28/min. On exam, the boy is lethargic but responsive. He appears to be grasping at his ears and swaying from side-to-side when attempting to ambulate. He vomited once in the emergency room. Which of the following arterial blood gas readings are most likely to be found in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Neutral ph.36, pco2 22 torr, and bicarbonate level test- 16 meq/l
B: Neutral.36, pco2 22 millimeter of mercury (mmhg), and hco3- 16 meq/l
C: pH 7.36, PCO2 22 mmHg, and HCO3- 16 mEq/L
D: Neutral ph.36, pco2 22 millimeter of mercury, and hco3- 16 meq/l
E: pH 7.48, PCO2 24 mmHg, and HCO3- 25 mEq/L

Question: A 62-year-old man presents with new onset constipation, decreased appetite, and fatigue. On physical exam, he has mild scleral icterus and abdominal distention. He denies fever, chills, or weight loss. Laboratory studies are noted below:
Hemoglobin 12.2 g/dL
Hematocrit 35%
Platelet count 130,000/μL
Bilirubin 4.0 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 56 IU/L
Aspartate aminotransferase 70 IU/L
Alanine aminotransferase 120 IU/L
Total protein 6.5 g/dL
Albumin 4.0 g/dL
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical presentation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Cholangiocarcinoma
B: Common bile duct stone
C: Gallstones
D: Hepatitis C
E: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma
Answer: A,E

Question: A 44-year-old male presents to the office for return visit to discuss results from his recent cardiac evaluation. He was previously seen in the office with new onset of chest discomfort. The patient underwent cardiac stress testing, which revealed a reduced maximal effort and ischemic ECG changes suggestive of an ischemic burden. Cardiac catheterization was performed and revealed 90% stenosis in the mid left anterior descending (LAD) artery. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and has never used tobacco products. Of note, his blood pressure is well-controlled and he does not have any symptoms of heart failure. He reports being very active prior to the onset of his chest discomfort. He swims for 1 hour on the weekends and walks for 30 minutes each day. The patient denies any family history of coronary artery disease. Which of the following combination of medications is not the most appropriate next step in management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Aspirin and clopidogrel
B: Lidocaine and metoprolol
C: Aspirin, beta-blocker, and statin
D: Diltiazem and verapamil
E: Statin and beta-blocker
Answer: B, D

Question: A 17-year-old man presents to his family physician for an evaluation about the size of his penis. He feels increasingly anxious during physical education (PE) class as he has noticed that the size of his penis is significantly smaller when compared to his peers. Based on the physical examination, he is Tanner stage 1. The weight and height are 60 kg (132 lb) and 175 cm (5 ft 9 in), respectively. The cardiopulmonary examination is normal; however, the patient has difficulty identifying coffee grounds by smell. Which of the following explains the pathophysiology underlying this patient’s disorder? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Expansion of a CTG trinucleotide repeat
B: Isolated gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) deficiency
C: Isolated fsh-releasing hormone (gnrh) deficiency
D: Leptin receptor mutation
E: Isolated gnrh (gonadotropin releasing hormone) (gnrh) deficiency

Question: A 42-year-old woman presents to your dermatology clinic with a 3-week history of a pruritic rash on her left distal leg and dorsum of the foot. In addition, she notices red, raised, firm nodules along the rash. She has no recent history of trauma, animal bites, or change in footwear. Examination of her left leg shows:
Small clusters of reddish brown papules on the dorsum of the foot
A reddish brown plaque on the distal lateral leg
Red, raised, firm nodules overlying the plaque and extending proximally to the popliteal fossa
Her vital signs are stable. There is no lymphadenopathy. The pretibial lymph nodes are not palpable. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Stasis dermatitis
B: Erythema nodosum
C: Erythema multiforme
D: Contact dermatitis
E: Erythema nodosum
Answer: A,C,D

Question: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department with the complaint of pain in his right toe for the past hour. The pain is so severe that it woke him up. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and binge drinks alcohol after work and on the weekends. He underwent an appendectomy when he was 14 years old. He is a long-distance truck driver. Neither of his parents had any significant medical history. His temperature is 37.7°C (100°F), blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and BMI is 25 kg/m2. On examination, his right first metatarsophalangeal joint is very tender, swollen, warm, and red in color. Range of motion cannot be assessed due to extreme tenderness.
Laboratory test
Complete blood count:
Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL
Leukocytes 16,000/mm3
Platelets 150,000/mm3
ESR 50 mm/hr
Synovial fluid is aspirated from the joint. The findings are:
Appearance Cloudy, dense yellow
WBC 30,000 cells/µL
Culture Negative
Needle-shaped birefringent crystals are observed in the joint aspirate. Which of the following are the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Organic acids competing with urate for tubular secretion
B: Increased renal reabsorption of urate
C: Lysis of large numbers of cells
D: Organic acidic competing with urate for tubular secretion
E: Organic acid substances competing with urate for tubular secretion

Question: A 56-year-old man presents to the office for his annual physical examination. He reports that he feels well. He currently takes finasteride 5 mg daily for hair loss, atenolol 25 mg daily for hypertension, and metoprolol 25 mg twice a day for atrial fibrillation. He has been taking all three medications for the past 5 years. His blood pressure is 126/82 mm Hg, pulse is 75/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Examination shows no abnormalities. His prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level is 1.43 ng/mL (N < 4.0 ng/mL). Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Increase the finasteride dose to 10 mg daily
B: Start dutasteride 0.5 mg once daily
C: Discontinue the metoprolol
D: Discontinue the atenolol
E: Schedule a repeat PSA level in 3 months
Answer: E

Question: A 33-year-old man is seen by his family physician for a periodic checkup. He is a retired professional hockey player who currently works as a hockey commentator. He is very fit and exercises regularly. He has not had any problems since his last checkup 1 year ago, except for a mild sore throat for the 4 days. He is also very concerned about having high cholesterol. He denies any fever or chills. He uses no medications, vitamins, or herbal supplements. Vital signs are: blood pressure 138/90 mm Hg, respiratory rate 16/min, heart rate 66/min, and temperature 37.2°C orally. Examination of the neck shows several lymph nodes, right and left, ranging in size from 0.5 to 1.5 cm in diameter. They are mobile, non-tender, and discrete. Examination of the head, lungs, heart, neurologic system, gastrointestinal system, and genitalia shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
WBC count 12,000/mm3
RBC count 4.5 million/mm3
Hemoglobin 14.0 g/dL
Hct 42%
Plt count 265,000/mm3
Sodium 140 mEq/L
Potassium 4.2 mEq/L
Chloride 108 mEq/L
CO2 25 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen 18 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL
Glucose 110 mg/dL
AST 24 IU/L
ALT 22 IU/L
Total bilirubin 0.6 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 0.2 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 88 IU/L
Albumin 4.3 g/dL
Total protein 7.3 g/dL
Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Ultrasonography of the abdomen
B: Sputum examination for fungi
C: Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain
D: Chest CT scan
E: Biopsy of a lymph node
Answer: C,D

Question: A 75-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-day history of a productive cough and shortness of breath. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and respirations are 32/min. Crackles are heard over the right upper and the entire left lung fields. Sputum culture confirms infection with Streptococcus pneumoniae. Despite appropriate therapy, the patient dies. A photomicrograph of a section of the lung obtained during the autopsy is shown. Which of the following mediators are most likely responsible for the presence of the cell-type indicated by the arrow? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Bizzozero's corpuscle/cell activation factor
B: Platelet activating factor
C: Platelets blood activation determinant
D: Interleukin-10
E: Leukotriene D4

Question: A 75-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-day history of a productive cough and shortness of breath. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and respirations are 32/min. Question: A 55-year-old man presents for a follow-up examination of a chronic right otitis media. The patient states that he has had this condition for approximately 6 months. He rates his pain as 7/10 and describes it as sharp and stabbing. The infection originally started as acute otitis media, and he was treated with amoxicillin-clavulanate for 10 days, but his symptoms did not resolve. He has been taking ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain with minimal relief. On physical examination, he is afebrile and vital signs are within normal limits. The right tympanic membrane is opaque, red, and bulging, with a loss of the light reflex. Bone and air conduction are decreased in the right ear. An audiogram reveals a conductive hearing loss in the right ear. The remainder of the head and neck examination is normal. Which of the following is indicated in the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Tympanostomy tube insertion
B: Myringotomy
C: Revision tympanoplasty
D: Otoplasty
E: Canalplasty
Answer: A,B

Question: A previously healthy 35-year-old primigravid woman at 12 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a fever, persistent headache, nausea, and abdominal discomfort for 1 week. During this time, she has also noticed that her gums bleed while brushing her teeth. A month ago, she returned from a camping trip to Sri Lanka. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Examination shows pallor and mild scleral icterus. There are a few scattered petechiae over the trunk and back. There is no lymphadenopathy. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8.2 g/dL
Leukocyte count 10,000/mm3
Platelet count 18,000/mm3
INR 1.0
Coomb's test negative
Fibrin split products negative
Serum
Urea 20 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Bilirubin
Total 3.0 mg/dL
Direct 0.8 mg/dL
Alanine aminotransferase 20 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase 16 U/L
Lactate dehydrogenase 900 U/L
Urine
Protein 1+
WBCs occasional
RBCs 50–60/hpf
Bacteria nil
A photograph of the peripheral blood smear is shown. Blood and urine cultures are negative. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices."

B: Thrombus thrombocytopenic purpura

D: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura
E: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

Question: A 32-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of a 3-week history of episodic facial swelling, primarily involving the face and ears. He reports an exacerbation of throat tightness and shortness of breath when he eats nuts, which he has noticed only during the past 6 months. He is generally well, with no history of any relevant medical conditions. On examination, he is afebrile with stable vital signs. No palpable cervical, axillary, or inguinal lymph nodes are noted. Skin examination of the face reveals a red, mildly indurated, plaque-like eruption with some vesicles on his cheeks and ears. This rash is worse on the left side of the face. Examination of the oro-pharynx is normal. Which of the following medications is most likely to be effective in treating his facial eruption? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Prednisone
B: Zafirlukast
C: Cetirizine
D: Budesonide
E: Montelukast
Answer: A

Question: A researcher is interested in identifying the most effective treatment for uncomplicated urinary tract infections (UTI) in women between the ages of 18 and 50. Of 200 consecutive women who present to the emergency room for such a UTI, 50 are randomized to each of the following: nitrofurantoin 100 mg every 12 hours for 5 days, nitrofurantoin 100 mg every 12 hours for 7 days, cefpodoxime 100 mg every 12 hours for 5 days, and cefpodoxime 100 mg every 12 hours for 7 days. The measured outcomes include progression to pyelonephritis, positive urine culture on day 7 after initiation of treatment, and likelihood of re-presenting to the emergency room for another UTI within 90 days. Which of the following best describes this type of study? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Factorial design studies
B: Factorial design study
C: Factorial design study
D: Factorial design scientific study
E: Cluster randomized trial

Question: A 60-year-old woman is seen by a nurse for a follow-up visit after a tonic-clonic seizure 2 days ago. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia She notes she has been experiencing headaches that awaken her from sleep for the past 2 months. She denies nausea, vomiting, or vision changes. She is administered a short-acting anxiolytic and anticonvulsant. A computed tomography (CT) scan is ordered to evaluate possible causes of her seizure. The CT scan shows a large tumor with contrast enhancement on the right temporal lobe. To what neurologic system does the location of this mass correspond? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Vision
B: Speech
C: Hearing
D: Motor and sensory control
E: Voluntary movement
Answer: B,D

Question: A 50-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a left-sided headache and blurry vision. She has been exercising heavily for the past several hours and was feeling winded just before these symptoms occurred. Her pulse is 100 bpm, BP is 165/75 mm Hg, and RR is 16. Her vision is blurry, and she is unable to make out any words on a newspaper. Her pupils are equal and responsive to light. She is also found to have unequal BPs in both arms (150/80 on the right and 95/65 on the left) and a loud bruit over the left renal artery. Which of the following conditions do not best explains her presentation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Compressive neuropathy
B: Cushing syndrome
C: Pheochromocytoma
D: Aortic dissection
E: Transient ischemic attack 
Answer: A,D,E

Question: A 19-year-old woman is brought into the emergency department after collapsing during a cheerleading practice session. Her vitals taken by the emergency medical services (EMS) include blood pressure 88/55 mm Hg, pulse 55/min. She was given a liter of isotonic fluid while en route to the hospital. At the emergency department, she is alert and oriented and is noted to be anorexic. The patient fervently denies being underweight claiming that she is ‘a fatty’ and goes on to refuse any further intravenous fluid and later, even the hospital meals. Which of the following are the best option for long-term management of this patient’s condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Cognitive-behavioral therapy
B: In-patient medical therapy
C: Cognitive-behavioral psychotherapy
D: Antidepressants
E: Appetite stimulants

Question: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine check-up. He has a history of coronary artery disease, for which he takes aspirin and a statin. His blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg, and his pulse rate is 80/min. Nine months ago, the results of his fasting lipid profile were:
Total cholesterol: 250 mg/dL
HDL cholesterol: 42 mg/dL
LDL cholesterol: 185 mg/dL
Triglycerides: 225 mg/dL
Which of the following are not the best therapeutical options for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Terazosin
B: Gemfibrozil
C: Cetirizine
D: Simvastatin
E: Nicotinic acid
Answer: B,C

Question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after a motor vehicle accident. He is unconscious upon arrival and is found to have severe internal bleeding due to trauma. He is taken for emergency surgery and severely damaged tissues are removed. After surgery, the boy is taken into the PICU for recovery. Over the subsequent week, serial labs are drawn showing target cells, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis. He is started on a prophylactic regimen that is continued upon discharge. Which of the following are consistent with the mechanism of action of the drug that was most likely prescribed in this case? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: 30S ribosome inhibitor
B: 50S ribosome inhibitor
C: Cell wall cross-linking inhibitor
D: Cell wall cross-linking inhibitor
E: Folate metabolism inhibitor

Question: A 46-year-old man reports a gradual loss of libido and erectile dysfunction of 6 months' duration. The sexual dysfunction has significantly affected his relationship with his wife. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Primary hyperparathyroidism
B: Peripheral arterial disease
C: Testosterone deficiency
D: Growth hormone deficiency
E: Corticosteroid excess
Answer: C

Question: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening involuntary movements of both arms for the past 7 months. He reports that certain daily activities have become more difficult to perform. His father had a similar condition that was treated with medications. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a low-amplitude tremor bilaterally when the arms are outstretched that worsens when reaching out to grab a pen. Muscle strength and tone is normal bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. On mental status examination, his mood is good. His speech is normal in rate and rhythm. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Deep brain stimulation
B: Thalamotomy
C: Levodopa and carbidopa therapy
D: Clonazepam therapy
E: Propranolol therapy

Question: A 9-year-old boy is brought to a physician by his mother for evaluation of generalized weakness, increased urination, and increased thirst. The mother mentions that her boy is always tired, and seems to be getting worse. He prefers watching television rather than going out and playing with other kids. Furthermore, he has had frequent episodes of constipation since birth. Except for frequent cravings for salty foods, the boy eats a regular diet. The patient was delivered healthy and is fully immunized. The medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. He has no siblings. His father is a banker and his mother is a librarian. The pulse is 90/min, the blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg, and the respiratory rate is 15/min. He is in the bottom 10th percentile for height and weight according to his age. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. He recently had a urinalysis that showed elevated urinary calcium excretion.
Additional lab testing results are as follows:
Serum electrolytes
Sodium 135 mEq/L
Potassium 3.2 mEq/L
Chloride 95 mEq/L
Plasma renin activity 10 ng/mL/hr (normal, 0.5–3.3 ng/mL/hr)
Plasma aldosterone concentration 20 ng/dL (normal, 2–9 ng/dL)
. What are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Renal artery stenosis
B: Primary hyperaldosteronism
C: Bartter's syndrome
D: Hypokalemic alkalosis
E: Gitelman's syndrome

Question: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department for clear vaginal discharge that started roughly 26 hours ago. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her first child was born at term by vaginal delivery. She has no history of any serious illnesses. She does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. Current medications include vitamin supplements. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Speculum examination demonstrates clear fluid at the cervical os. The fetal heart rate is reactive at 160/min with no decelerations. Tocometry shows uterine contractions. Nitrazine testing is positive. She is started on indomethacin. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Administer betamethasone, ampicillin, and proceed with cesarean section nos
B: Administer ampicillin and progesterone
C: Administer ampicillin and test amniotic fluid for fetal lung maturity
D: Administer betamethasone, ampicillin, and proceed with cesarean section
E: Administer betamethasone, ampicillin, and proceed with cesarean delivery

Question: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-year history of urinary incontinence that has been worsening. Over the past few months, he has had to change his clothes up to 10 times a day. This is a significant problem as he teaches 3rd grade and urinates on himself once or twice per day. He denies urge incontinence. He has difficulty initiating micturition and sometimes experiences weak urine stream and hesitancy. Sometimes, he cannot empty his bladder completely. On physical examination, his general and rectal examinations are normal. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Transurethral needle ablation (TUNA)
B: Suprapubic prostatectomy
C: Open prostatectomy
D: Percutaneous laser prostatectomy
E: Transurethral incision of the prostate (TUIP)
Answer: E

Question: A 35-year-old man presents to a clinic complaining of fatigue and swelling in his hands and feet. He noticed a 20-lb weight gain in the past 2 months. He is a nonsmoker and drinks 1–2 glasses of wine per day. His medications include metoprolol and ibuprofen. On physical examination, blood pressure is 170/90 mm Hg. He has 3+ pitting edema in his legs and feet, but no jugular venous distension. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria. A chest x-ray shows normal heart size and bilateral pleural effusions. Laboratory studies show:
Serum  
Sodium 130 mEq/L
Potassium 3.8 mEq/L
Chloride 98 mEq/L
Bicarbonate 20 mEq/L
BUN 50 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Glucose 90 mg/dL
Calcium 10.2 mg/dL
Phosphate 2.0 mg/dL
Total protein 6.5 g/dL
Albumin 3.0 g/dL
24-hour urinary protein 5.4 g
Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: ACE inhibitor
B: Refer patient to nephrology
C: Thiazide diuretic
D: Pioglitazone
E: Sodium restriction
Answer: B,C,D

Question: A 72-year-old man develops reduced urine output and a serum creatinine concentration of 2.9 mg/dL three days after being hospitalized for acute diverticulitis. On admission, a complete blood count showed a hemoglobin concentration of 15.5 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 14,000/mm3. Urinalysis showed 2+ proteinuria, and serum studies showed a blood glucose of 145 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 1.2 mg/dL. A CT scan of the abdomen confirmed the diagnosis. Therapy with intravenous ketoprofen, piperacillin, and tazobactam was begun, and the patient was placed on bowel rest. He has a history of hypertension, chronic constipation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Prior to admission, his medications were insulin, metoprolol, and losartan. Today, his temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 97/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft on physical examination, and there is tenderness to palpation of the left lower quadrant. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's current renal findings? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Gastrointestinal blood loss
B: Adverse drug reaction
C: Contrast agent administration
D: Contrast administration
E: Chronic hypertension
"

Question: A 56-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 5-month history of erectile dysfunction. He has a history of angina pectoris with a percutaneous coronary angioplasty 3 years ago. He smokes 2 packages of cigarettes per day. His blood pressure is 158/92mm Hg, pulse rate is 78 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute. Examination of his heart reveals a 1/6 aortic systolic flow murmur; otherwise, the exam is normal. An electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm with no ischemic changes. Lipid profile shows total cholesterol 285 mg/dL, HDL cholesterol 35 mg/dL, and triglycerides 235 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis and management of this patient?
Options: A: Tadalafil 20 mg as needed before sexual activity
B: Sildenafil 100 mg as needed before sexual activity
C: Vardenafil 20 mg as needed before sexual activity
D: Start treatment for dyslipidemia
E: Coronary bypass surgery
Answer: D

Question: A 25-year-old woman presents to the physician with a 3-day history of fever, headache, myalgias, and nausea. She is a nurse and took a 10-day trip to Africa 3 weeks ago. Her vital signs include: temperature 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse 75/min, blood pressure 115/70 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 18/min. Her physical examination is non-focal. Which of the following laboratory test findings are not consistent with malaria? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Decreased nucleated red blood cells
B: Increased monocytes
C: Increased platelets
D: Decreased hemoglobin
E: Decreased neutrophils
Answer: C,E

Question: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of persistent diarrhea and fatigue for 1 month. She has had up to 12 watery stools per day. Sometimes she awakens at night because she has to defecate. She has abdominal bloating and cramps. She has had a 2-kg weight loss in the past month. She returned from a trip to Costa Rica 7 weeks ago. She has a history of bronchial asthma and bulimia nervosa. She works as a nurse. She does not smoke and drinks 1–2 beers on the weekend. Current medications include fish oil, a multivitamin, and a salbutamol inhaler. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. Abdominal and rectal examinations are unremarkable. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 46%
Leukocyte Count 6,500/mm3
Platelet Count 220,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 136 mEq/L
K+ 3.2 mEq/L
Cl- 102 mEq/L
HCO3- 33 mEq/L
Mg2+ 3.3 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 14 mg/dL
Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL
Abdominal ultrasound shows no abnormalities. Colonoscopy shows dark colored mucosa with interspersed white spots. Biopsies of colonic mucosa are obtained and sent for pathological evaluation. Which of the following are the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Medication history abuse
B: History of medication abuse
C: VIPoma
D: Irritable bowel syndrome
E: Medication abuse

Question: A 52-year-old woman presents to the physician because of persistent left lower quadrant (LLQ) pain and diarrhea. She has had LLQ pain for the past 3 months. The pain is dull and aching in character, and it radiates to her left hip and medial thigh. The intensity of the pain has been gradually increasing over the past 3 months. She has had frequent, soft stools for the past 2 weeks. She has had intermittent LLQ pain for the past 2 years. She has had no dysuria, hematuria, or urinary incontinence. She denies rectal pain, urgency, or constipation. She had a total hysterectomy at age 35 years. She has never smoked; she drinks alcohol 1–2 times per month. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her current medications include a beta-blocker and a statin. Examination shows LLQ pain on palpation, peroctal examination shows no tenderness. Laboratory studies show:
White Blood Cell Count 5600/mm3
Hemoglobin 12.3 g/dL
Hematocrit 37.6%
Platelet Count 300,000/mm3
Glucose 100 mg/dL
Urea Nitrogen 25 mg/dL
Total Bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL
Direct Bilirubin 0.3 mg/dL
Total Protein 7.8 g/dL
Albumin 4.8 g/dL
Sodium 142 mEq/L
Potassium 4.1 mEq/L
Chloride 101 mEq/L
Bicarbonate 27 mEq/L
Calcium 9.2 mg/dL
Lipase 23 U/L
Serum Amylase 75 U/L
Colonoscopy shows a fungating mass in the rectosigmoid colon. The mass causes partial obstruction of the colon. Biopsies of the mass are obtained and sent for pathological evaluation. Which of the following is the most likely site of the primary tumor in this patient?
Options: A: Stomach
B: Ovary
C: Pancreas
D: Lung
E: Breast
Answer: B

Question: A 24-year-old man presents with a  3-day history of right hip pain after a twist-and-fall injury during a soccer game. He reports pain with walking and has difficulty bearing weight on his right leg. On examination, hip internal and external rotation are painful, and there are no signs of ecchymosis or swelling. The results of plain radiography are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Plain radiography
B: Computed tomography (CT) arthrography of the right hip
C: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the right hip
D: Three-dimensional (3D)-CT scan of the right hip
E: Bone scan of the right hip
Answer: C

Question: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of sore mouth. He says that swallowing is not painful. He has had asthma for more than 20 years. His only medication is a high-dose combination salmeterol/fluticasone inhaler. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 125/65 mm Hg. A photograph of his oral mucosa is shown. Indirect mirror examination of the posterior oropharynx, larynx, and hypopharynx shows no abnormalities. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Nystatin
B: Fluconazole
C: Nystatin
D: Nystatin
E: Nystatin

Question: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because he has had a 3-day history of abdominal pain. He has had mild nausea and vomiting. He had a cholecystectomy 15 years ago. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg. There is right upper quadrant abdominal tenderness. Laboratory studies show:
Total bilirubin 0.7 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 0.2 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 140 IU/L
Aspartate aminotransferase 40 IU/L
Alanine aminotransferase 50 IU/L
Amylase 130 IU/L
Lipase 180 IU/L
Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's abdominal pain? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Pancreatitis
B: Cirrhosis
C: Cholangitis
D: Cholecystitis
E: Crohn disease
Answer: A,C

Question: A 29-year-old woman presents with a 1-week history of progressive worsening chest pain with associated shortness of breath. She experienced angina initially at rest which has progressed to occurring even during rest. Her symptoms have not improved with nitroglycerin. Physical examination reveals an increased left heart border. Electrocardiogram shows ST segment depression. Two-dimensional echocardiography demonstrates hypokinesis involving the anteroseptal and apical walls of the left ventricle. Echocardiogram also reveals a small amount of pericardial effusion. The patient undergoes coronary catheterization, which shows critical stenosis of the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. She undergoes percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with placement of a drug-eluting stent in the LAD. She is also started on aspirin, clopidogrel, atenolol, and isosorbide mononitrate. At this time, which of the following medications is least likely to be effective in the management of this patient's angina?
Options: A: Acetaminophen
B: Metoprolol
C: Lisinopril
D: Diltiazem
E: Clonidine
Answer: A

Question: Hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1a) is a transcription factor with increased activity under conditions of cellular hypoxia. In normoxia, von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) protein hydroxylates prolyl residues on oxygen-dependent degradation domains of HIF-1a, targeting it for proteasomal degradation. Hydroxylation by VHL is inhibited under hypoxic conditions, allowing HIF-1a to escape degradation, dimerize with HIF-1ß, and translocate to the nucleus. This results in the upregulation of hypoxic response elements, leading to angiogenesis. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can mimic the hypoxic state to promote angiogenesis by inhibiting HIF-1a hydroxylation, even in the absence of hypoxia. A researcher wants to perform an experiment to detect HIF-1a in RCC under normoxic conditions with blotting techniques. Which of the following statements are most likely to be true regarding her experiment? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: A Northern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a hypoxic control cell.
B: A west blot will show increases hif-1α compared to a normoxic control.
C: A Southern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a hypoxic control cell.
D: A Southern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a normoxic control cell.
E: A Western blot will show increased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control.

Question: Hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1a) is a transcription factor with increased activity under conditions of cellular hypoxia. In normoxia, von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) protein hydroxylates prolyl residues on oxygen-dependent degradation domains of HIF-1a, targeting it for proteasomal degradation. Hydroxylation by VHL is inhibited under hypoxic conditions, allowing HIF-1a to escape degradation, dimerize with HIF-1ß, and translocate to the nucleus. This results in the upregulation of hypoxic response elements, leading to angiogenesis. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can mimic the hypoxic state to promote angiogenesis by inhibiting HIF-1a hydroxylation, even in the absence of hypoxia. A researcher wants to perform an experiment to detect HIF-1a in RCC under normoxic conditions with blotting techniques. Which of the following statements are not most likely to be true regarding her experiment? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: A Northern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a hypoxic control cell.
B: A west blot will show increases hif-1α compared to a normoxic control.
C: A Southern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a hypoxic control cell.
D: A Southern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a normoxic control cell.
E: A Western blot will show increased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control.

Question: A 16-year-old male presents to the clinic after experiencing pain in the left lower quadrant of his abdomen for the last 12 hours. He has no fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation. He plays soccer and reports that the pain began after a tackle during a soccer game. Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. His blood pressure is 112/68 mm Hg, pulse is 75/min, and respirations are 18/min. His abdominal exam is normal and he has no rebound or guarding. Rectal examination reveals a firm, tender mass in the left lower quadrant. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Order a MRI of the abdomen/pelvis
B: Order urine analysis and urinalysis
C: Prescribe Tamsulosin
D: Order a CT scan of the abdomen/pelvis
E: Reassure the patient and discharge home
Answer: A,D

Question: A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of worsening abdominal pain and diarrhea over the past 2 months. He reports that the pain is mostly in the lower left quadrant of the abdomen and radiates to the rectum. The pain is often severe enough to wake him from sleep at night. He has had as many as 20 bowel movements per day, with loose, watery stools and occasional fecal incontinence. He has lost 10 kg (22 lb) in the past 2 months. He also reports experiencing fevers, chills, and night sweats. On physical examination, his temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination of the abdomen shows diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound tenderness. Bowel sounds are slightly decreased. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Crohn's disease
B: Ulcerative colitis
C: Diverticulitis
D: Irritable bowel syndrome
E: Appendicitis
Answer: C,E

Question: A previously healthy 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of dizziness and palpitations for 2 days. Prior to the onset of the symptoms, he attended a bachelor party where he lost several drinking games. An ECG is shown. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomoyopathy
B: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
C: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
D: Paroxysmal af
E: Sick sinus syndrome

Question: A 63-year-old woman visits a physician for a well-woman examination. She had breast cancer 10 years ago and was treated with lumpectomy and radiation therapy. She is worried about cancer recurrence. Her vital signs and history are otherwise unremarkable. Examination shows no abnormalities. For this patient, which of the following is not the most appropriate screening measure? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Chest x-ray
B: Pelvic examination
C: Mammography
D: Serum CEA
E: Colonoscopy
Answer: A,B,D

Question: A 77-year-old man comes to your office for a routine visit. He is doing well, and his only complaint is the recent appearance of several brown greasy appearing lesions on his forehead (figure A) that he can't seem to peel off. What are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Seborrheic keratosis
B: Seborrheic keratosis
C: Keloid
D: Acanthosis nigricans
E: Erythema nodosum
