Question: An 18-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her mother for vaginal bleeding. The mother states that she noticed the bleeding today, which appeared as brown discharge with clots in the patient’s diaper. The mother denies frequent nosebleeds or easy bruising. She also denies any known trauma. She does mention that the patient has been limping and complaining of left leg pain since a fall 2 months ago. On physical exam, there are multiple 2-3 cm hyperpigmented patches on the patient’s trunk. There is bilateral enlargement of the breasts but no pubic hair. The vaginal orifice is normal and clear with an intact hymen. A plain radiograph of the left lower leg shows patchy areas of lytic bone and sclerosis within the femoral metaphysis. Which of the following are associated with the patient’s most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Polyostotic fibrous abnormal structure or growth
B: Hearing loss
C: Polyostotic fibrous abnormal cellular structure or growth
D: Pheochromocytoma
E: Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia

Question: An 89-year-old woman sees her neurologist for a follow-up evaluation. Three months ago, she presented with complaints about facial asymmetry. Her daughter has noticed that her mother’s mouth is droops downwards on the right side of her face and that she cannot close her right eye well. The same side also lacks wrinkles on the forehead. Since then, the patient feels like her facial muscles have gotten weaker. She was given a course of corticosteroids, but she has still not recovered fully. Upon being asked to close her eyes, the patient has difficulty doing so and fails to completely close her eyelids. On examination, there is no loss of pain, temperature, or crude or tactile touch sensations in the whole face. The neurological exam is otherwise unremarkable. This patient also has type 2 diabetes mellitus which is well controlled with metformin. The neurologist recommends a therapy that will help relieve her symptoms. Which of the following are the most likely treatment option being prescribed to this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Botox
B: Carbamazepine
C: Vitamin B12
D: Botox
E: Botox

Question: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of pain in his right knee for the past week. The pain is exacerbated by jogging and climbing up stairs. He has no history of trauma to the knee. He is otherwise healthy. He is an active member of his school's gymnastics team. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows a tender swelling at the proximal tibia; range of motion is full. Knee extension against resistance causes pain in the anterior proximal tibia. The remainder of the examinations shows no abnormalities. X-ray of the right knee shows anterior tibial soft tissue swelling with fragmentation of the tibial tuberosity. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Administration of oral ketorolac
B: Perform joint aspiration
C: Open reduction of the tuberosity
D: Administration of oral methotrexate
E: Application of a lower leg cast
"

Question: A 25-year-old woman presents to a physician with a rash that started 3 weeks ago. The rash began on her trunk and spread to her extremities. She has no fever, chills, or weight loss. She also denies pruritus. She is taking estrogen for hot flashes secondary to premature menopause. Her vital signs are normal. Examination shows an erythematous maculopapular rash on her trunk and extremities. The rash does not blanch with pressure. There is no mucosal involvement. Which of the following drugs is most likely causing this patient's rash?
Options: A: Tamoxifen
B: Metronidazole
C: Imipramine
D: Minoxidil
E: Estrogen
Answer: E

Question: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician requesting prenatal care. For the past 2 months, she has had increasing breast tenderness, nausea, 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain, and urinary frequency. She is not sure about the date of her last menstrual period. She has been trying to conceive with her husband since she stopped taking oral contraceptives 6 months ago; she was happy to tell him last week that she is pregnant. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild, nontender abdominal enlargement. The cervical os is closed. Urine β-hCG is negative. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Delusion of pregnancy
B: Pseudocyesis
C: Pregnancy
D: Pseudocyesis
E: Ectopic pregnancy

E: Ectopic pregnancy

Question: A 20-day-old child is brought to the emergency department by her parents. They are concerned about lethargy and easy bruising. Her mother reports that she has been eating less for the past few days. Today she was difficult to arouse. She normally nurses four-five times a day, but ate less yesterday and this morning. The girl was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery at home with minimal prenatal or postnatal care. This is her first visit to a physician of any type. The family is carefully questioned and child abuse is ruled out. The daughter’s pulse is 97/min, respirations are 35/min, temperature is 35.8°C (96.4°F), and blood pressure is 71/46 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diffuse petechiae and bruising. Which of the following are the most likely cause? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Group B streptococcus (GBS) infection
B: Hepatitis B infection
C: Thyroid stimulating hormone deficiency
D: Vitamin D deficiency
E: Vitamin K deficiency

Question: A 49-year-old man presents to the office for a routine medical examination. He has a 45-pack-year history of smoking cigarettes. He smokes 2 packs cigarettes per day. A review of systems is negative except that the patient reports fatigue. On physical examination, vital signs are: pulse 92/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 126/80 mm Hg, and temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F). His chest examination shows rhonchi and wheezes bilaterally. Laboratory tests show:
Hemoglobin 15.4 g/dL
Hematocrit 45%
WBC count 11,000/mm3
Platelet count 245,000/mm3
Serum  
Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL (69.80 μmol/L)
PSA 10.0 ng/mL (normal < 4 ng/mL)
Which of the following are the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: End stage renal disease
B: Congestive heart failure
C: BPH
D: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
E: Prostate cancer
Answer: A, B, C, D

Question: A couple is seeking care from a reproductive endocrinologist. The wife is 29 years old and the husband is 30 years old. They have been trying to conceive for over a year without success. Both have had normal physical examinations and blood work, with the exception of semen analysis results that indicate that the husband has a low sperm concentration of 2.5 million sperm/mL. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Testicular biopsy
B: Assisted reproductive technology (ART)
C: Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI)
D: Epididymal aspiration
E: Vasovasostomy
Answer: E

Question: A 34-year-old patient is brought to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. An EKG shows sinus tachycardia and chest radiograph reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette. While observing sinus tachycardia on the patient's telemetry, you note that the radial pulse cannot be palpated during inspiration. What should be the next step in management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Pericardiocentesis
B: Pericardiocentesis
C: Pericardiocentesis
D: Pericardial window
E: Pericardiocentesis

Question: A 34-year-old patient is brought to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. An EKG shows sinus tachycardia and chest radiograph reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Question: A 33-year-old woman presents to your clinic for ongoing evaluation of her newly diagnosed gestational diabetes mellitus. During her last prenatal visit 2 weeks ago, she started on 20 units of insulin glargine prior to bedtime. She was advised to maintain a carbohydrate controlled diet and to monitor her finger stick glucose levels 3–4 times per day. During this time, she has been experiencing preprandial sugars as high as 130–150 mg/dL. Which of the following nonmedication interventions is most likely to help manage her blood glucose levels?
Options: A: Decrease her carbohydrate intake at breakfast
B: Do moderate intensity exercise for 30 minutes after dinner
C: Eat her dinner in the late morning
D: Stop eating all foods containing grains or starches
E: Monitor her blood glucose more frequently
Answer: A

Question: A 7 -day-old newborn boy presents to the emergency department with a history of fever, irritability, and generalized erythema. During the first 2 days of clinical manifestations, the parents of the child tried to control the symptoms using acetaminophen; however, the newborn continued to be ill, and blisters were noticeable around the buttocks, hands, and feet. During the physical examination, the vital signs include body temperature 39.0°C (102.3°F), heart rate 130/min, and respiratory rate 45/min. Ears, nose, and oral mucosa preserved their integrity, while the skin presents with diffuse blanching erythema and flaccid blisters with a positive Nikolsky’s sign. What are the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Ritter dis
B: Scalded skin syndrome
C: Impetigo
D: Scalded skin syndrome
E: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome

Question: A 19-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of right leg pain. The onset of the pain began 1 week ago with light activity. Presumed that the pain was related to physical exertion, the patient continued to play basketball. Currently, the patient states the pain is severe and persists even at rest. The patient denies fevers, chills, cough, or shortness of breath. He denies any recent trauma or recent insect bites. Vital signs are: T 37.8°C (100.0°F), HR 120/min, BP 105/72 mm Hg, RR 20/min, SpO2 100% on room air. On examination, integumentary inspection shows erythema in the right lower extremity extending from the ankle to the knee, with tenderness to palpation. Active and passive range of motion of the lower extremity is limited by pain. Right foot pulses are intact. The pain is exacerbated by dorsiflexion of the right foot. What are not the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Deep vein thrombosis
B: Cellulitis
C: Soft tissue abscess
D: Musculoskeletal strain
E: Rhabdomyolysis
Answer: A,D,E

Question: A 5-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician’s office by his parents after they noticed blood in his urine. The child has been complaining of difficulty in passing urine and has lower abdominal pain. He seems more bloated than usual. On some occasions, he starts crying while passing urine, primarily because of a burning sensation. A urinalysis is performed, and the results are as follows:
Urine pH 6.2
Urine specific gravity 1.010
Glucose Negative
Ketones Negative
RBCs 1-2/hpf
WBCs 0-1/hpf
Casts 2-3/hpf
The pediatrician believes the boy has a bladder infection with a double-stranded DNA virus. Which of the following conditions are also commonly associated with this viral infection? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Gastroenteritis
B: Painful dermatomal vesicles
C: Lymphadenopathy
D: Vesicular rash
E: Plantar warts

Question: A 5-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician’s office by his parents after they noticed blood in his urine. The child has been complaining of difficulty in passing urine and has lower abdominal pain. He seems more bloated than usual. On some occasions, he starts crying while passing urine, primarily because of a burning sensation. A urinalysis is performed, and the results are as follows:
Urine pH 6.2
Urine specific gravity 1.010
Glucose Negative
Ketones Negative
RBCs 1-2/hpf
WBCs 0-1/hpf
Casts 2-3/hpf
The pediatrician believes the boy has a bladder infection with a double-stranded DNA virus. Which of the following conditions are not also commonly associated with this viral infection? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Gastroenteritis
B: Painful dermatomal vesicles
C: Lymphadenopathy
D: Vesicular rash
E: Plantar warts

A,C,D

Question: A 20-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of 6 hours of vaginal bleeding. She states that the bleeding started as soon as she woke up that morning. She was 6 weeks pregnant. She states that her partner has left town for the weekend while she was at work and will not be back until Sunday night. Her pregnancy was planned, and she is devastated at the thought of losing the pregnancy. An ultrasound is performed and shows no fetal heart beating. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Salpingo-oophorectomy
B: Dilation and curettage
C: Hysterectomy
D: Lysis of adhesions
E: Laparotomy
Answer: B

Question: An 80-year-old African American man is brought to the emergency department in a confused state with history of general illness for the past week. He is known to be hypertensive, but noncompliant with medications for the last 20 years. Physical examination reveals dry skin, ecchymoses, and conjunctival pallor. His blood pressure is 180/99 mm Hg, heart rate is 89/min, and respiratory rate is 17/min. The initial laboratory results are remarkable for hemoglobin of 10 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 90 μm3, platelet count of 200,000/mm3, blood urea nitrogen of 29 mg/dL, and creatinine of 2.1 mg/dL. Which of the following would be the best initial management for this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor (ACEI)
B: Kininase ii inhibitor (acei)
C: Calcium channel blocker (CCB)
D: Angiotensin-converting enzyme antagonists (acei)
E: Thiazide

Question: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with a 1-day history of nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. She has been passing 8-10 loose stools per day and has associated abdominal pain. She has tried drinking fluids but reports an immediate onset of nausea and vomiting after each attempt to do so. She reports no hematochezia, melena, or hematemesis. She has a history of hypertension and heart failure, for which she takes lisinopril and furosemide. She has a past medical history of ischemic stroke but is fully recovered without residual deficits. In the emergency department, her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1 °F), heart rate is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Her medications are held. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Treat with a potassium-sparing diuretic
B: Administer intravenous immunoglobulin (ivig)
C: Administer sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate)
D: Administer loperamide
E: Obtain histiocytopenia-lymphohistiocytosis virus (hlv) serologies
Answer: D

Question: A 52-year-old man presents to the office for evaluation of increasingly severe dysphagia, regurgitation, and chest pain. His symptoms have worsened over the past 3 months and are now interfering with his ability to eat solid foods. He admits to unintentional weight loss over the past 6 months, but is unsure of the exact amount. He reports intermittent heartburn and has previously taken over-the-counter antacids with temporary relief. He used to be an avid weight lifter, but has recently noticed decreased muscle strength and tone. He takes no regular medications. He denies using alcohol or illicit drugs. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Examination of the head, ears, eyes, nose, and throat is unremarkable. Cardiovascular examination shows a regular rate and rhythm. Pulmonary and gastrointestinal examinations are unremarkable. Musculoskeletal examination shows decreased strength in the proximal muscles of all extremities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.1 mg/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 102 μm3
Platelet count 200,000/mm3
Creatinine 2.0 mg/dL
Antinuclear antibodies 1:1280
ESR 50 mm/h
Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Polymyositis
B: Rheumatoid arthritis
C: Dermatomyositis
D: Psoriatic arthritis
E: Systemic lupus erythematosus
Answer: B,D

Question: A 62-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 3-day history of headache, nausea, and decreased urination. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Na+ 136 mEq/L
K+ 3.2 mEq/L
Cl- 115 mEq/L
Mg2+ 1.4 mEq/L
Urine
pH 7.0
Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.28 and a HCO3- concentration of 14 mEq/L. Prolonged treatment with which of the following drugs would best explain this patient's findings? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
B: Acetazolamide
C: Eplerenone
D: Amphotericin B
E: Heparin

Question: A 24-year-old woman presents to a physician with a history of exposure to a close friend who was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. She was told by her friend that she need to see a physician because she needs to be treated as well, even if she is not having symptoms yet. She currently denies any headaches, vision changes, nausea or vomiting, or neck stiffness. Her physical exam is within normal limits. Her vital signs are stable. She is prescribed rifampin for prophylaxis with specific instructions on when to follow up if symptoms develop. When asked about the possibility of pregnancy, she mentioned that she uses combination oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for contraception. The physician suggested that her husband should use condoms for contraception as she requires antibiotic therapy. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the need for additional contraception? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of estrogens.
B: Rifampin inhibits CYP3A4, which metabolizes progestins.
C: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of progestins.
D: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of estrogens.
E: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of progestins.
Answer: A,B,C

Question: A 68-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with a 7-month history of fatigue and low back pain. Her pain is not improved by over the counter analgesics. Laboratory analysis is notable for a calcium level of 11.5 mg/dL, creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL, and blood urea nitrogen level of 30 mg/dL. Large eosinophilic casts are seen on renal biopsy. Which of the following findings are most likely to be seen on peripheral blood smear? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Linear aggregations of anucleate erythrocyte
B: Linear aggregations of red blood cells
C: Linear aggregations of blood corpuscles
D: Leukocytosis with abundant mature myeloid cells
E: Linear aggregations of blood erythrocyte

Question: A 24-year-old nulliparous woman is seen in the emergency department after 2 days of right lower quadrant (RLQ) pain. The pain is located in the periumbilical area, but it migrated to the RLQ over the past 12 hours. She reports associated nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. The patient has a history of dysmenorrhea, but her menses are otherwise regular. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 108/58 mm Hg. Examination of the abdomen shows right lower quadrant tenderness and guarding with voluntary guarding. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Moviprep
B: Pelvic examination
C: Ceftazidime
D: Cilostazol
E: Tamsulosin
Answer: B,C

Question: A 3-day-old boy is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for seizures. He was born to a 33-year-old woman at 31 weeks gestation via cesarean section. His birth weight was 1400 grams. Vital signs are significant for systemic hypotension, bradycardia, and hypoventilation. On physical exam, the patient has an altered level of consciousness with decreased spontaneous and elicited movements. The patient is hypotonic on motor testing, has bulging anterior fontanelle, and appears cyanotic. Which of the following are the best next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Skulling echography
B: Cranial ultrasonography
C: Bone structure of cranium imaging ultrasound
D: Cranium bone echography
E: MRI of the head

Question: A 45-year-old man presents to your office with a 2-year history of moderate-to-severe pelvic pain, irritative voiding urinary symptoms (frequency and dysuria), and occasional frank blood in his semen with painful ejaculation. He has been evaluated by several practitioners, who have all prescribed antimicrobial therapy, including ciprofloxacin, with no improvement and leading to emotional distress and sleep disturbances. The physical examination is unremarkable, except for a mildly tender prostate, without masses or nodules. There are no testicular masses, hernias, or hemorrhoids. Additionally to this health issue, you have also been following him for recurrent abdominal pain, periods of constipation and diarrhea, and fatigability, with all test results within the normal range thus far. A summary of recent tests is shown in the following table:
Urine test
Sample White cells Culture
Mid-stream urine Negative Negative
Expressed prostatic secretion Positive Negative
. What are the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Benign prostatic hyperplasia
B: Chronic, non-bacterial prostatitis
C: Acute prostatitis by Chlamydia trachomatis
D: Chronic prostatitis by resistant Escherichia coli
E: Interstitial cystitis

Question: A 65-year-old woman presents with a several month history of right upper quadrant abdominal pain and nausea. She has had no vomiting. She had an episode of weight loss of approximately 0.9–1.4 kg (2–3 lb) over the past 12 months. There is no history of similar symptoms or of jaundice. She had a hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy at age 45 years. She takes hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension and metoprolol for angina. She reports that she has never smoked and consumes approximately four alcoholic drinks per week. She has no known drug allergies. Examination shows a well-developed, well-nourished woman in no distress. The weight is 54 kg (118 lb) and the height is 160 cm (63 in). Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse 85/min, blood pressure 130/81 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Her sclerae are white without icterus. The chest examination shows equal breath sounds bilaterally without rales, rhonchi, or wheezes. The cardiovascular examination shows an irregular heart rate without murmurs, gallops, or rubs. Examination of the abdomen shows a soft, non-tender abdomen, with no organomegaly or masses. Laboratory studies show:
Serum bilirubin 1.0 mg/dL (N < 1.2 mg/dL)
Alkaline phosphatase 166 IU/L (N 30–115 IU/L)
Aspartate aminotransferase 30 IU/L (N < 45 IU/L)
Alanine aminotransferase 24 IU/L (N < 41 IU/L)
Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL (N 0.5–1.3 mg/dL)
Albumin 3.6 g/dL (N 3.3–4.9 g/dL)
White blood cell count 7000/mm3 (N 4500–11,000/mm3)
Hemoglobin 13.0 g/dL (N 12–16 g/dL)
Platelet count 150,000/mm3 (N 150,000–400,000/mm3)
Urinalysis sg 1.025, pH 6.0, protein < 0.3 g/dL, glucose negative, WBC moderate, RBC 0-1/hpf
Ultrasound of the liver and biliary system shows stones or sludge in the gallbladder, as well as a dilated common bile duct. The patient is prescribed gemfibrozil for hyperlipidemia. What are not the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's liver disease? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Evaluate the patient for primary biliary cholangitis
B: Perform a liver biopsy
C: Modify the patient's diet
D: Place the patient on a low-fat, high-fiber diet
E: Administer cholecystectomy
Answer: A,B

Question: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, weight loss, and muscle aches during the past 2 months. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her only medication is a multivitamin. A metyrapone stimulation test is performed and the results rule out a diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency. Which of the following changes in laboratory findings are most likely to have been observed in this patient following the administration of the drug? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Increase in serum ACTH
B: Decrease in urinary 17-hydroxycorticosteroids
C: Augmented in serums acth
D: Increase in serums acth
E: Increase in urine metanephrines

Question: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, weight loss, and muscle aches during the past 2 months. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her only medication is a multivitamin. A metyrapone stimulation test is performed and the results rule out a diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency. B,C,D,E

Question: A 24-year-old woman reports 3 days of "flu-like" symptoms: myalgias, arthralgias, fatigue, low-grade fever (37.8°C [100°F]), nausea, and vomiting. She now has a rash that is most prominent on her abdomen, palms, and soles and is accompanied by conjunctival injection and erythema. She denies any oral, genital, or rectal lesions. 
Her blood pressure is 100/50 mm Hg, pulse 120/min, respirations 25/min, and temperature 38.2°C (100.8°F). Examination of the skin shows a diffuse fine, blanching, maculopapular rash, most conspicuous on the palms and soles. The oral, genital, and rectal areas are not involved. There is conjunctival injection and erythema, but no uveitis or iritis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of this patient?
Options: A: Rheumatology consultation
B: Obtain rubella titer
C: Obtain blood and throat cultures
D: Examine a Tzanck smear
E: Obtain serologic studies for parvovirus B19
Answer: D

Question: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine gynecological examination and to refill her birth control pills. Her last pap smear at age 22 showed no intraepithelial lesions nor malignancy of the cervical cells. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 4 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner. Her father died of colon cancer at the age of 75 years and her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 40 years. She mentions that she is planning a backpacking trip through Europe in 2 months. Her routine immunizations are all up-to-date. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F) and her blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Pelvic and speculum examination show no abnormalities. Which of the following are the best recommendation for the patient at this time? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis screening
B: Beta-hCG urine test
C: Neisseria gonorrhoeae and chlamydia trachomatis screening study
D: Neisseria gonorrhoeae and chlamydia trachomatis screening
E: Neisseria gonorrhoeae and chlamydia trachomatis screening trial

Question: A 28-year-old woman is seen for evaluation of a rash on the volar aspect of her hands and feet that began 1 week ago. Four days ago, she began having tenderness of the oral mucosa. She denies facial swelling, joint pain, or eye pain. She is taking acyclovir by mouth 3 times a day. Examination shows erythema and vesicular lesions on the volar aspect of the hands and feet in a glove-and-stocking distribution. The oral mucosa is tender but has no lesions. A potassium hydroxide skin preparation of a lesion from the hand shows branching septate hyphae. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Dermatitis herpetiformis
B: Pityriasis rosea
C: Tinea pedis
D: Erythema multiforme
E: Dyshidrosis
Answer: A,C

Question: A 70-year-old man presents to the hospital with a 5-day history of odynophagia, fever, and a sore throat. He has no significant medical history, and he takes no medications. He is allergic to erythromycin. Physical examination reveals an ill-appearing man with a temperature of 102°F, heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 100/60 mm Hg. Mild erythema and edema are present in the oral pharynx. Examination of the lungs, heart, and abdomen reveals no abnormalities. White blood cell count is 25,000/μL with 80% neutrophils. A rapid strep test result is negative, and a Gram stain of the pharynx shows numerous gram-positive cocci in pairs and chains, with many neutrophils. Chest x-ray and electrocardiogram results are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Ampicillin
B: Vancomycin
C: Penicillin
D: Clindamycin
E: Erythromycin
Answer: A,D

Question: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her concerned father. He states that ever since her uncomplicated delivery she has failed to gain weight, has had chronic diarrhea, and has had multiple bacterial and viral infections. During the course of the workup, an absent thymic shadow is noted and a lymph node biopsy demonstrates the absence of germinal centers. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Adenosine deaminase deficiency
B: Adenosine deaminase deficiency
C: Adenosine deaminase deficiency
D: NADPH oxidase deficiency
E: Adenosine deaminase deficiency

Question: A 65-year-old man presents to the physician with a 2-week history of a persistent cough productive of green sputum. Options: A: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
B: Amoxicillin
C: Doxycycline
D: Clindamycin
E: Clarithromycin

Which of the following drugs were most likely prescribed to this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.

Question: A 22-year-old gravida 1 presents to her physician at 15 weeks gestation for a prenatal appointment. Question: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because he has had diarrhea for 3 days. It is nonbloody, loose, and frequent, emptying his bowels up to 15 times/day and awakening him from sleep. He has also noticed significant abdominal cramping, mild nausea, and intermittent vomiting. He tried some loperamide, which did not help. His medical history is unremarkable. He takes no medications, and he denies tobacco or alcohol use. A stool test for common ova and parasites is negative. On physical examination, he is in no acute distress. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. His BMI is 21. His abdominal exam is benign, with no tenderness, hepatomegaly, or splenomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
Options: A: Bacillary dysentery
B: Irritable bowel syndrome
C: Ulcerative colitis
D: Colitis
E: Crohn disease
Answer: A

Question: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 26 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department because of frequent contractions. The contractions last 40 seconds, occur every 2 minutes, and are increasing in intensity. She has a history of recurrent painful ulcers on her vulva, but she currently does not have them. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a non-reassuring fetal heart rate. Her current medications include acyclovir, folic acid, and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), heart rate is 88/min, and blood pressure is 126/76 mm Hg. Contractions are felt on the abdomen. The cervix is dilated to 5 cm, 70% effaced, and the station of the head is -2. A fetal ultrasound shows no abnormalities. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Allow vaginal delivery
B: Allows vaginal delivery
C: Allows vaginal transferred
D: Perform cesarean delivery
E: Allow vaginal transfer technique

Question: A 59-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and fever of 1 week duration. She also reports fatigue, nausea, and vomiting. She has a history of congestive heart failure, which has been managed with diuretics. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 131/72 mm Hg. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bibasilar rales. There is 2+ pitting edema in the legs. Which of the following are not the most likely causes of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Right-sided heart failure
B: Gastrointestinal hemorrhage
C: Left-sided heart failure
D: Pulmonary embolism
E: Viral gastroenteritis
Answer: B,E

Question: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his wife due to abdominal distension and persistent somnolence for the past 2 weeks. The patient’s wife says that he has been sleeping much more than usual for the past 5 days. His bowel and bladder habit have not changed. His past medical history is significant for alcoholic liver cirrhosis. His vital signs include: pulse 76/min, respiratory rate 15/min, temperature 38.0°C (100.4°F) and blood pressure 122/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient is altered and not responsive to commands. Oriented x 0. The abdomen is significantly distended. Shifting dullness is present and a positive fluid wave can be elicited. Hyperreflexia and asterixis are noted. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
Laboratory test
Sodium 140 mEq/L
Potassium 3.5 mEq/L
Chloride 97 mEq/L
Glucose 90 mg/dL
Ammonia 100 µg/dL (ref: 19-60 µg/dL)
Arterial blood gas
pH 7.4
pCO2 40 mm Hg
pO2 90 mm Hg
HCO3 26 mEq/L
An abdominal ultrasound shows surface nodularity compatible with cirrhosis but no other changes aside from ascites. An upper GI endoscopy is performed which shows gastric varices with no signs of active bleeding. An MRI of the brain is insignificant. What are the most likely precipitating factor that led to this patient’s condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis
B: Metabolic alkalosis
C: Variceal gastrointestinal bleeding
D: Bacterial peritonitis spontaneous
E: Hypoglycemia

Question: A 35-year-old female 5 months pregnant presents with complaints of fatigue, easy bruisability, and diffuse gingival pain. Her hemoglobin was 9.0 g/dL. Which of the following are not the most appropriate management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Oral iron
B: Blood transfusion
C: Parenteral iron
D: Folic acid supplement
E: Vitamin B12 supplement
Answer: B,D,E

Question: A 72-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital for the evaluation of breathlessness and fatigue. His pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Further evaluation shows a systemic vascular resistance of 35 mm Hg × min/L with an end-systolic volume of 80 mL. Which of the following describes the ejection fraction in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: 30%
B: 15%
C: 35%
D: 25%
E: 20%

Question: A 72-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital for the evaluation of breathlessness and fatigue. His pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Further evaluation shows a systemic vascular resistance of 35 mm Hg × min/L with an end-systolic volume of 80 mL. Which of the following do not describes the ejection fraction in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: 30%
B: 15%
C: 35%
D: 25%
E: 20%

D

Question: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with substernal chest pain and diaphoresis. An electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrates ST-elevation in leads V1 through V4. His blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg and pulse is 90/min. Vital signs include: temperature 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse 90/min, blood pressure 180/110 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 18/min. Nitroprusside is prescribed. Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is performed with a drug-eluting stent placed in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) demonstrates a resolving anterior wall hypokinesis. What is the most important next step in the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Start thiopurines
B: Start infliximab
C: Start coumadin
D: Dual antiplatelet therapy
E: Genetic testing
Answer: D

Question: A 31-year-old female patient presents with significant swelling and redness of her fingers that is causing her significant pain. Her right knee has also been stiff and slightly swollen for the past 6 weeks. She is overall fatigued and has difficulty moving around but has not sought medical attention until now. On physical examination, the distal interphalangeal joints are swollen, warm, and painful; her nails are pitted and cracked. There are also rough, erythematous skin patches seen over her elbows which have been present for the last few months. She reports that herer father has a similar condition. They both use hydrating creams and topical glucocorticoids with moderate benefit. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Gout
B: Psoriatic inflammation of joint nos
C: Psoriatic arthritis
D: Psoriatic arthritides
E: Psoriatic arthritis

Question: A 69-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being found on the floor in his home, unresponsive and incontinent. The paramedics report that he was breathing but had no pulse. Resuscitative efforts were begun immediately, and he was transported to the ED. There is nasal trauma, entrapped air around both orbits, and an injury to the right parietal bone with extensive scalp hematoma. The pupil reflexes are equal and round, reactive to light, and accommodation is present. The breath sounds are equal and normal bilaterally. He has no spontaneous respirations, and the abdominal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: CT scan of the head and neck
B: Immediate arteriography
C: Ventriculostomy
D: Intubation
E: Angiogram
Answer: B,E

Question: A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of worsening pain, discoloration, and swelling of her right hand. Two days ago, she was camping outdoors in Texas with her two young children. She was awoken in the middle of the night by “something crawling on my hand.” The following morning, she saw a wound on her hand that was initially painless, but over the next several hours she noticed reddening and blistering. Yesterday, the lesion turned blue with a blackish discoloration at the center. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bluish plaque with a central area of necrosis surrounded by a rim of erythema at the dorsum of the right hand. Which of the following animals are most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Bald-faced hornet
B: Diamondback rattlesnake
C: Brown recluse spider
D: Striped bark scorpion
E: Deer tick

Question: A 28-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of painful, pruritic lesions on his dorsal penile shaft, glans, and scrotum. He has never had a similar rash. He denies fever, malaise, and change in his urinary habits. On examination, multiple erythematous, scaly papules and plaques with overlying crust and fissures are present on the glans penis, penile shaft, and scrotum. There are no other palpable lesions on the physical examination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Secondary syphilis
B: Condyloma acuminata
C: Psoriasis
D: Herpes simplex virus type 2
E: Primary syphilis
Answer: E

Question: A 53-year-old obese woman with diabetes comes to the physician reporting worsening diarrhea and hematochezia. She is accompanied to the office by her husband, who reports that she has been experiencing episodes of urgency, frequency, and incontinence as well. Stool testing results are negative for white blood cells, mucus, pathogenic bacteria, and ova. The following is revealed by colonoscopy:
Normal-appearing mucosa in the colon
Numerous small (<5 mm) polyps in the transverse colon and rectum
Two sessile polyps in the rectum are removed and sent for pathologic examination which reveals that both polyps are tubular adenomas (TA) without evidence of invasion. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Colonoscopy in 1 year
B: Colonoscopy in 3 years
C: Flexible sigmoidoscopy in 5 years
D: Flexible sigmoidoscopy in 10 years
E: Abdominal CT scan in 1 year
Answer: E

Question: A 25-year-old female is brought to the emergency department by her family. They found her somnolent next to her computer and scattered pill bottles over two hours ago. The family cannot recall the types of pill bottles that they found and did not bring them to the ED. The patient's past medical history is notable for anxiety, obesity, hypertension, and polycystic ovarian syndrome. She is currently not on any medications other than an exercise program with which she is non-compliant. A physical exam is performed and is within normal limits. The patient begins communicating with the physician and states that she did take acetaminophen but it was only a few pills. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse is 82/min, blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, respirations are 11/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Which of the following are the next best step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: N-acetylcysteine
B: Blood acetaminophen levels
C: N-acetylcysteine
D: IV fluids
E: Syrup of ipecac

Question: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of recurrent vaginal yeast infections. She has had three infections in the last 6 months. She has no history of other sexually transmitted diseases. Her last menstrual period began 10 days ago. She is not using hormonal contraception. Her partner has no symptoms. On examination, the temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), the pulse is 80/min, and the blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination of the skin, mucous membranes, and lymph nodes shows no abnormalities. Examination of the heart, lungs, and abdomen shows no abnormalities. Examination of the vagina shows slight erythema of the vaginal mucosa. Microscopic examination of the vaginal fluid shows budding yeast. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's yeast infection? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Diabetes
B: Obesity
C: Frequent antibiotic use
D: Pregnancy
E: Immunosuppression
Answer: C

Question: Two hours following an elective cholecystectomy, a 43-year-old woman has fever and chills. The patient received cephalexin for antibiotic prophylaxis and one unit of packed red blood cells during the procedure. She underwent a hysterectomy 9 years ago for leiomyomata uteri. She has a 5-year history of hypertension treated with lisinopril. Her temperature is 39.5°C (102.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a mildly tender abdominal wound without erythema. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. She had a Foley catheter and peripheral line access placed at the time of the procedure. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Adverse effect of medication
B: Blood transfusion reaction
C: Blood complications transfusion
D: Urinary tract infection
E: Transfusion reaction

Question: A 24-year-old man presents to a physician because of a 1-day history of right-sided ear pain and a bloody, purulent discharge from the right ear. He has had several episodes of right-sided otitis media during the past few years. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and requires insulin. He has no known allergies. He is sexually active with multiple partners and does not use condoms. He also reports recreational use of methamphetamines. Examination of the right ear shows a perforation of the tympanic membrane. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Otitis media
B: HIV infection
C: Pneumococcal meningitis
D: Chlamydia trachomatis
E: Neurosyphilis
Answer: B,C,D,E

Question: A 45-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset dyspnea. Her past medical history is significant for varicose veins in her lower extremities, well-controlled diabetes mellitus type 2, and a 25 pack-year smoking history. The patient currently takes metformin and pioglitazone. Family history is significant for her sister who died at the age of 35 because of a pulmonary embolism. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), the pulse is 111/min, the respirations are 18/min, and the blood pressure is 130/60 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient is pale and diaphoretic. Cardiac exam is significant for an S3 gallop. There is erythema and swelling over multiple varicose veins in her left leg. Ultrasound of her left leg is positive for a deep vein thrombosis. The patient is admitted, and anticoagulation is started with a vitamin K inhibitor. However, despite these interventions, she dies shortly after admission. Which of the following were the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Distal peripheral microembolism
B: Defic protein s
C: Necrotizing fasciitis
D: Protein S deficiency
E: Protein s deficiencies

Question: A 29-year-old woman with a history of anxiety disorder is brought to the emergency department by emergency medical services after accidentally ingesting 12 tablets of alprazolam, 0.5 mg each, 1 hour before presentation. In the emergency department, her heart rate is 76/min and regular, respiratory rate is 12/min, blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Examination of her lungs is clear to auscultation bilaterally, and no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi are heard. Examination of her heart reveals tachycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Neurological examination reveals lethargy, ataxia, and dysarthria. Which of following is the most likely medication for the patient to be given?
Options: A: Lorazepam
B: Naltrexone
C: Flumazenil
D: Ondansetron
E: Sodium bicarbonate
Answer: C

Question: A 6-month-old boy presents to his pediatrician for a wellness examination. The mother reports that her child has difficulty rolling from his back to his front and sitting unsupported. The patient is able to smile and furrow his brow normally, but she has noticed that he has a weak cry and suck. He was born at 38 weeks gestation via a spontaneous vaginal delivery without any complications. The mother said that the patient appeared "normal" until the past few weeks. On physical exam, his extraocular muscle movements are intact, and a symmetric smile is seen. He has symmetric flaccid weakness of both his upper and lower extremities. He also has a bell-shaped chest. Deep tendon reflexes are diminished. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Anterior horn cell degeneration
B: Axonal demyelination
C: Decreased acetylcholine receptor density
D: Impaired acetylcholine release
E: Myonecrosis

Question: A 57-year-old woman presents to a physician with a 3-month history of intermittent, painless yellowing of the whites of her eyes. She also reports a 2-month history of darkened amber urine and vague pruritis of the extremities, as well as a recent unintentional weight loss of 5 kg. She denies abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or melena. Her medical history includes hypertension, which is well controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. She has not consumed alcohol in many years and denies use of illicit drugs. On review of systems, she says that she has a dull aching pain intermittently in the epigastric region that radiates to the right upper quadrant. On physical examination, no jaundice of the skin is apparent, but the sclerae are deeply yellow. The liver is enlarged 1 cm past the costal margin, although it is nontender. No splenomegaly or ascites are identified. There is no lymphadenopathy. She has moderate pruritus on her arms and legs. Laboratory findings include:  
total bilirubin 6.8 mg/dL  
direct bilirubin 5.8 mg/dL  
aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 198 U/L  
alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 142 U/L  
alkaline phosphatase 137 U/L  
gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) 93 U/L  
Hepatitis serologic studies  
Hepatitis A anti-HAV: Positive  
Hepatitis B surface antigen: Negative  
Hepatitis B core antibody (HBcAb): Positive  
Hepatitis C antibody: Negative  
Serum ceruloplasmin 18 mg/dL  
Serum protein electrophoresis: Normal Which of the following are the most likely causes of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Biliary obstruction
B: Cirrhosis
C: Gilbert syndrome
D: Hepatitis B
E: Hepatitis C
Answer: D

Question: A 32-year-old G6P3003 female presents to her primary care physician for a preoperative evaluation for a hysterectomy. Her past medical history includes depression with current use of fluoxetine. No history of alcohol abuse. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She denies any urinary or bowel incontinence. She does complain of low back pain. On physical exam, her vital signs are within normal limits. Her heart is regular rate and rhythm. Her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. Her abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended. The cervix and uterus are normal. Which of the following medications is contraindicated for this patient?
Options: A: Acetaminophen
B: Ofloxacin
C: Ibuprofen
D: Loratadine
E: Codeine
Answer: E

Question: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for short stature. Neither his clothing nor his shoe size have changed over the past year. He also frequently bumps into obstacles such as furniture and has headaches at night. He is always thirsty for cold water and has been urinating more frequently. Three years ago, he had an asthma attack that was treated with albuterol and a one-week course of steroids. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis and had precocious puberty. His mother's height is 147 cm (4 ft 10 in) and his father's height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in). He is at the 5th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/64 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The genitals and pubic hair are both Tanner stage 1. Axillary hair is absent. Patellar reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:
Na+ 145 mEq/L
K+ 4.1 mEq/L
Cl- 102 mEq/L
HCO3- 25 mEq/L
Ca2+ 9.4 mg/dL
Glucose 110 mg/dL
Thyroid-stimulating hormone 0.3 μU/mL
Thyroxine 3.9 μg/dL
Insulin-like growth factor 1 24 ng/mL (N=61–356 ng/mL)
Insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3 2.1 mcg/mL (N=1.6–6.5 μg/mL)
. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Craniopharyngioma
B: Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome
C: Craniopharyngioma
D: Craniopharyngioma
E: Craniopharyngioma

Question: A 60-year-old man with type 2 diabetes presents to the physician for his scheduled annual examination. Examination shows that his blood pressure is 148/76 mm Hg and his weight is 90.7 kg (199.9 lb). His provider discussed the benefits of weight loss with him and prescribed orlistat, 120 mg three times per day. Which of the following complications is of concern for this patient during treatment with orlistat? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Hepatotoxicity
B: Hypertension
C: Nephrotoxicity
D: Fatty stool
E: Steatorrhea
Answer: D,E

Question: A 25-year-old male patient comes to the emergency department with complaints of right calf pain and swelling for the last 24 hours. He is using crutches to ambulate in the triage area. He denies shortness of breath, chest pain, or arm swelling. He has no past medical history, no known allergies, and is not taking any medications. He is afebrile. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 160/95 mm Hg, oxygen saturation is 100% on room air, and BMI is 29 kg/m2. Physical examination is significant for normal pulses and capillary refill in bilateral lower extremities. There is no tachypnea, jugular venous distension, or thrills over the carotid or femoral arteries. Neck pulses are full and equal. There is no bruits heard over the abdomen or lower extremities. Pulmonary and cardiac examinations are unremarkable. Musculoskeletal examination shows an antalgic gait. Right calf is erythematous and edematous, with no fluctuance. The calf is tender to palpation, and there is no pitting edema. Pedal pulses are intact and equal bilaterally. Motor and sensation remain intact distally. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options:
A: Apply a long leg cast
B: Perform venography
C: Perform an echocardiogram
D: Start anticoagulation
E: Measure d-dimers
Answer: A,C,D,E

Question: A mother brings her 6-year-old daughter to the pediatrician to discuss her child's sleeping troubles. Three times now in the last month the child has begun screaming and crying in the middle of the night. When the parents rush to the child's room, they find her crying inconsolably. They try to ask her what is wrong, but she does not respond and persists crying for approximately 20 minutes, after which she goes back to sleeping comfortably. Upon awaking the following morning, she has no recollection of the night's events. Which of the following are true about these episodes? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: They happened only during non-rem sleeps
B: They occur only during non-REM sleep
C: They can occur any time during the sleep cycle
D: They are associated with child abuse
E: They are associated with later development of a mood disorder

Question: A 68-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and weight loss. He is especially concerned about a recent episode in which he noticed a blurring of his vision and headache; he also notes that his “memory is not as good as it used to be,” which his wife confirms. Physical exam is notable only for pallor and general weakness. Laboratory studies reveal anemia as well as an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) reveals a sharp, narrow spike of monoclonal IgM; serum IgM concentration is 6.3 g/dL. What are the most likely diagnosis in this case? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia
B: Multiple myeloma
C: Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia
D: Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma
E: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

Question: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic constipation and abdominal pain. He reports having infrequent bowel movements (often 5-6 days between movements) for the last several months. He describes the pain as dull, aching, and relieved with defecation. He denies any nausea, vomiting, blood in his stool, hematochezia, or diarrhea. The patient also reports a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. Additionally, he reports frequent urgency to urinate and burning with urination. On physical examination, he is afebrile with normal vital signs. His abdomen is soft and distended, with mild tenderness on palpation in the left lower quadrant. Rectal examination reveals hard stool in the rectal vault. The prostate is slightly enlarged but nontender. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Irritable bowel syndrome
B: Pancreatitis
C: Diverticulitis
D: Colorectal cancer
E: Prostate cancer
Answer: D

Question: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of an increasing difficulty in hearing over the past several months. His mother says they have to speak at a higher volume for him to understand them. He also complains of having difficulty reading his favorite books because he is not able to see the words clearly. His father received a renal transplant in his 20s. The vital signs are within normal limits. The physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Urea nitrogen 15 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL
Urine
Blood 1+
Protein 1+
RBC 15–17/hpf
WBC 1–2/hpf
The audiometry shows bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. The ophthalmologic examination shows anterior lenticonus. Which of the following best explains these findings? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Alport syndrome
B: Alport's syndrome
C: Hematuria-nephropathy-deafness syndrome
D: Von Hippel-Lindau disease
E: Hereditary nephritis alports syndrome

Question: A 68-year-old male presented to the clinic with a 6-month history of pain in the right shoulder. The pain started slowly and has progressively worsened to the point that he can no longer sleep on his right side. His symptoms are worse with elevation and active movement of the right arm. He does have a history of diabetes for 15 years. Physical exam showed moderate tenderness to palpation over the greater tuberosity without swelling. On range of motion testing, he had 0 degrees of flexion and 155 degrees of extension. He had a positive Hawkins impingement test. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Biceps tenotomy
B: Subacromial decompression
C: Arthroscopic capsular release
D: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
E: Injection of a long-acting corticosteroid into the subacromial space
Answer: A,C

Question: A 32-year-old man arrives to his primary care physician to discuss his fear of flying. The patient reports that he has had a fear of flying since being a teenager. He went on a family vacation 15 years ago, and during the flight there was turbulence and a “rough landing”. Since then he has avoided flying. He did not go to his cousin’s wedding because it was out of the country. He also was unable to visit his grandmother for her 80th birthday. The last time his job asked him to meet a client out of state, he drove 18 hours instead of flying. Two years ago he promised his fiancé they could fly to Florida. Upon arrival at the airport, he began to feel dizzy, lightheaded, and refused to go through security. During the clinic visit, the patient appears anxious and distressed. He recognizes that his fear is irrational. He is upset that it is affecting his relationship with his wife. Additionally, his current job may soon require employees in his sales position to fly to meet potential clients. He is embarrassed to have a conversation with his manager about his fear of flying. Which of the following are the best therapy for the patient’s condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Alprazolam
B: Cognitive behavioral therapy
C: Fluoxetine
D: Psychodynamic psychotherapy
E: Zolpidem

Question: A 3-year-old boy presents to the physician for evaluation of a persistent cough and sore throat. He has a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F), respiration rate of 24 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation of 98% in room air. Examination of the ears, mouth, and throat shows hypertrophy of the tonsils and adenoids, and mild erythema of the posterior pharynx. The trachea is deviated to the right. The rest of the examination results are normal. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient’s condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Congenital hyperthyroidism
B: Adenovirus infection
C: Parainfluenza infection
D: Haemophilus influenzae infection
E: Retropharyngeal abscess
Answer: B,C

Question: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine examination. She has no symptoms. She says she was previously told that she has 2 full sisters, but her mother has recently admitted that a neighbor’s sperm was used for intrauterine insemination to conceive her. This information has been difficult for her to process. She is beginning to have doubts about her relationship with her parents and is wondering if they want to do genetic testing. Which of the following is the best way to counsel this patient about the availability of genetic testing? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Explain that genetic testing is complex and should only be done in the context of a mental health evaluation.
B: Reassure the patient that genetic testing is available and can provide definitive answers about her biological origins.
C: Encourage her to speak to her parents about her concerns and see if they are willing to undergo genetic testing.
D: Suggest that she meet with a genetic counselor to learn more about her options.
E: Tell her that genetic testing is not necessary because it will not change who she is.
Answer: C,D

Question: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. He was the front seat unrestrained driver in a head-on collision. The patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale of 5 and is subsequently intubated. Physical exam is notable for subcutaneous emphysema in the clavicular area. Needle decompression and chest tube placement are performed, and the patient is stabilized after receiving 2 units of blood and 2 liters of fluid. Chest radiography demonstrates proper tube location and resolution of the pneumothorax. The patient is transferred to the trauma intensive care unit. On the unit, a repeat chest radiograph is notable for a recurrent pneumothorax with the chest tube in place. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Tracheobronchial rupture
B: Inappropriate chest tube placement
C: Tracheo bronchial rupture
D: Tracheo bronchial rupture
E: Tracheobronchial rupture

Question: A 10-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with a 2-week history of dry, nonproductive cough that began after swimming in a public pool. He denies any recent travel, fevers, chills, shortness of breath, or chest pain. Vital signs are as follows:
Temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F)
Heart rate 88 beats/min
Respiratory rate 18 breaths/min
Blood pressure 112/70 mm Hg
Oxygen saturation 98% on room air

On physical examination, the patient has no distress. Examination of the tympanic membranes shows mild hyperemia and bulging with injection of the surrounding vasculature. The pharynx is mildly erythematous. The chest is clear to auscultation bilaterally and percussion. Laboratory findings are as follows:
Complete blood count:
WBC 11,000/µL (Reference range: 4500-11,000/µL)
Segmented neutrophils 67% (Reference range: 40%-75%)
Lymphocytes 22% (Reference range: 15%-40%)
Monocytes 3% (Reference range: 2%-10%)
Eosinophils 6% (Reference range: 0%-5%)
Basophils 2% (Reference range: 0%-1%)

Results of a rapid streptococcal antigen test are negative. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Treat the patient with amoxicillin
B: Obtain a chest x-ray
C: Start the patient on symptomatic therapy, such as cough suppressants
D: Administer antibiotics
E: Draw blood for respiratory viral serologies
Answer: B,D,E

Question: A 25-year-old man with a past medical history of constipation and fibromyalgia presents to the emergency department with generalized malaise and severe diarrhea. The patient states that he has not felt well for the past 24 hours and his symptoms are no longer tolerable. He denies taking any medications or illicit drugs and states he is generally healthy. His temperature is 99.3°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 122/88 mmHg, pulse is 107/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates an ill appearing young man. Physical exam is notable for rhinorrhea, lacrimation, and piloerection. The patient’s pupils are dilated and reactive to light. During placement of an ultrasound guided IV, multiple scars are noted in the antecubital fossa, and it is noted that it is very difficult to place an IV in this patient. During the exam, he begins actively vomiting. Which of the following could be an appropriate treatment for this patient’s symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Clonidine
B: Diazepam taper
C: Haloperidol and diphenhydramine
D: Clonidine
E: Oseltamivir

Question: A 6-year-old male presents to the office for his scheduled immunization visit. His mother states that he is healthy overall and she has no concerns at this time. The patient's past medical history is significant for mild asthma. His current medications include albuterol inhaler as needed for wheezing. Immunization records show that he is up-to-date except for being overdue for his 6-year-old vaccine. According to the CDC recommendations, which of the following vaccines should you administer at this visit? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: MMR
B: DTaP
C: Tdap
D: IPV
E: Hib
Answer: B,C,D

Question: A 20-year-old woman in the army recruit collapses during an especially hot day at basic training. She was in her normal excellent state of health prior to this event. Two weeks ago, she had an upper respiratory infection (URI) but has since recovered. Her father has chronic kidney disease (CKD), bilateral hearing loss, and vision problems. At the hospital, her temperature is 40.3°C (104.5°F), blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg, pulse is 105/min, and respiratory rate is 24/min. On physical exam, the patient appears to have altered mental status and her skin is dry, hot, and erythematous. She is complaining of severe bilateral flank pain and generalized myalgia. Catheterization produces 200 mL of tea-colored urine. Urine dipstick is positive for blood, but urinalysis is negative for RBCs or WBCs. Which of the following are most likely responsible for her condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Heat stroke
B: Neisseria meningitides
C: Heat exhaustion
D: Heat stroke
E: IgA nephropathy

Question: A 53-year-old man with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and diabetes mellitus presents with left facial droop and right hemiparesis that had developed gradually over the past week. The day prior to this, he also began having slurred speech. A brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan with contrast reveals a large mass with surrounding edema in the left frontal lobe with a considerable amount of surrounding edema. On examination, his vital signs are BP 140/90, pulse 80/min, respirations 13/min, and temperature 37°C. His speech is dysarthric, the left eye droops, and the smile is asymmetrical. Attempts to lift the left arm and leg fail, and reflexes and strength are diminished there. The patient also has numbness in these extremities. Which of the following is not the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Glioma
B: Tuberculosis
C: Lung cancer
D: Meningioma
E: Bacterial encephalitis
Answer: C,E

Question: A 21-year-old male presents to his primary care provider for fatigue. He reports that he graduated from college last month and returned 3 days ago from a 2 week vacation to Vietnam and Cambodia. For the past 2 days, he has developed a worsening headache, malaise, and pain in his hands and wrists. The patient has a past medical history of asthma managed with albuterol as needed. He is sexually active with both men and women, and he uses condoms “most of the time.” On physical exam, the patient’s temperature is 102.5°F (39.2°C), blood pressure is 112/66 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He has tenderness to palpation over his bilateral metacarpophalangeal joints and a maculopapular rash on his trunk and upper thighs. Tourniquet test is negative. Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL
Hematocrit: 44%
Leukocyte count: 3,200/mm^3
Platelet count: 112,000/mm^3

Serum:
Na+: 142 mEq/L
Cl-: 104 mEq/L
K+: 4.6 mEq/L
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
BUN: 18 mg/dL
Glucose: 87 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
AST: 106 U/L
ALT: 112 U/L
Bilirubin (total): 0.8 mg/dL
Bilirubin (conjugated): 0.3 mg/dL

. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Chikungunya
B: Chikungunya
C: Chikungunya
D: Hepatitis A
E: Typhoid fever

Question: A 22-year-old woman presents to the clinic for her third trimester prenatal care visit. Her blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. She denies having headaches, visual disturbances, or ankle swelling. A urine dipstick shows proteinuria. Her serum creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Admit to the hospital immediately
B: Repeat blood pressure measurement in 1 week
C: Administer oral nifedipine
D: Measure 24-hour urine protein
E: Administer intravenous hydralazine
Answer: A,D

Question: A 42-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of diarrhea. He is afebrile and has no other symptoms. He has no history of gastrointestinal problems. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following are not the correct choice as a cause of this patient's diarrhea? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Celiac disease
B: Irritable bowel syndrome
C: Ulcerative colitis
D: Pancreatitis
E: Crohn's disease
Answer: B,D

Question: A 38-year-old nursing home worker presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and productive cough for the past couple of months. His fever is low-grade and sputum is often blood-tinged. He has lost 6.8 kg (15.0 lb) during this period and complains of profound night sweats. A plain radiograph of the patient’s chest shows consolidation in the apical part of the right lung. Baseline investigations show the following:
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin 11 g/dL
White blood cells  
Total count 16,000/mm3
Differential count  
Neutrophils 35%
Lymphocytes 54%
Eosinophils 11%
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 84 mm
The physician suspects that the patient is suffering from a chronic lung infection. Which of the following statements best describes the type of lung inflammation in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: It consists of a largely surroundings granulomata with epithelioid cellula with langhans type giant cells.
B: It has a granuloma with Anitchov cells around a core of fibrinoid collagen necrosis.
C: It consists of a largely circumscribed granuloma with epithelioid cells with Langhans cells.
D: It consists of a largely circumscribed epithelioid granulomas with epithelioid cells set with langhans giant cells.
E: It consists of a largely surround granulomas with epithelioid cell with langhans giant cells.

Question: A 60-year-old woman comes to the outpatient clinic with a chief complaint of nausea for the past 8 hours. The nausea is constant and is not associated with vomiting, abdominal discomfort, or diarrhea. The patient denies fever, cough, or any other systemic symptoms. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hypothyroidism for which she takes lisinopril, simvastatin, and levothyroxine, respectively. She is also taking a multivitamin daily. On physical exam, she appears slightly distressed. Her vital signs are: blood pressure 162/102 mm Hg, heart rate 86/min, and respirations 20/min. Examination of the chest reveals clear lung fields bilaterally with no wheezes, rales, or rubs. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rate and rhythm. There is no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. Examination of the abdomen is normal. There is no tenderness, guarding, or rebound. Bowel sounds are present in all four quadrants. Rectal examination is normal. Vaginal examination reveals no masses or tenderness. Results of a complete blood count and electrolytes are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Acute gastritis
B: Peptic ulcer disease
C: Irritable bowel syndrome
D: Cholecystitis
E: Pancreatitis
Answer: A

Question: A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after being thrown from a horse. He was not wearing a helmet. He is alert and oriented. Respiratory rate is 28/min, heart rate is 105/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Neurological examination reveals a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15 without any focal deficits. Examination of the lumbosacral region reveals swelling, tenderness, and palpable deformity. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next steps in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Apply a belt
B: Obtain an x-ray of the lumbosacral spine
C: Perform a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the lumbosacral spine
D: Obtain an x-ray of the thoracic spine
E: Administer intravenous (IV) fluids
Answer: A,B,D

Question: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her father for evaluation. He is concerned that she has not undergone puberty yet, while all of her classmates at school have. The patient herself feels well overall, with no specific complaints. Examination shows vital signs of T 98.9, HR 71, and BP 137/92. The physician notes undeveloped breasts and normal external and internal female genitalia in Tanner I stage of development. Question: A 26-year-old man presents to the clinic for his annual physical exam. He has no medical problems and takes no medications. His blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg, pulse is 70/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. His height is 66in and his weight is 198 lb. He is not concerned about his weight and denies any dietary changes or problems with exercise. The physician notes that his waist circumference is 39 in. Body mass index (BMI) and waist circumference are calculated. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Refer to a dietician
B: Initiate pharmacologic weight loss therapy
C: Recommend an exercise program
D: Recommend a low-calorie diet
E: Recommend a low-carbohydrate diet
Answer: A,C,D

Question: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive at home.  On examination, he is lethargic, has shallow respirations, and has a blood pressure of 80/50 mm Hg and a heart rate of 120/min. Which of the following medications is not the most appropriate for initial management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Epinephrine
B: Atropine
C: Naloxone
D: Intravenous fluids
E: Thiamine
Answer: B,C

Question: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of increasing weakness and numbness of the upper extremities for 5 days. During the past 2 days, she has had urinary incontinence not related to sneezing or laughing. Last summer, she had weakness and numbness of her right lower extremity that was worse when she was outside; she regained her strength 3 weeks later. She has no history of serious illness. She has had 10 male sexual partners in her lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an impaired tandem gait. There is mild spasticity and muscle strength is decreased in both upper extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. The abdominal reflex is absent. Muscle strength in the right lower extremity is mildly decreased. Sensation to vibration and fine touch is decreased over the upper extremities. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Antinuclear antibody testing
B: Muscle biopsy
C: Rapid plasma reagin test
D: MRI of the brain and spine
E: Lumbar puncture

Question: A 37-year-old woman is brought into the emergency department after falling down a flight of stairs at her home. She is conscious but not alert. Neurological examination shows dilated pupils that do not respond to light and a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 6. A CT scan of the brain shows a subdural hematoma with a midline shift to the left. She underwent an emergency craniotomy to relieve pressure. Which of the following is not an important consideration for the management of this patient?
Options: A: Target temperature management
B: Methylprednisolone therapy
C: Monitoring of intracranial pressure
D: Fluid management
E: Transfusion of blood products as indicated
Answer: B

Question: A 63-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit for hemodynamic instability. Several days prior, he had been swimming in the Gulf coast when he stepped on a sharp rock and cut his right foot. Three days ago, the patient presented to the emergency room after noticing painful redness spreading along his skin up from his right foot and was subsequently admitted for antibiotic treatment. Currently, his temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C), blood pressure is 84/46 mmHg with a mean arterial pressure of 59 mmHg, pulse is 104/min, and respirations are 14/min. His telemetry shows sinus tachycardia. His blood cultures are pending, but Gram stain demonstrated gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following best describes the form of shock and the skin exam? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Distributive shock with warming process integument
B: Distributive shock with warm skin
C: Hypovolemic shock with warm skin
D: Distributive shock with warms skin
E: Obstructive shock with cold skin

Question: A 22-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of swelling in her face, hands, and neck with occasional abdominal pain. The symptoms usually resolve in 2 to 3 days. She has had these swelling events her whole life; however, they have become more debilitating recently. Last week she had an event that restricted her ability to eat and swallow.  Past medical history is noncontributory. Her father is alive and well with no significant medical history. Her mother and her maternal aunt have a similar condition. Today, her physical exam is within normal limits. She brought a picture of her swollen hand as seen in the picture. The treating physician has a strong suspicion of an inherited disorder. C1-inhibitor levels are ordered and found to be extremely low. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: DiGeorge syndrome
B: C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency
C: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
D: Hereditary angioneurotic edemas
E: Hereditary angioedema
