Question: A 38-year-old woman is seen in the clinic for an annual visit. She has a history of hypertension that is being treated with lisinopril. Her blood pressure today is 148/96 mm Hg. Her weight is 79 kg (174 lb) and height is 165 cm (65 in). She has no other medical problems. She desires to become pregnant and has not been trying to conceive. She currently has regular menstrual cycles. Which of the following is recommended? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Obtain a fasting plasma glucose level.
B: Obtain a serum creatinine level.
C: Obtain a hemoglobin A1c level.
D: Recommend starting prenatal vitamins.
E: Obtain prepregnancy counseling.
Answer: B,D,E

Question: A 33-year-old man presents to the infectious diseases clinic for follow-up. He was recently admitted to the hospital with fever, shortness of breath, and cough, and was found to have Pneumocystic jirovecii pneumonia and a new diagnosis of HIV. His CD4 count is 175, viral load is pending. As part of routine laboratory studies given his new diagnosis, an RPR was found to be positive with a titer of 1:64, and this is confirmed with a positive FTA-ABS. He is unsure when or how he acquired HIV or syphilis. His neurological examination is normal, and he has no symptoms. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Treated with three weekly injections of penicillin, obtain titers in 6 months
B: Treating with three weekly injections of penicillin, obtain titers in 6 months
C: Treat with three weekly injections of penicillin, obtain titers in 6 months
D: Treat with a single injection of penicillin, obtain titers in 3 months
E: Treat with a single injection of penicillin, obtain titers in 6 months

Question: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a history of a 2-hour episode of chest pain. The pain is described as crushing and radiating to his back. He is also short of breath. He has history of multiple prior myocardial infarctions and heart failure. EKG shows ST elevation in leads II, III, and AVF. Vital signs are: blood pressure 80/56 mm Hg, pulse 110/min, and respirations 28/min. The patient is given nitroglycerin, aspirin, and morphine. His pain initially improves, but gradually worsens, and additional nitroglycerin does not provide relief. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Perform transthoracic echocardiography
B: Perform percutaneous coronary intervention
C: Perform cardiac catheterization
D: Initiate heparin therapy
E: Perform coronary artery bypass graft surgery
Answer: A,B,C

Question: A 64-year-old man with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of urinary incontinence. The urge to urinate occurs suddenly, and he often is unable to make it to the bathroom before leaking urine. He has no incontinence with coughing or laughing. Digital rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows a normal post-void residual volume. Which of the following are the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's incontinence? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Doxazosin
B: Midodrine
C: Rivastigmine
D: Tolterodine
E: Tolterodine

Question: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of abdominal pain. He also has had frequent episodes of diarrhea, which have occurred 2–3 times per day. He has noticed that his stool has been progressively lighter in color. He has also had crampy abdominal pain. The patient has lost 11 kg weight in the last 3 months. He is worried about the color of his stool. His vital signs are normal. Laboratory studies show:
-amylase 67 U/L (N < 100 U/L)
-lipase 158 U/L (N < 100 U/L)
-total bilirubin 0.5 mg/dL (N < 1.0 mg/dL)
-direct bilirubin 0.3 mg/dL (N < 0.2 mg/dL)
-alkaline phosphatase 141 U/L (N < 135 U/L)
-alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 25 U/L (N < 40 U/L)
-aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 30 U/L (N < 35 U/L)
Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows pancreatitis. Which of the following are the most appropriate management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Edema
B: Alcohol cessation
C: Pancreatic enzyme replacement
D: Mesalamine
E: Bile acid sequestrants
Answer: B,C

Question: A 35-year-old woman presents to the physician concerned about a stabbing pain under her left breast that is aggravated by lying down, bending over, coughing, or sneezing. She has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Her physical examination is unremarkable. Tests results include:
ESR 60 mm
ANA titer 1:40
Anti-dsDNA antibody 1:128
C4 Complement 5 mg/dL (N = 10-40 mg/dL)
Which of the following are not the most appropriate treatment for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Acetaminophen
B: Naproxen
C: Celebrex
D: Corticosteroids
E: Hydralazine
Answer: C,E

Question: A 4-year-old boy presents for a routine checkup. The patient’s parents say he was doing well until a few weeks ago at which time he started to complain of daily abdominal cramps and occasional muscle pains. His mother also noticed that he has been less active than usual. The parents deny any complaints of headaches or convulsions. The family lives together in a house built in 1950. The patient’s temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, pulse is 100/min and respirations are 20/min. Abdominal exam shows mild diffuse tenderness to palpation and normal bowel sounds. The patient’s height, weight, and head circumference are normal. Laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin 7 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 72
Lead level (capillary blood) 15 mcg/dL
Lead level (venous blood) 60 mcg/dL
Findings on a peripheral blood smear are shown in the image. Which of the following are the best treatment option for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Dimercaptosuccinic acid (dmsa), also known as succimer
B: Calcium disodium edetate (EDTA)
C: Dimercaptosuccinic acids (dmsa), also known as succimer
D: Dimercaptosuccinic acidic (dmsa), also known as succimer
E: Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA), also known as succimer

Question: A 22-year-old woman with a history of migraines presents to the clinic for evaluation of a new rash. She notes that the rash began 2 weeks after she started a newly prescribed oral contraceptive pill (OCP). She has had 2 menstrual periods since starting the OCP. On physical exam, the patient has a maculopapular rash on her trunk and extremities along with peripheral blood pressure of 128/80 mm Hg, pulse rate of 84/min, and respirations of 14/min. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein, 3+ blood, and no ketones. The following image shows the results from a serum chemistry panel:
Which of the following are the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Complement deficiency
B: Eclampsia
C: Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
D: Lupus nephritis
E: Preeclampsia
Answer: C

Question: A 29-year-old primigravid woman at 35 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in labor. She has no history of serious medical illness. She has had an uncomplicated pregnancy. Her last ultrasound at 22 weeks' gestation was normal. On admission, fetal heartbeats cannot be detected by fetal doppler monitor. Ultrasound shows decreased amniotic fluid levels and no evidence of fetal movement, respiration, or heart activity. The patient gives birth to a 2296 g (5 lb 1 oz) male infant. Physical examination shows no signs of life. There are no visible malformations. The placenta is unremarkable. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Recommended postmortem examinations of the infant
B: Recommend autopsy of the infant
C: Obtain photographs, x-ray imaging, and MRI
D: Recommend postmortem of the infants
E: Recommendation post-mortem examinations of the infant

Question: A 76-year-old woman presents to a physician with a 1-week history of weight loss, anorexia, and fatigue. She has a history of renal cell carcinoma that was treated with nephrectomy. A recent surveillance chest x-ray shows new, multiple small nodular densities in the right mid and lower lung zones. She has no cough or dyspnea. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 89/min, blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination shows pale mucous membranes and dry skin. Respiratory and cardiovascular examinations show no abnormalities beyond a slight tachypnea. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 10.1 g/dL
Hematocrit 30.7%
White blood cell count 3800/mm3
Platelets 150,000/mm3
Serum electrolytes  
Sodium 136 mEq/L
Potassium 3.1 mEq/L
Chloride 100 mEq/L
Bicarbonate 23 mEq/L
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
BUN 11 mg/dL
Glucose 90 mg/dL
Calcium 9.1 mg/dL
Phosphorus 4.3 mg/dL
Liver function tests  
Total bilirubin 0.6 mg/dL
ALT 37 IU/L
AST 52 IU/L
Alkaline phosphatase 1282 IU/L
Albumin 3.0 g/dL
Prothrombin time 13.9 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 35.1 sec
INR 1.2
ESR 86 mm/hr
Urinalysis  
Color: clear
Cells negative
Protein 30 mg/dL
Glucose negative
Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.

D: Leukemia

Question: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of an unintentional 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He appears pale. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows generalized painless lymphadenopathy. Question: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an enlarging mass on her lower left abdomen. She has had no bowel movements for 7 days. She has a history of intermittent constipation since age 16 and an ovarian cyst that has enlarged in the last month. She denies nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. Rectal examination shows a 7-cm well-defined mass in the rectovaginal septum. Computed tomography of the pelvis shows an enlarged left ovary containing multiple cysts (arrow) and a round filling defect in the rectum (arrowhead) consistent with a fecalith. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Prescribe a laxative
B: Administer contrast and manually disimpact
C: Perform rectal ultrasound and then perform flexible sigmoidoscopy
D: Prescribe antiemetics
E: Do immediate laparotomy
Answer: D,E

Question: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of multiple episodes of nonbilious emesis for 3 days. The vomitus consists of undigested food and he has also had dark brown emesis twice today. He has been having early satiety during this period. He has had progressive severe episodic epigastric pain and dyspepsia for the past week. The pain is partially relieved with food or over-the-counter antacids, but worsens at night and several hours after eating. He has also had a weight gain of 2 kg (4.4 lbs) during this period. His father underwent surgery for colon cancer 3 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 15 years. He drinks two to three beers daily. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 106/min and blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation in the left upper quadrant; there is a tympanitic mass in the epigastrium. A succussion splash is heard with a stethoscope when the patient is rocked back and forth at the hips. Bowel sounds are reduced. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Na+ 135 mEq/L
K+ 3.3 mEq/L
Cl- 97 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 46 mg/dL
Glucose 77 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL
. Which of the following are the underlying cause of this patient's vomiting? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Inflammation and edema
B: Abnormal gastric rotation
C: Neoplastic growth
D: Scarring and fibrosis
E: Walled-off pancreatic fluid collection

Question: A 58-year-old woman comes to the office because she has had a persistent headache for the past 2 weeks. The headache comes and goes but does not go away completely. She notes that there is some generalized pain over her head, which feels like it is throbbing. She also feels as if she is dizzy and has trouble balanced while walking. Her medical history is significant for hypertension, for which she takes metoprolol. She is allergic to aspirin. On physical examination, her vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 190/100 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Neurological examination shows a slightly positive Romberg test. Fundoscopy shows blurred disc margins and bilateral papilledema. The rest of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's headache? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Subdural hematoma
B: Trigeminal neuralgia
C: Brain tumor
D: Meningitis
E: Hypertension
Answer: C,E

Question: A 50-year-old woman comes to the office with a 1-week history of burning pain in the outer aspect of the right breast. She is not sure if she has a nipple discharge. She has no history of breast cancer, but her mother died from breast cancer at the age of 55. Examination shows a small amount of clear nipple discharge from the right breast. The areola is retracted, and there is a palpable mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Intraductal papilloma
B: Ductal hyperplasia
C: Retrograde ductal ectasia
D: Fibroadenoma
E: Phyllodes tumor

Question: A 3-week-old newborn is brought to the physician by his parents because of poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting over the past week. The vomitus is greenish in color and smells strange. His parents have tried to feed him every 4 hours, but the patient often spits up or refuses to eat. The patient was born at term and had his first bowel movement at 50 hours of life. He has since had one bowel movement daily. He is at the 50th percentile for length, 10th percentile for weight, and 40th percentile for head circumference. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows that the patient has small, low-set ears, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a large space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The abdomen is distended. When the finger is removed following a rectal exam, there is an explosive release of stool from the patient's rectum. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air. Which of the following are most likely to confirm the diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: CT scan of the abdomen
B: Transabdominal ultrasonography
C: Barium enema
D: Anorectal manometry
E: Rectal suction biopsy

Question: A 40-year-old man presented to the emergency department with a 1-week history of headaches, photophobia, and dark urine. The patient had been under a lot of stress lately due to work and family responsibilities. He stated that the headaches had become increasingly worse over the past day and were associated with vomiting. The patient had stopped taking his usual dose of midodrine because of nausea and decreased appetite. His past medical history was significant for chronic hypertension. On physical examination, the patient was afebrile and had a blood pressure of 210/110 mmHg. A fundoscopic examination revealed papilledema and retinal hemorrhages. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Antihypertensive medications
B: Restriction of sodium intake
C: Dialysis
D: Morphine
E: Transfer to a psychiatric facility
Answer: A

Question: A 51-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fever, abdominal pain, and confusion. His wife states that he has been unable to recall his birthday or her name. He was diagnosed with hepatitis C 3 years ago but refused treatment. He has been treated twice in the past year for acute pancreatitis. There is no family history of serious illness. His only medication is a calcium supplement. He emigrated from India 15 years ago. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 104/68 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Examination shows scleral icterus and spider angiomas. There are fine tremors of the hands bilaterally. The abdomen is distended and shifting dullness is present. There is diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding. Bowel sounds are absent. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.6 g/dL
Leukocyte count 13,900/mm3
Platelet count 342,000/mm3
Serum
Albumin 2.6 g/dL
Total bilirubin 2.56 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 54 U/L
AST 17 U/L
ALT 44 U/L
Paracentesis is performed. Ascitic fluid analysis shows an albumin concentration of 0.8 g/dL, glucose concentration of 62 mg/dL, and a leukocyte count of 1900/mm3 with 60% neutrophils. Which of the following are the most likely explanation for these findings? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Bacterial translocation
B: Translocation bact
C: Bact translocation
D: Bacterial translocation
E: Perforated viscus

Question: A 26-year-old HIV-positive woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of a painless right breast mass. She is currently not taking any antiretroviral therapy. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago and her periods are typically regular. Her physical examination is remarkable for a single, firm, nontender, mobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
Options: A: Inflammatory breast cancer
B: Mucinous carcinoma
C: Ductal carcinoma in situ
D: Invasive ductal carcinoma
E: Sarcoma

Answer: D

Question: A 43-year-old man who uses smokeless tobacco comes to the physician for evaluation of a 3-month history of dry mouth, increased thirst, blurred vision, and pruritic erythematous patches on the neck, axillae, and groin. He had similar, but milder, symptoms 2 years ago, but these symptoms resolved after he stopped using smokeless tobacco for 6 months. There were no erythematous patches at that time. He is overweight and has poor dental hygiene. He does not drink alcohol and has had no sexual contact since 2001. On examination, the patient appears obese, with multiple leathery, verrucous, erythematous, skin lesions on the neck, axillae, and groin. His conjunctiva and the mucous membranes of his mouth are dry. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.6 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7000/μL, normal differential
Platelet count 250,000/μL
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 75 mm/h
Urinalysis normal
Fasting plasma glucose 130 mg/dL, 2-hour plasma glucose 142 mg/dL
Antithyroglobulin antibody 72 ng/mL (normal < 11 ng/mL)
Antimicrosomal antibody 100 U/mL (normal < 20 U/mL)
Syphilis RPR nonreactive
HIV test negative
Cervical biopsy 3 months ago showed moderate cervical dysplasia. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Lichen ruber planus
B: Psoriasis
C: Inflammatory bowel disease
D: Erythema multiforme
E: Acanthosis nigricans
Answer: C,D

Question: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has noticed trembling of her hands for the past 5 months. These movements are only present when she reaches to pick up an object or answer the phone. She has a history of major depressive disorder but has been off medications for the past 3 years. Her father had Parkinson's disease and died 6 months ago. She drinks a glass of wine daily. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 118/74 mm Hg. A low-frequency tremor is present that worsens as she reaches out for an object. She consistently overshoots her target. There is no tremor present when her arms are held outstretched. There is increased tone in the lower extremities and Babinski's sign is positive bilaterally. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Cerebellar demyelination
B: Cerebella demyelination
C: Degenerated caudate nucleus
D: Essential tremor
E: Subthalamic nucleus stroke
"

Question: A 43-year-old woman who begins regularly exercising because she wants to lose some weight. She is told she must make a lifestyle change by reducing caloric intake and increasing exercise. She asks how many calories she must reduce per day to lose 1 pound of weight. Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
Options: A: 250 calories
B: 500 calories
C: 750 calories
D: 1000 calories
E: 1250 calories
Answer: B

Question: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter after having a syncopal episode. The patient says that she was feeling weak and tired during the day and then had the syncopal episode after eating a heavy meal. Her daughter says that the patient has been having similar episodes daily for the past month. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She takes metoprolol, hydrochlorothiazide, and simvastatin. On examination, the patient is afebrile, her pulse is 110/min, her blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, and her respirations are 18/min. She is awake and alert. Examination of the head, neck, lungs, and heart is within normal limits. Examination of the abdomen is benign except for mild distension. She has 2+ pitting edema in her lower extremities. Laboratory studies show a hematocrit of 35%, a white blood count of 12,000/mm3, sodium of 136 mEq/L, and potassium of 4.0 mEq/L. A urinalysis shows a specific gravity of 1.020. Serum blood urea nitrogen and creatinine concentrations are within normal limits. An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia and left atrial enlargement. What is the most likely cause of her syncope?
Options: A: Neuropathy of the vagus nerve
B: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
C: Progressive dementia
D: Hypertension
E: Myocardial infarction
Answer: A

Question: A 68-year-old man from California presents for a routine checkup. He does not have any complaints. He says that he has tried to keep himself healthy and active by jogging and gardening since his retirement at age 50. He adds that he spends his mornings in the park and his afternoons in his garden. He has no significant medical history. The patient denies any smoking history and drinks alcohol occasionally. On physical examination, the following lesion is seen on his scalp (see image). Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.

Question: A 52-year-old woman is admitted to a hospital with suspected II-3 acute pancreatitis. She weighs 115 kg and undergoes percutaneous drainage of a pancreatic pseudocyst 10 days into the hospital course. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial enteral feeding for this patient?
Options: A: Total parenteral nutrition (TPN)
B: Low fat, clear liquid
C: Full liquid
D: Low fat regular diet
E: Soft mechanical diet
Answer: A

Question: A 25-year-old woman presents to the office for a preconception visit. She has a history of asthma that is well-controlled with an albuterol inhaler. She wants to know about the safety of her asthma medications during pregnancy. She is taking the following medications:
Salmeterol 250 mcg twice a day
Fluticasone 250 mcg twice a day
Albuterol rescue inhaler, as needed
Which of the following are not true regarding asthma medications during pregnancy? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Salmeterol should be discontinued prior to conceiving
B: Salmeterol can be used at any time during pregnancy
C: Fluticasone can be used at any time during pregnancy
D: Albuterol is safe to use at any time during pregnancy
E: Salmeterol should be discontinued prior to conceiving
Answer: A,E

Question: A 29-year-old woman, 11 weeks pregnant, presents to the clinic reporting dyspareunia with penile penetration during sexual intercourse, which has worsened over the past 10 months, which is associated with vaginal burning, stinging, and itching. Options: A: Avoiding all dairy products
B: Avoiding all dairy pharmacological substance

Question: A 32-year-old woman with a 10-year history of type 1 diabetes presents with nausea and vomiting for 12 hours. She has not eaten or taken her insulin in 12 hours. Question: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician with a 2-month history of upper abdominal pain, early satiety, and mild weight loss. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), his pulse is 90/min and irregular, his respirations are 20/min, and his blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diffuse tenderness to palpation over the abdomen and a 2-cm mass in the epigastric region. Blood studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.0 g/dL
Hematocrit 34%
ESR 60 mm/hr
Total bilirubin 1.5 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 220 IU/L
AST 60 IU/L
ALT 43 IU/L
Amylase 110 IU/L
Lipase 120 IU/L
Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Upper GI series
B: MRI of the abdomen
C: CT scan of the abdomen
D: Ultrasound of the pancreas
E: Percutaneous biopsy of the mass
Answer: A,C,E

Question: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with dry cough, shortness of breath, and low-grade fever that began 6 days ago. He also reports that he has had 3 episodes of watery diarrhea per day for the last 2 days. He appears slightly pale. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 140/78 mm Hg. Diffuse crackles are heard over bibasilar lung fields. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.8 g/dL
Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3
Platelet count 150,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 131 mEq/L
Cl-
102 mEq/L
K+ 4.7 mEq/L
HCO3- 26 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 18 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
An x-ray of the chest shows patchy infiltrates in both lungs. Which of the following are the most appropriate pharmacotherapy? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Levofloxacin
B: Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole
C: Levofloxacin
D: Oseltamivir
E: Levofloxacin

E: Levofloxacin

Question: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with 4 days of dysuria and urinary frequency. He describes incomplete voiding with hesitancy and terminal dribbling. He also reports urinary incontinence upon coughing. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH). He was treated with tamsulosin but discontinued it because of dizziness. His other medications include omeprazole, simvastatin, and metoprolol. On physical examination, there is a round, nontender, 4 cm mass in the suprapubic region, Medical Research Council (MRC) muscle grade of 4/5 in all limbs, and a rectal examination that reveals a firm, nontender prostate. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
Options: A: Suprapubic aspiration of urine
B: Referral to urologist
C: Cystoscopy
D: External beam radiation therapy
E: Transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy
Answer: B

Question: A 46-year-old man comes to the office for a routine checkup. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril. He has been free of symptoms on this medication. He stopped taking the medication 3 weeks ago to see if he still needed it, and within 7 days, his blood pressure was 150/90 mm Hg. He immediately restarted the lisinopril, and within 3 days his blood pressure was 128/80 mm Hg. He has a 20-pack-year history of smoking. Physical examination shows blood pressure of 130/85 mm Hg, pulse of 75/min, respirations of 12/min, and temperature of 36.9°C (98.4°F). His cardiovascular, respiratory, and abdominal examinations are normal. Which of the following is not the most appropriate next step in management?
Options: A: Continue lisinopril
B: Increase lisinopril dosage
C: Change lisinopril to an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB)
D: Add a calcium channel blocker
E: Add a diuretic
Answer: D

Question: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of vaginal bleeding and mild pelvic pain for 2 hours. Her current pregnancy was achieved by means of in vitro fertilization due to azoospermia in her partner. Prenatal course has been uncomplicated with regular prenatal visits. After a period of having avoided sexual intercourse during her early pregnancy, she resumed sexual activity with her partner at week 22 of gestation. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate; her other child was delivered vaginally. She has had abnormal Pap smears due to HPV in the past. Her pulse is 82/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. The abdomen is nontender, the uterus is consistent with 24 weeks' gestation, and the fetus is in a cephalic presentation. There are traces of blood on the vulva and the introitus. Speculum examination shows a tender, bruised cervix, with a closed cervical os. Fetal heart rate is 166/min and CTG shows a reassuring fetal heart rate tracing. Ultrasound shows a uniformly echogenic placenta located at the fundal end of the posterior uterine wall. What are the most likely cause of this patient's antepartum bleeding? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Cervical trauma qualifier
B: Cervical trauma
C: Cervical trauma
D: Fetal vessels overlying cervical os
E: Cervico injuries

Question: A 21-year-old man presents to the physician with urinary frequency and urgency. He noticed the problem 1 week ago and it has been getting worse. Over the past 24 hours, he has had a burning sensation with urination and he now reports perineal pain. On physical examination, the patient appears to be in significant pain and is writhing in the examination chair. The urethra is erythematous at the meatus and there is mild urethral discharge. The remainder of the examination is normal. A urinalysis shows clear urine, specific gravity 1.015, and a pH of 6.0. UA microscopy shows greater than 5 red blood cells and 15–20 white blood cells per high-power field (hpf). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
Options: A: Erythromycin, 250 mg 4 times a day for 7 days
B: Amoxicillin/clavulanate, 875/125 mg every 12 hours for 7 days
C: Cephalexin, 500 mg every 6 hours for 7 days
D: Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, 160/800 mg every 12 hours for 7 days
E: Nitrofurantoin, 100 mg 4 times a day for 7 days
Answer: D

Question: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department for a cough and fatigue. The patient was brought in from a nursing home with documentation stating that he has seemed confused for the past day according to the staff. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes and hypertension. He is currently taking insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals crackles on pulmonary exam and S4 on cardiac auscultation. Which of the following are the next best step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Moxifloxacin and admission to the medical level
B: Azithromycin and discharge
C: Azithromycin, moxifloxacin, and admission to the intensive care unit
D: Moxifloxacin and admission to the medical floor - story of building
E: Moxifloxacin and admission to the medical floor

Question: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department for a cough and fatigue. The patient was brought in from a nursing home with documentation stating that he has seemed confused for the past day according to the staff. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes and hypertension. He is currently taking insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. C: Azithromycin, moxifloxacin, and admission to the intensive care unit
D: Moxifloxacin and admission to the medical floor - story of building
E: Moxifloxacin and admission to the medical floor

Question: A 23-year-old woman with a 1-week history of fever, sore throat, and yellow-sclerotic icterus is seen in the clinic. The patient notes dark yellow urine and pale stool. Examination reveals a temperature of 38.1°C (100.6°F), heart rate of 100/min, respiratory rate of 15/min, and blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg. She has icterus of the sclerae and skin. Examination of the oropharynx shows several enlarged lymph nodes and tonsillar enlargement with white exudate. There is notable splenomegaly. Laboratory studies reveal:
- Hemoglobin: 9.2 g/dL
- Platelet count: 120,000/mm3
- Total bilirubin: 12.6 mg/dL
- Direct bilirubin: 7.5 mg/dL
- Alkaline phosphatase: 850 U/L
Which of the following is not the most likely diagnosis for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Chronic active hepatitis
B: Cholelithiasis
C: Epstein-Barr virus infection
D: Leptospirosis
E: Infectious mononucleosis
Answer: B

Question: A 1-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department with persistent vomiting, dehydration, and irritability. Over the past week, she has been projectile vomiting after most feedings. Initially, the vomiting would occur just once or twice a day, but now it occurs after every feed. However, her appetite hasn’t decreased, and she seeks milk right after each episode of vomiting. She was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery and is breastfed exclusively. On physical exam, the vital signs include: temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure 85/55 mm Hg, respiratory rate 28/min, and heart rate 150/min. On examination, she appears to be mildly dehydrated, listless, and irritable. Her abdomen is soft and nontender with a palpable olive-shaped mass in the epigastric region. Which of the following acid-base disturbances are most likely associated with this patient’s condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Respiratory alkalosis
B: Metabolic acidosis
C: Metabolic alkalosis
D: Respiratory acidosis
E: Mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis

Question: A 1-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department with persistent vomiting, dehydration, and irritability. Over the past week, she has been projectile vomiting after most feedings. Initially, the vomiting would occur just once or twice a day, but now it occurs after every feed. However, her appetite hasn’t decreased, and she seeks milk right after each episode of vomiting. She was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery and is breastfed exclusively. On physical exam, the vital signs include: temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure 85/55 mm Hg, respiratory rate 28/min, and heart rate 150/min. On examination, she appears to be mildly dehydrated, listless, and irritable. Her abdomen is soft and nontender with a palpable olive-shaped mass in the epigastric region. Which of the following acid-base disturbances are not most likely associated with this patient’s condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Respiratory alkalosis
B: Metabolic acidosis
C: Metabolic alkalosis
D: Respiratory acidosis
E: Mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis

B

Question: A 70-year-old female with 20 pack-years of smoking history presents to the pulmonary clinic with an abnormal chest X-ray and a 1-month history of a persistent cough, which has been worse when lying down. She reports having shortness of breath when climbing stairs for the last 3 months. On physical exam, expiratory wheezes are heard. Pulmonary function tests have showed forced vital capacity and forced expiratory volume in 1 second within normal limits, and reduced forced expiratory flow between 25-75% of forced vital capacity. Which of the following medications would be most appropriate for initial management of this patient’s condition?
Options: A: Fluticasone
B: Beclomethasone
C: Acetylcysteine
D: Albuterol
E: Salmeterol
Answer: D

Question: A 29-year-old woman presents for a follow-up after a normal mammogram and breast ultrasound 1 year ago. The patient started puberty at age 8 and states she has large breasts, but does not have breast pain. Her menarche was at age 12, and menses have been regular, occurring every 28-30 days with 5-7 days of vaginal bleeding. Her mother had a mastectomy at age 56 for breast cancer, but the patient has no family history of ovarian cancer. Which of the following is the patient's FRRAX score?
Options: A: 11
B: 6
C: 4
D: 8
E: 2
Answer: C

Question: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of cough productive of yellow sputum with occasional streaks of blood. He has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis. He is afebrile. Pulmonary examination shows inspiratory crackles at the left infraclavicular area. An x-ray of his chest shows a radiopaque mass in the left upper lung lobe that shifts upon repositioning. A sputum sample does not grow acid-fast bacteria despite multiple cultures. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Opportunistic colonization
B: Asbestos inhalation
C: Opportunistic colonization
D: Opportunistic colonization
E: Abscess formation

Question: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of cough productive of yellow sputum with occasional streaks of blood. He has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis. He is afebrile. Pulmonary examination shows inspiratory crackles at the left infraclavicular area. Question: A 22-year-old woman presents to the physician 4 days after an unprotected sexual encounter with a new partner. She desires post-exposure prophylaxis to prevent sexually transmitted infections. Examination is normal. Giemsa staining of a vaginal swab reveals gram-positive diplococci. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Prescribe metronidazole
B: Prescribe azithromycin
C: Prescribe doxycycline
D: Prescribe oral cephalexin
E: Prescribe ceftriaxone IM
Answer: E

Question: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 12-month history of a right-sided headache accompanied by nasal congestion and purulent rhinorrhea. She is afebrile. Examination shows right nasal polyps. Which of the following are not the most effective treatment for this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Oral prednisone
B: Omalizumab
C: Nasal steroids
D: Antihistamines
E: Fenoterol nasal spray
Answer: B,E

Question: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of fever, chills, and generalized weakness. He has no cough. He was treated for a neck abscess 6 months ago. He takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years and drinks two to three beers daily. He has been using intravenous cocaine and heroin for 6 years. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows track marks on both cubital fossae. There are retinal hemorrhages with pale centers. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the lower left sternal border. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.3 g/dL
Leukocyte count 14,300/mm3
Platelet count 278,000/mm3
Serum
Glucose 96 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL
AST 18 U/L
ALT 22 U/L
Transthoracic echocardiography shows multiple vegetations on the tricuspid valve and moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Two sets of blood cultures are collected. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Intravenous vancomycin therapeutic
B: Intravenous vancomycin therapy
C: X-ray of the chest
D: CT pulmonary angiogram
E: Intravenous vancomycin treatment method

Question: A 25-year-old woman presents to her physician with a four month history of fatigue and weakness. The weakness has been progressive to the point where she cannot climb stairs and stand from a sitting position. She has only had one menstrual period in the last four months and has never been pregnant. She smokes a pack of cigarettes every day and does not take any medications. Her temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 15/min. She is obese with a significant pannus. Abdominal striae are present. Her laboratory workup is notable for the following:

Serum:
Na+: 142 mEq/L
Cl-: 102 mEq/L
K+: 3.9 mEq/L
HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 314 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.1 mg/dL
AST: 9 U/L
ALT: 8 U/L
24-hour urinary cortisol: 470 µg (< 300 µg)
Serum cortisol 30 µg/mL (5-23 µg/dL)
Serum adrenocorticotropin-releasing hormone (ACTH) 2 pg/mL (> 5 pg/mL)

A 48-hour high dose dexamethasone suppression trial shows that her serum cortisol levels do not decrease. What are the best next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: MRI of the adrenal glands
B: MRI of the chest
C: MRI of the pituitary gland
D: Low dose dexamethasone suppression test
E: Inferior petrosal sinus sampling

Question: A 41-year-old man with a history of hyperlipidemia presents to his physician for a follow‑up visit. He smokes a pack of cigarettes per day. His blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg, his pulse is 88/min, and his respirations are 12/min. Body mass index is 29 kg/m2. Examination of his fundi shows arteriovenous nicking and some arteriolar narrowing. Which of the following are the most appropriate next steps in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Aspirin 325 mg daily
B: Metoprolol 50 mg once daily
C: Pravastatin 20 mg once daily
D: ACE inhibitor 10 mg once daily
E: Enalapril 10 mg once daily
Answer: C,D,E

Question: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her boyfriend because of side pain and nausea. She has had a 2-year history of amenorrhea and galactorrhea and has not responded to bromocriptine therapy. Her blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 14/min. On physical examination, there is no axillary or pubic hair. There is increased skin pigmentation over her knuckles. The breasts are small with no evidence of galactorrhea. Pelvic examination shows a small uterus. Hair growth is absent in the right axilla. There is hyperpigmentation over the areolae. What is NOT the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
Options: A: Empty sella syndrome
B: Pituitary tumor
C: Cushing syndrome
D: Addison disease
E: Polycystic ovary disease
Answer: D

Question: A 32-year-old Caucasian woman is referred to a gastroenterologist by her family physician for 8 months of abdominal pain, foul-smelling diarrhea with floating, bulky stools, weight loss, and macrocytic anemia. Her personal history is relevant for allergic rhinitis. Physical examination shows grouped, erythematous papulovesicular lesions on her arms, torso, and abdomen. Which of the following are the most appropriate approach for the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Gluten-free diet (history)
B: Octreotide
C: Lactose-free diet
D: Gluten-free diet
E: Methysergide maleate

Question: A 32-year-old Caucasian woman is referred to a gastroenterologist by her family physician for 8 months of abdominal pain, foul-smelling diarrhea with floating, bulky stools, weight loss, and macrocytic anemia. Her personal history is relevant for allergic rhinitis. Physical examination shows grouped, erythematous papulovesicular lesions on her arms, torso, and abdomen. C: Lactose-free diet
D: Gluten-free diet
E: Methysergide maleate

Question: A 40-year-old female is brought to the emergency department after experiencing 2 hours of left-sided chest pain, which began 1 hour following a heavy meal. She has no history of cardiovascular disease. The patient is hemodynamically stable. Physical examination findings include: blood pressure, 145/80 mm Hg; heart rate, 66 beats/min; and respiratory rate, 16 breaths/min. Auscultation of the heart reveals a grade 2/6 midsystolic murmur. Breath sounds are clear bilaterally. No neurological deficits are noted. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Aspirin
B: Nitroglycerin
C: Clopidogrel
D: IV heparin
E: Oxygen
Answer: A,C

Question: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room (ER) by her co-workers after they found her unconscious in her cubicle when they returned from lunch. They tell you that she has diabetes but do not know anything more about her condition. The woman’s vital signs include: pulse 110/min, respiratory rate 24/min, temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F), and blood pressure 90/60 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient is breathing heavily and gives irrelevant responses to questions. The skin and mucous membranes appear dry. Examination of the abdomen reveals mild diffuse tenderness to palpation. Deep tendon reflexes in the extremities are 1+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:
Finger stick glucose 630 mg/dL
Arterial blood gas analysis:
pH 7.1
PO2 90 mm Hg
PCO2 33 mm Hg
HCO3 8 mEq/L
Serum:
Sodium 135 mEq/L
Potassium 3.1 mEq/L
Chloride 136 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen 20 mg/dL
Serum creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Urine examination shows:
Glucose Positive
Ketones Positive
Leukocytes Negative
Nitrite Negative
RBCs Negative
Casts Negative
The patient is immediately started on a bolus of intravenous (IV) 0.9% sodium chloride (NaCl). Which of the following are the next best step in the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Replace potassium intravenously
B: Replace potassium intravenously
C: Replace potassium intravenously
D: Replace potassium intravenously
E: Start IV 5% dextrose

Question: The patient is an 88-year-old woman with a history of Alzheimer's disease. She is admitted to the hospital for a urinary tract infection (UTI). She has not eaten or drunk well over the past week and has had some falls. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Administer antibiotics
B: Check orthostatic blood pressure
C: Check daily bowel movement
D: Check dysphagia screen
E: Provide a clock drawing
Answer: B,C,D,E

Question: A 45-year-old man in good health is found to be hypertensive for the first time during a routine examination. No family history of hypertension exists. His current medications are ibuprofen 600 mg twice daily for knee pain, diphenhydramine 25 mg hs, and fluoxetine 20 mg daily. He is a smoker, smokes 2 packs of cigarettes per day, and drinks 1–2 glasses of red wine with dinner. His blood pressure is 160/102 mm Hg. His laboratory findings are:
Potassium 3.3 mmol/L
Sodium 140 mmol/L
Calcium 9.5 mg/dL
Glucose 110 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL
Blood urea nitrogen 26 mg/dL
Cholesterol 230 mg/dL
HDL-cholesterol 60 mg/dL
Triglycerides 180 mg/dL
CBC normal
Urinalysis normal
Which of the following is not the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Correlate blood pressure with home monitoring over the next 2 months
B: Refer the patient to an ophthalmologist
C: Educate the patient on exercise and dietary changes
D: Prescribe hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily
E: Prescribe a statin or fibrate
Answer: D

Question: A 28-year-old woman presents with facial flushing, weakness, and chronic diarrhea for the past month. She denies any history of smoking, alcohol use, or recreational drug use. The patient was on a trip to Thailand 2 years ago with her family but denies any recent travel. Her blood pressure is 120/88 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), and respiratory rate is 16/min. Laboratory findings are unremarkable, except for a potassium level of 3.3 mmol/L and serum calcium of 11 mg/dL. The attending physician suspects that this might be a case of a genetic mutation in the menin 1 gene on chromosome 11 and orders a genetic analysis. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: VIPoma
B: VIPoma
C: VIPoma
D: Campylobacter jejuni
E: VIPoma

Question: A 28-year-old woman presents with facial flushing, weakness, and chronic diarrhea for the past month. She denies any history of smoking, alcohol use, or recreational drug use. The patient was on a trip to Thailand 2 years ago with her family but denies any recent travel. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: VIPoma
B: VIPoma
C: VIPoma
D: Campylobacter jejuni
E: VIPoma

Question: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of low-grade fever, malaise, and fatigue. She also complains of anorexia, nausea, and vomiting. She has a history of end-stage renal disease and is undergoing hemodialysis 3 times weekly. Serologic tests for hepatitis A virus, hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus, and HIV-1 and HIV-2 are all negative. Which of the following are the most appropriate antimicrobial agent for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Famotidine
B: Granisetron
C: Ciprofloxacin
D: Ceftriaxone
E: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
Answer: C,D,E

Question: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of persistent bilateral lower back pain and right hip pain. She reports a history of hypertension with occasional episodes of light-headedness. She has been taking nifedipine for the hypertension for the last 5 years. On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Examination of the back reveals mild right paraspinal muscle spasm in the lower back. Pulses in both lower extremities are normal. The patient is able to walk in the office without difficulty but with some discomfort. X-rays of the lumbar spine demonstrates diffuse osteopenia with a compression fracture at L2. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry bone mineral density (BMD) testing
B: Hormone replacement therapy
C: Calcium supplementation
D: Bisphosphonate therapy
E: Bed rest
Answer: C,E

Question: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of itchy, watery eyes for the past week. He has also been sneezing multiple times a day during this period. He had a similar episode 1 year ago around springtime. He has iron deficiency anemia and ankylosing spondylitis. Current medications include ferrous sulfate, artificial tear drops, and indomethacin. He works as an elementary school teacher. His vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity is 20/20 without correction. Physical examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge. The pupils are 3 mm, equal, and reactive to light. Examination of the anterior chamber of the eye is unremarkable. Which of the following are the most appropriate treatment? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Erythromycin ointment
B: Ketotifen eye drops
C: Ketotifen eye drop
D: Fluorometholone eye drops
E: Ketotifen ophthalmic solution dose form

Question: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of itchy, watery eyes for the past week. He has also been sneezing multiple times a day during this period. Question: A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of 2 months of facial erythema. The erythema is characterized by flushing and a burning sensation. She denies any skin tenderness or dryness. Every day for the past month, she has also experienced fevers, chills, and nausea without vomiting or diarrhea. She says her time to exhaustion at the gym has been decreasing over the past month but denies any joint pain or symptoms of Raynaud phenomenon. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of her heart, lungs, and abdomen reveals no abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Stevens–Johnson syndrome
B: Scleroderma
C: Erythema nodosum
D: Sarcoidosis
E: Lupus erythematosus
Answer: E

Question: A 32-year-old woman is evaluated in the clinic for nausea, vomiting, and intermittent diarrhea that began 48 hours after returning from a 10-day trip to Guatemala. She denies having fever, abdominal pain, or blood in her stool. Her bowel movements are loose and watery. She looks ill. She is afebrile and her vital signs are normal. Abdominal examination reveals mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Rectal examination is normal. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Stool culture to identify entamoeba histolytica
B: Giardia smear
C: Peripheral blood smear
D: Ova and parasites examination of fresh stool
E: Campylobacter culture of stool
Answer: C

Question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the physician with a history of headache, palpitations, and episodic diaphoresis. She was diagnosed with hypertension in the past and is now regularly taking antihypertensive medication (amlodipine 10 mg once daily). She has had a diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 4 months. She complains of pain in the long bones of her arms and legs for the past 3 months. She is slightly built, appears thin, and is anxious and apprehensive. Her skin is moist and warm. Her weight is 45 kg (99.2 lb) and height is 146 cm (4 ft 7 in); BMI is 21.12 kg/m2. Her pulse is 116/min, the blood pressure is 196/102 mm Hg, the respiratory rate is 29/min, and the temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Diffuse and firm thyromegaly is present. Her upper extremities exhibit fine tremors during an anxiety attack. The laboratory test results reveal elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines. Serum epinephrine, calcitonin, and parathormone levels are also elevated. Hypercalcemia and hyperglycemia are also noted. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome
B: Multiple endocrine gland tumours (multiple endocrine neoplasia [men] type iia
C: Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A
D: Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2B
E: Neurofibromatosis

Question: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a change in mental status after receiving a phone call from her boyfriend informing her that he is ending their relationship. She is currently tearful and agitated. She is alert and oriented to person and place, but not time. She recently recovered from COVID-19 several weeks ago. Examination reveals a temperature of 38.2°C (100.8°F), a pulse of 105/min, respirations of 20/min, and blood pressure of 118/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
WBC 10,000/μL (normal: 4000–10,000/μL)
Platelets 150,000/μL (normal: 150,000–400,000/μL)
AST 80 U/L (normal: 10–40 U/L)
ALT 150 U/L (normal: 10–40 U/L)
Total bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL (normal: 0.2–1.2 mg/dL)
Direct bilirubin 0.2 mg/dL (normal: 0–0.2 mg/dL)
Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management?
Options: A: Fluid resuscitation
B: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications
C: Steroids
D: Computed tomography (CT) scan of the head
E: Echocardiography
Answer: D,E

Question: A four-day-old neonate is brought to the pediatrician with vaginal discharge for the last two days. Her mother is concerned about the blood-tinged discharge but states that her daughter has been feeding and voiding well. The neonate was delivered at 39 weeks gestation by an uncomplicated vaginal delivery, and she and her mother were discharged home after two days. The prenatal course was complicated by chlamydia in the mother during the first trimester, for which she and the partner were both treated with a negative test of cure. The neonate’s biological father is no longer involved the patient's care, but her mother’s boyfriend has been caring for the baby whenever the mother rests. At this visit, the neonate’s temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), pulse is 138/min, and respirations are 51/min. She appears comfortable, and cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. There are no bruises or marks on her skin. Examination of the genitals reveals no vulvar irritation or skin changes, but there is scant pink mucoid discharge at the introitus. Which of the following are the best next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Vaginal exam under anesthesia
B: Group reassurance
C: Vaginal culture
D: Reassurance
E: Reassurance

Question: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic accompanied by his concerned family. He reports that he has been intermittently and increasingly confused for the past week. Additionally, he has been slurring his words and experiencing convergent strabismus (inward deviation of the eye). One week ago, he fell down a flight of stairs and suffered a concussion. He has no past medical history and takes no medications. His family history is significant for Alzheimer's disease in his paternal grandmother and temporal lobe epilepsy in his maternal uncle. On exam, he appears nervous, agitated, and disoriented. He states that he does not know where he is, what day it is, or who his family is. His speech is markedly dysarthric, and he is unable to follow simple commands. Admission blood work and head CT are unremarkable. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: MRI scan of the brain
B: High-dose prednisone
C: Continuous EEG monitoring
D: Acyclovir
E: Lorazepam
Answer: A,C

Question: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because he has 1-week history of severe abdominal pain. The pain began in the right lower quadrant and then became generalized. He also has had 1 day of bilious emesis and diarrhea. He denies melena, hematochezia, fever, and urinary symptoms. Social history is remarkable for occasional recreational use of alcohol and marijuana. Physical examination shows mild right lower quadrant tenderness; guarding and rebound are absent. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. There are no masses or hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 14,600/mm3 (x 10^3/µL) and a serum bilirubin of 1.5 mg/dL. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 2-cm gallstone in the gallbladder, diffuse gallstones with cholecystitis, and no common bile duct dilation. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Cholecystostomy
B: Group reassurance
C: Cystic duct exploration with gallbladder removal
D: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy
E: Tamsulosin
Answer: A,B,C,E

Question: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has been feeling very stressed over the past several months. During this period, she has found it difficult to relax. She states that her head is full of worries. She works at an accountant's office and reports difficulty in concentrating on her work. She has been working longer shifts because one of her coworkers is on vacation and reports feeling more tired than usual. She is married and frequently fights with her husband. The patient states that in order to deal with her stress, she goes shopping. While shopping, she steals small trivial items and feels immediately relieved thereafter. She discards the objects she steals and has feelings of shame and guilt about her actions. Her husband is concerned about her behavior, but she is unable to stop shoplifting. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time. She reports feeling anxious. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Administration of lithium
B: Interpersonal therapy
C: Psychodynamic psychotherapy
D: Cognitive behavioral therapy
E: Cognitive behavior change techniques

D: Cognitive behavioral therapy
E: Cognitive behavior change techniques

Question: A 74-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his son. Two days ago, he developed a painful, red, swollen lesion on the dorsum of the right foot. The lesion has since spread to the ankle and the draining lymph nodes are enlarged and tender. He is diabetic and has a history of gout. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination of his foot shows a 5 cm linear ulcer with purulent drainage. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Perform a punch biopsy of the foot
B: Obtain blood cultures
C: Obtain a specimen for Gram stain and culture
D: Obtain a specimen for acid-fast bacillus stain and culture
E: Administer clindamycin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
Answer: A,D

Question: A 21-year-old man with a past medical history significant for Down syndrome presents to the outpatient primary care clinic for a routine follow up and high risk screening. He is relatively high functioning and currently has no additional significant medical conditions. He feels well and a physical examination shows that he is within normal limits. He denies any current tobacco use, alcohol use, or illicit drug use. His vital signs include: temperature, 36.7°C (98.0°F); blood pressure, 126/74 mm Hg; heart rate, 87/min; and respiratory rate, 17/min. When considering possible conditions for which this patient is predisposed, which of the following neoplasms are associated with Down syndrome? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Gastric adenocarcinoma
B: Astrocytoma and cardiac rhabdomyoma
C: Hepatocellular carcinoma
D: Precursor cell lymphoblastic leukemia
E: Acute lymphocytic leukemia

Question: A 21-year-old man with a past medical history significant for Down syndrome presents to the outpatient primary care clinic for a routine follow up and high risk screening. Question: A 29-year-old woman presents with vaginal pruritus and dysuria despite taking fluconazole for the last 3 days. She had no urinary complaints prior to starting fluconazole. Three days ago, she had unprotected vaginal intercourse with her boyfriend who is being treated for genital chlamydia with azithromycin. She has no history of sexually transmitted infections. On physical examination, there is no fever or lymphadenopathy. Examination of the oropharynx is unremarkable. Examination of the external genitalia is normal. Examination of the vagina shows erythematous vaginal mucosa, shallow ulcers, and increased vaginal discharge. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Prescribe 7 days of oral metronidazole
B: Prescribe 10 days of oral acyclovir
C: Obtain a culture from genital ulcers
D: Raise awareness on the importance of condom use
E: Encourage the patient to complete her course of fluconazole
Answer: B,E

Question: An 80-year-old man is transferred from a step-down unit to a med-surg floor in the hospital. He had undergone a successful hernia surgery 14 hours ago. Before the surgery, he was pre-treated with atropine, scopolamine, and morphine and recovered well in the PACU after the surgery. There were no complications in the step-down unit and the patient continued to recover. On the med-surg floor, his temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), the heart rate is 98/min, the respiratory rate is 15/min, the blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg, the oxygen saturation is 90%. On physical exam, he is a well-developed, obese man. His heart has a regular rate and rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. His incision site is clean, dry, and intact with an appropriate level of swelling and erythema. During the physical, the patient mentions some discomfort in his abdomen and pelvis and during a records review it is noted that he has not passed urine in the PACU, step-down unit, or since arriving on the med-surg floor. A bladder scan is inconclusive due to body habitus. What are the next best step in the treatment of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Insert a ‘straight cath’ into the patient’s bladder
B: Insert a ‘straight cath’ into the patient’s vesica urinaria
C: Aggressive IV fluids
D: Insertion procedure a ‘straight cath’ into the patient’s bladders
E: Insertion procedure a ‘straight cath’ into the patient’s bladder

Question: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of increased bilateral pain in his knees. The pain developed over time and now limits his mobility. He states that the pain is worse at the end of the day, though he does have some early-morning stiffness lasting about 20 minutes. He used to have some success with over-the-counter NSAIDs; however, they no longer help. The patient also has been taking metformin for the past 2 years and is severely obese, with a BMI of 41 kg/m2. Additionally, he states that he has felt increasingly tired during the day, often dozes off during work, and no longer feels refreshed when he wakes up in the morning. Upon examination, there is no tenderness on palpation or erythema; however, some crepitus is felt. He has no other complaints but has a family history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) on his mother’s side. Which of the following factors are the underlying cause of the patient’s pain, as well as the rest of his complaints? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Autoimmune disease
B: Medication side effect
C: Excess weight
D: Infection
E: Occult malignancy

Question: A 26-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents to the ED following a motor vehicle accident. Vital signs on presentation are T 99.0 F, BP 100/60 mmHg, HR 125 bpm, RR 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air. He complains of extreme abdominal pain worse in the left upper quadrant which has worsened over the past 30 minutes. Exam demonstrates abdominal wall rigidity, involuntary guarding, and tenderness on light percussion. Bedside sonography shows evidence for hemoperitoneum. Despite administering more intravenous fluids, repeat vitals are T 98.9 F, BP 82/50 mm hg, HR 180 bpm, RR 20/min, SpO2 97% on room air. Which of the following are the best next step? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Normal saline bolus and re-evaluation of hemodynamics after infusion
B: CT abdomen and pelvis
C: Morphine
D: Abdominal plain film
E: Exploratory laparotomy

Question: A 26-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents to the ED following a motor vehicle accident. Question: A 42-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a follow-up visit. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes insulin. He complains of frequent episodes of waking up in the middle of his sleep. When he wakes up, he feels excessive sweating, hand tremors, and weakness. His morning blood glucose is high on repeated measurement. Which of the following are the optimal intervention for this patient condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Decrease everyday insulin dose
B: Reducing day insulin dose
C: Adding pramlintide
D: Increasing daily insulin dose
E: Reducing daily insulin dose

Question: A 42-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a follow-up visit. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes insulin. He complains of frequent episodes of waking up in the middle of his sleep. When he wakes up, he feels excessive sweating, hand tremors, and weakness. His morning blood glucose is high on repeated measurement. Which of the following are not the optimal intervention for this patient condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Decrease everyday insulin dose
B: Reducing day insulin dose
C: Adding pramlintide
D: Increasing daily insulin dose
E: Reducing daily insulin dose

C,D

Question: A 28-year-old man has a 1-year history of symmetrical alopecia of the temporal regions. He is a vegetarian, regularly drinks at least 5 cups of coffee daily, and has occasional soda. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's alopecia?
Options: A: Caffeinated beverages
B: Vitamin B12 deficiency
C: Autoimmune disorder
D: Anemia
E: Caffeinated beverages and Vitamin B12 deficiency
Answer: B

Question: A 30-year-old African American woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a dry cough and chest discomfort for the past 3 days. During this period, the patient has had headaches, muscle aches, joint pain, fever, and chills. Ten days ago, she was hiking with her family in Mississippi. The patient has asthma that is treated with an albuterol inhaler. Her mother has a lung disease treated with methotrexate. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows slight wheezes throughout both lung fields. Laboratory studies and urinalysis are positive for polysaccharide antigen. Bronchoalveolar lavage using silver/PAS-staining shows macrophages filled with a dimorphic fungus with septate hyphae. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Legionella pneumophila infection
B: Aspergillus fumigatus infection
C: Darling's disease
D: Histoplasma capsulatum infection
E: Small form histoplasmosis

Question: A 30-year-old African American woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a dry cough and chest discomfort for the past 3 days. During this period, the patient has had headaches, muscle aches, joint pain, fever, and chills. Ten days ago, she was hiking with her family in Mississippi. The patient has asthma that is treated with an albuterol inhaler. Her mother has a lung disease treated with methotrexate. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows slight wheezes throughout both lung fields. Laboratory studies and urinalysis are positive for polysaccharide antigen. Bronchoalveolar lavage using silver/PAS-staining shows macrophages filled with a dimorphic fungus with septate hyphae. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Legionella pneumophila infection
B: Aspergillus fumigatus infection
C: Darling's disease
D: Histoplasma capsulatum infection
E: Small form histoplasmosis

D

Question: A 59-year-old woman presents to the office for a routine examination. She is in generally good health and does not take any medications. She works as a legal secretary and has smoked about 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years. She exercises 30 minutes most days of the week. She denies any chest pain, shortness of breath, or orthopnea. On physical examination, her heart rate is 70/min and regular. Her respiratory rate is 12/min. Blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg in the right arm and 138/80 mm Hg in the left arm. Her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. There is a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left sternal border. There are no gallops or rubs. She has no edema in her lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
Options: A: Send the patient home.
B: Refer the patient for a chemoprophylaxis.
C: Order a ventilation/perfusion lung scan.
D: Order a chest x-ray.
E: Schedule the patient for cardiac valve replacement.
Answer: A

Question: A 28-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of progressive dyspnea and fatigue. He denies any fever, cough, or night sweats. Four months ago, he was treated for a superficial skin infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 10 days. Over the past 3 weeks, the patient has noticed the onset of severe, stabbing retrosternal chest pain that radiates to the back and upper arms, along with shortness of breath. Fatigue has also become more pronounced. Nine days ago, the patient developed a periungual lesion. On examination, temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Examination of the lungs shows dullness to percussion and crackles over the right upper lung. Apical systolic murmurs are heard best at the left sternal border with radiation to the axilla and posteriorly over the scapula. A tender lesion is seen on the proximal nail fold of the left index finger.
Laboratory studies show:
WBC 12,000/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 75%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 5%
Platelet count 300,000/mm3
ESR 50 mm/h
C-reactive protein 5 mg/L
Antinuclear antibody titer 1:1280  (positive)
Anti-dsDNA antibody titer 1:640 (positive)
RF 1:1280 (positive)
Anti-Smith antibody titer 1:640 (positive)
Anti-Ro antibody titer 1:320 (positive)
Anti-La antibody titer 1:320 (positive)
Lupus anticoagulant titer 2 sec
Cardiovascular
Electrocardiogram: normal
Transthoracic echocardiogram: pericardial effusion
Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Initiate steroids for treatment of lupus.
B: Steroids
C: Valvuloplasty for valve disease
D: Aspiration of pericardial fluid
E: Tube thoracostomy
Answer: C,D,E

Question: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because he has not been able to walk since waking up that morning. His mother said that when he tried to get out of bed that he was unable to stand without support. He also complained of prickling in his hands and feet. Three weeks ago, he had a fever, dry cough, and a sore throat. The fever and sore throat subsided a week after they began, but the cough is persisting. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. His vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is severe weakness in both lower extremities and mild sensory loss of the hands and feet. Knee and ankle jerk reflexes are absent. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.0 g/dL
Leukocyte count 6000/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 64%
Eosinophils 2%
Lymphocytes 26%
Monocytes 7%
Platelet count 160,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 27 mm/h
Serum
Na+ 138 mEq/L
Cl- 101 mEq/L
K+ 4.9 mEq/L
HCO3- 26 mEq/L
Ca2+ 9.7 mg/dL
Creatine kinase 93 U/L
A lumbar puncture is performed; cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 2/mm3, a glucose concentration of 60 mg/dL, and a protein concentration of 91 mg/dL. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in treatment? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)
B: Ig iv (iv immunoglobulins)
C: Botulism antitoxin
D: Iv ig (ivig therapy)
E: Intravenous ig (ivig therapy)

Question: A 24-year-old woman presents to a physician with a history of exposure to a close friend who was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. She was told by her friend that she need to see a physician because she needs to be treated as well, even if she is not having symptoms yet. She currently denies any headaches, vision changes, nausea or vomiting, or neck stiffness. Her physical exam is within normal limits. Her vital signs are stable. She is prescribed rifampin for prophylaxis with specific instructions on when to follow up if symptoms develop. When asked about the possibility of pregnancy, she mentioned that she uses combination oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for contraception. The physician suggested that her husband should use condoms for contraception as she requires antibiotic therapy. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the need for additional contraception? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of estrogens.
B: Rifampin inhibits CYP3A4, which metabolizes progestins.
C: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of progestins.
D: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of estrogens.
E: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of progestins.
Answer: A, C

Question: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 7-day history of nausea and vomiting. Over the past 2 days, he has also been feeling weak and tired. When standing up after sitting for a while, he feels dizzy. He says he has to go to the bathroom more often than usual, and that he is urinating “a normal amount” each time. He has not had diarrhea. He has hypertension, for which he has been taking hydrochlorothiazide for the past 6 months. He drinks 9 glasses of water per day and takes his medication regularly. He is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 106/54 mm Hg, and pulse is 92/min. Physical examination shows whitening of the tongue. Skin that is pinched on the back of the hand retracts after 5 seconds. On mental status examination, his speech is slowed; he is oriented to person, place, and time. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Na+ 150 mEq/L
Cl− 97 mEq/L
K+ 3.6 mEq/L
HCO3− 30 mEq/L
Osmolality 354 mOsm/kg
Hemoglobin A1C 10.5%
Urine
Osmolality 400 mOsm/kg
. Which of the following are the most likely explanation for these findings? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Osmotic diuresis
B: Osmotic diuresis
C: Gastroinstestinal fluid loss
D: Osmotic diureses
E: Osmotic flow urinary
