Question: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of tonic-clonic seizures. He denies nausea, vomiting, constipation, abdominal pain, heartburn, or flatulence. A classmate saw the first seizure and brought the patient to the emergency department. He has not had any seizures since. He is afebrile and has normal vital signs. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft, and there are no palpable masses. The patient is not taking any medications. Which of the following are the most appropriate initial laboratory studies in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Complete blood count 
B: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 
C: Electrolytes with magnesium and phosphorus
D: Basic metabolic panel 
E: Liver function tests 
Answer: A,C

Question: A 26-year-old woman presents to a clinic for a routine examination. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 59 kg (130 lb); BMI is 23.6 kg/m2. Her pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. No abnormal pregnancies or comorbidities are noted on her family history. On physical examination, she is afebrile and alert. No dermatological lesions are noted. There is no pallor, cyanosis, clubbing, or spider angioma. Examination of the respiratory, cardiovascular, and musculoskeletal systems is within normal limits. Her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Her heart rate is 90 bpm, and her thyroid gland is normal in size. On abdominal examination, there is no ascites, and the liver and spleen are not palpably enlarged. Neurological examination shows no focal deficits. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.0 g/dL
Hematocrit 34%
Total WBC 12,500/mm3
RBC morphology Microcytic and hypochromic
Serum
Albumin 4.5 g/dL
Transferrin saturation 30%
Vitamin B12 250 pg/mL
Serum ferritin 32 mcg/L
Iron 70 mcg/dL
TIBC 400 mcg/dL
Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Iron deficiency anemia
B: Thalassemia minor
C: Vitamin B12 deficiency anemia
D: Vitamin B12 deficiency anemia
E: Folate deficiency anemia
Answer: B,C,D,E

Question: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain. The patient states she has pain in the right side of her abdomen which started yesterday and has been worsening. She has experienced a few episodes of vomiting and diarrhea during this time. The patient has a past medical history of constipation which is treated with fiber supplements. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, you note a young woman who appears to be in pain. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. Abdominal exam is notable for right lower quadrant pain that is reproducible when the left lower quadrant is palpated. The patient is given morphine. Which of the following are the next best step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: ß-hCG
B: ß-hCG
C: CT scan
D: Stool occult blood
E: Ultrasound

Question: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of the onset of worsening cough over the past 3 weeks. She has had shortness of breath on exertion and requires pillows at night for sleeping. She also reports a painful skin rash with black scabs on her palms. She has no history of lung disease or asthma. She smokes 10 cigarettes per day. Physical examination shows clear lungs to auscultation. Marked palmar keratoses are noted. Wheezing is not heard. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Lichen sclerosus
B: Asthma
C: Lung cancer
D: Systemic lupus erythematosus
E: Rheumatoid arthritis
Answer: A,B,D

Question: A 55-year-old man presents into the emergency department with a severe cough and difficulty breathing. He says that he finds himself out of breath after taking a few steps, and has to sit down and rest, in order to continue. He also says that, at night, he has the greatest difficulty in breathing and usually uses at least 3 pillows to sleep comfortably. He mentions a cough that appears only at night, but which is persistent enough to wake him up from sleep. He mentions that he has had a ‘heart attack’ 5 years ago. He also says that he continues to consume alcohol on a regular basis even though his doctor has advised against it. He has brought his lab reports which he had recently got done on the suggestions of his family doctor. An electrocardiogram (ECG) and a chest X-ray are found. Which of the following are the next step in this patient’s management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Angiography
B: Computed Tomography (CT)
C: Echocardiogram
D: Echocardiography
E: Cardiac biopsy

Question: A 22-year-old man presents to the medical clinic after getting bit in the hand by a stray dog 2 days ago. The patient has no past medical history and takes no prescription medications. He does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. The patient’s vitals are currently within normal limits. On examination, the physician notices 2 clean puncture wounds with localized cellulitis. Capillary refill is 2 seconds. Sensorimotor evaluation of the hand is without deficits. Which of the following are the most appropriate treatment choice for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Amoxicillin-potassium clavulanate combination
B: Amoxicillin-clavulanate
C: Acid amoxycillin clavulanic

Question: A 46-year-old male was recently diagnosed with metastatic prostate cancer. His symptoms include dysuria, hesitancy, urgency, and terminal hematuria. Multiple metastases were noted in his abdomen and lymph nodes, as well as in both lungs. His prostate-specific antigen level is 100 ng/mL. A bone scan was negative. Which of the following management options is most appropriate? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Flutamide
B: Docetaxel
C: Cisplatin
D: Estramustine phosphate
E: Cabozantinib
Answer: E

Question: A 27-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a general checkup. She has been doing well in school and has no complaints. The patient has a past medical history of asthma which is controlled with albuterol. She is currently sexually active but states that she uses birth control. She has many friends and states that her mood is typically positive. The patient's last pap smear was 1 year ago. Her father died of colon cancer at the age of 68, and her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 65. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 147/108 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient's BMI is 19 kg/m^2. Physical exam demonstrates a normal S1 and S2, normal breath sounds, and an abdominal exam that is within normal limits. Which of the following are the best next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Discontinue birth control and placed an intrauterine device
B: Discontinue birth control and place an intrauterine device
C: Discontinue birth control and placement an intrauterine device
D: Pregnancy test
E: Discontinue birth control and place an intrauterine device

Question: A 43-year-old man comes to the office for examination 10 days after injuring his right knee while playing basketball. Examination at that time revealed a right knee effusion with tenderness and pain over the medial joint line. Radiographs are negative. He has been using ibuprofen for the pain, but his pain continues. Today, on examination, his right knee is normal in appearance with no swelling. He has a small effusion. He has 10° of flexion contracture of the right knee and 10° of extension lag. He also has tenderness and pain over the medial joint line. Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Posterior cruciate ligament tear
B: Medial meniscus tear
C: Medial collateral ligament sprain
D: Osteoarthritis
E: Iliotibial band syndrome
Answer: D

Question: A 6-month-old boy presents to a pediatrician for the evaluation of recurrent bacterial infections. He has a history of a variety of bacterial infections since birth. Physical examination reveals light-colored skin with silver-colored hair. The pediatrician suspects an immunodeficiency disorder and decides to order several tests. Study of the boy’s neutrophils reveals that they contain large cytoplasmic vacuoles. Genetic studies show a mutation in the LYST gene. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)
B: Common variable immunodeficiency
C: Chediak-Higashi syndrome
D: Congenital thymic aplasia
E: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency–1

Question: A 17-year-old woman presents to the clinic with bilateral lower extremity swelling that has been present for 5 months. Over the past 2 weeks, she has also experienced increased dyspnea on exertion and dyspnea at rest. She is in no acute distress. On physical examination, there is moderate-to-severe edema of the bilateral lower extremities and feet. Findings on neurological examination are normal. Initial laboratory studies are as follows:
 Hemoglobin: 10.2 g/dL
 Hematocrit: 30%
 Serum sodium: 131 mEq/L
 Serum potassium: 3.5 mEq/L
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 40 mg/dL
 Serum creatinine: 2.5 mg/dL
 Urinalysis: 2+ protein
 Which of the following are the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Nephrotic syndrome
B: Acute glomerulonephritis
C: Acute renal failure
D: Obstructive nephropathy
E: Pyelonephritis
Answer: A

Question: An 18-year-old woman presents to a physician because of a 2-day history of shortness of breath. She has had a left-sided headache for 4 days, and there is a rash over her legs and abdomen. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 110/min, and BP is 120/80 mm Hg. Examination of the heart and lungs are normal. Her spleen is not palpable. Examination of the skin shows a nonpruritic maculopapular rash that is blanchable. Blood tests results reveal leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows the following results: pressure 550 mm H2O, color slightly xanthochromic, RBC count 1500/μL, WBC count 120/μL, and protein 105 mg/dL. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's illness? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Meningoencephalitis
B: Bacterial meningitis
C: Subarachnoid hemorrhage followed by meningitis
D: Viral meningitis
E: Guillain-Barré syndrome
Answer: E

Question: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after an episode of altered mental status. She was at a party when she suddenly fell to the floor. Her friends state that she was not responsive and was acting oddly. After the episode, the patient seemed confused and had no memory of the event. The patient has a past medical history of substance abuse, depression, and anxiety. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 117/69 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam reveals a girl who seems confused and responds to questions slowly. Her gait is stable, and she demonstrates 5/5 strength in her upper and lower extremities. Laboratory values and a urine dipstick test are performed as seen below:

Toxicology:
Benzodiazepines: Positive
Marijuana: Positive
Cocaine: Negative
Phencyclidine: Negative

Urine Dipstick:
Appearance: Dark
Red blood cells: Positive
Glucose: Negative

. Which of the following are the best next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Diazepam
B: Electroencelphalography
C: IV fluids and mannitol
D: Phenytoin
E: Supportive therapy and observation

Question: A 67-year-old woman presents to the clinic with multiple hematomas over her body. The lesions are most noticeable on her lower extremities and buttocks. There are no associated joint symptoms, weakness, rash, dysphagia, palpitations, nausea, or vomiting. She also reports bruising with minor trauma. The patient denies taking any medications. On examination, there is extensive ecchymosis on the lower extremities, buttocks, and forearms. There are no petechiae. Her gait and strength are normal. Initial laboratory work reveals the following:

Hemoglobin: 12.5 g/dL
Hematocrit: 36.8%
Platelets: 50,000/uL
Prothrombin time (PT): 14.2 seconds (INR 1.2)
Partial thromboplastin time (PTT): 34 seconds
Fibrinogen: 250 mg/dL
. Which of the following is not the best next step in management of the patient's thrombocytopenia? There may be one or more correct choices.

B: Tranexamic acid

Question: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of difficulty sleeping and fatigue. Menses occur at irregular 35- to 50-day intervals and last 3–7 days. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. She has had an unintentional 10-kg (22-lb) weight gain over this period. She also reports decreased sexual desire and increased hair growth on her face and arms. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, increased pigmented hair over the chin and upper lip, and purple stretch marks on the abdomen. She has a prominent hump of fat over the base of the dorsum of her neck and decreased proximal muscle tone and strength. Serum studies show:
Na+ 154 mEq/L
K+ 2.8 mEq/L
Cl- 103 mEq/L
HCO3- 30 mEq/L
Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL
Glucose 236 mg/dL
ACTH 2 pg/mL (N = 7–50)
. Which of the following are the most appropriate treatment for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Adrenalectomy
B: Adrenalectomy
C: Polychemotherapy and radiation therapy
D: Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy
E: Partial nephrectomy

Question: A 50-year-old man with a 5-year history of asthma comes to the physician because of gradually increasing dyspnea over the past 3 months. He also has a progressive non-productive cough. The patient has a 10-year history of cigarette smoking (one pack/day). His mother has mild asthma. On physical examination, the respiratory rate is 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. There are diffuse expiratory wheezes throughout both lung fields. Peak expiratory flow rate is 230 L/min. The patient has a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss over the past year. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 45%
Hemoglobin 13.5 g/dL
Leukocyte count 9500/mm3
Differential:
Neutrophils 61%
Lymphocytes 30%
Eosinophils 6%
Basophils 1%
Serum studies:
Sodium 137 mEq/L
Potassium 4.0 mEq/L
Chloride 103 mEq/L
Bicarbonate 25 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen 15 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.3 mg/dL
Glucose 98 mg/dL
Which of the following are the most appropriate treatment for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Recombinant human interleukin-2
B: Prednisone 40 mg orally once a day
C: Salmeterol 50 µg orally twice a day
D: Theophylline 400 mg orally twice a day
E: Cromolyn sodium 40 mg orally four times a day
Answer: D

Question: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of worsening dysphagia and hoarseness. He has had weight loss of 10 kg (22 lb) over the past 3 months. He has had no cough, hemoptysis, odynophagia, or pyrosis. He has a long history of gastroesophageal reflux disease for which he takes ranitidine 150 mg twice daily. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He appears chronically ill. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Examination of the head and neck shows mild cachexia. There is laryngeal tenderness but no thyromegaly or palpable lymph nodes. Findings on respiratory examination are normal. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Chest and barium esophagram findings are shown. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Upper endoscopy
B: Esophagram
C: PET scanning of the oropharynx
D: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD)
E: Flexible laryngoscopy
Answer: B,C

Question: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and vomiting for 8 hours. He has had around 3–4 episodes of greenish colored vomit during this period. He has major depressive disorder with psychosis. His mother has Graves' disease. Current medications include sertraline and haloperidol. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. He is diagnosed with acute appendicitis and is taken to the operating room for an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy. The appendix is gangrenous and perforated with purulent fluid in the pelvis. Just after the appendiceal base is ligated, the patient shows muscle rigidity and profuse diaphoresis. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 146/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The end-tidal CO2 is 85 mm Hg. Which of the following are the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Propranolol
B: Dantrolene
C: Bromocriptine
D: Dantrolene
E: Surgical embolectomy

Question: A 62-year-old man with a history of osteoarthritis and hypertension presents to the office with a 3-day history of increasing lower back and left leg pain. The pain is not relieved with rest or over-the-counter pain medications. He also complains of numbness on the dorsum of the foot and the plantar surface of the toes of the left foot. Bowel and bladder function are normal. The patient has been taking naproxen for 6 days. He denies any history of fever, chills, or urinary symptoms. Physical examination shows a temperature of 38.6°C (101.5°F), heart rate 84/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg. The examination of the back shows tenderness over the L4–L5 facet joint. Range of motion of the lumbar spine is decreased. Sensation is diminished in the S1 distribution on the left. Reflexes are normal throughout. The patient is able to straight-leg raise to 75° on the left and to 90° on the right. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: MRI scan of the lumbar spine
B: Bed rest
C: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
D: Lumbar epidural cortisone injection
E: Refer to a neurosurgeon for immediate surgery
Answer: A,D

Question: A 40-year-old woman presents to her family physician with a 3-week history of swollen neck. The small, round, and painless swelling, which was detected 3 weeks ago in the middle of her neck, has now increased in size. The swelling is associated with sweaty palms and soles, insomnia, irritability, nervousness, and fatigue; however, the patient does not complain of fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, weight loss, vision problems, or body swelling. The patient’s medical history is negative for similar symptoms or a thyroid disorder. The vital signs are within normal limits. Local examination reveals a 3 x 3 cm round, non-tender, non-fluctuant, and non-pulsatile swelling in the anterior triangle of her neck. The patient carries a total white blood cell count of 10,200/mm3, including 70% neutrophils, 30% lymphocytes, and zero eosinophils.The erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 20 mm/hr (normal, 0–29 mm/hr). What are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Silent thyroiditis
B: Silent thyroiditis
C: Silent thyroiditis
D: Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
E: Riedel's thyroiditis

Question: A 71-year-old male complains of fatigue, shortness of breath, and lightheadedness for the past 6–8 months. He reports decreased appetite but denies fevers, chills, night sweats, or weight loss. On physical examination, he is afebrile. Splenomegaly is noted. Mild lymphadenopathy is palpable in the cervical and axillary regions. The patient has several café-au-lait macules on the trunk, and mild hypertrichosis is noted on the trunk and extremities. Which of the following are the most likely cause of his symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
B: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
C: Myelodysplastic syndrome
D: Polycythemia vera
E: Essential thrombocythemia
Answer: B

Question: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents with a 2-week history of pruritus and rash. The pruritus is most intense at night, and the rash is located on the trunk, extremities, and face. He has also had intermittent headaches for the past week. The boy is afebrile and has no other symptoms. He is currently taking no medications. Examination reveals multiple urticarial wheals and papules on the trunk, extremities, and face. There is no lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly. The remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits. A complete blood count is obtained and shows an elevated eosinophil count. Which of the following is not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
Options: A: Scabies
B: Demodex folliculorum
C: Strongyloides stercoralis
D: Giardia lamblia
E: Necator americanus
Answer: B,D,E

Question: The Kozak sequence for the Beta-globin gene has a known mutation which decreases, though does not abolish, translation of the Beta-globin mRNA, leading to a phenotype of thalassemia intermedia. What would the blood smear be expected to show in a patient positive for this mutation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Macrocytic red blood cells
B: Hyperchromic red blood cells
C: Microcytic red blood cells
D: Bite cells
E: Ringed sideroblasts

Question: A 68-year-old man presents with difficulty breathing for the last 3 hours. Upon asking about other symptoms, he mentions that he had a cough for the last 4 months which he attributes to his smoking. He says he had frequent nasal stuffiness and headaches over the last 3 months, for which he takes over-the-counter cold medications and analgesics. Over the last 2 months, he often felt that his face was mildly swollen, especially in the morning hours, but he did not consider it to be anything serious. No significant past medical history. He reports a 20-pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 108/78 mm Hg, and the respiratory rate is 24/min. On physical examination, auscultation of the chest reveals rhonchi and crepitus over the right lung. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. A chest radiograph reveals a mass in the middle lobe of the right lung. Which of the following clinical signs would most likely be present in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Bilateral pedal edema
B: Distended veins over lower abdomen
C: Papilledema
D: Positive Adson test
E: Papilledema

Question: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. She has had 5–6 loose bowel movements per day associated with urgency, cramping, and occasional nausea. The diarrhea has been progressively more severe over the past several days. She reports low-grade fever over the past week. Vitals include: temperature 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse 78/min, respiratory rate 16/min, blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg, and pain 10/10. Physical examination revealed: right lower quadrant tenderness, positive occult blood in stool, and no guarding or rebound tenderness. Vaginal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is not a likely cause of her condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Clostridium difficile
B: Giardia lamblia
C: Shigella
D: Campylobacter jejuni
E: Crohn's disease
Answer: E

Question: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the restrained driver. On arrival, she has a cervical collar in place and is unresponsive. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 131/76 mm Hg. Her pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. She is unresponsive to noxious stimuli. She is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is begun. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Toxicology screening is negative. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a massive intracranial bleed and a cervical spine injury at the level of C3. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in diagnosing brain death? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Electroencephalography
B: Magnetic resonance angiography
C: Deep tendon reflex testing
D: Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography
E: Corneal reflex test

Question: A 79-year-old man comes to the office with a 6-week history of progressive weakness, fatigue, and dyspnea. He denies fevers, chills, night sweats, or weight loss. He has not taken any medication, and his medical history is noncontributory. Examination shows a temperature of 36.7°C (98.1°F), a heart rate of 84/min, respiratory rate of 16/min, and a blood pressure of 120/80 mm Hg. His height is 167.6 cm (5 feet 6 inches) and his weight is 79 kg (174 lb). His respiratory examination shows mild bibasilar rales. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows bilateral fluffy infiltrates throughout all lung fields. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 10.8 g/dL (108 g/L)
Hematocrit 31.4%
MCV 92 fL
Platelet count 250,000/mm3
WBC 9700/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 71%
Band neutrophils 3%
Lymphocytes 15%
Monocytes 10%
Eosinophils 1%
Serum
Sodium 145 mEq/L (145 mmol/L)
Potassium 4.5 mEq/L (4.5 mmol/L)
Chloride 107 mEq/L (107 mmol/L)
Bicarbonate 27 mEq/L (27 mmol/L)
BUN 15 mg/dL (5.37 mmol/L)
Creatinine 1.3 mg/dL (0.12 mmol/L)
Glucose 110 mg/dL (6.11 mmol/L)
Total protein 5.5 g/dL (55 g/L)
Albumin 3.5 g/dL (35 g/L)
Aspartate aminotransferase 42 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase 45 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase 90 U/L
Total bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL (13.68 μmol/L)
Direct bilirubin 0.2 mg/dL (3.42 μmol/L)
1. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Bronchitis
B: Pneumonia
C: Pulmonary embolism
D: Lung abscess
E: Congestive heart failure
Answer: B

2. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Bronchoscopy
B: Percutaneous lung biopsy
C: Start antibiotics
D: Chest CT
E: Transbronchial biopsy
Answer: C,D

Question: A 45-year-old man arrives by ambulance to the emergency room after being involved in a very severe construction accident. The patient was found unconscious with a large metal spike protruding from his abdomen by a coworker who was unable to estimate the amount of time the patient went without medical aid. Upon arrival to the ER, the patient was unconscious and unresponsive. His vital signs are BP: 80/40, HR: 120 bpm, RR: 25 bpm, Temperature: 97.1 degrees, and SPO2: 99%.He is taken to the operating room to remove the foreign body and control the bleeding. Although both objectives were accomplished, the patient had an acute drop in his blood pressure during the surgery at which time ST elevations were noted in multiple leads. This resolved with adequate fluid resuscitation and numerous blood transfusions. The patient remained sedated after surgery and continued to have relatively stable vital signs until his third day in the intensive care unit, when he experiences an oxygen desaturation of 85% despite being on a respirator with 100% oxygen at 15 breaths/minute. On auscultation air entry is present bilaterally with the presence of crackles. A 2/6 systolic murmur is heard. Readings from a Swan-Ganz catheter display the following: central venous pressure (CVP): 4 mmHg, right ventricular pressure (RVP) 20/5 mmHg, pulmonary artery pressure (PAP): 20/5 mmHg. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP): 5 mm Hg. A chest x-ray is shown as Image A. The patient dies soon after this episode. What are the most likely direct cause of his death? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Diffuse alveolar damage
B: Ventricular septal defect
C: Diffuse alveolar damage
D: Papillary muscle rupture
E: Diffuse alveolar damage

Question: A 70-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents to the office for evaluation of his gait and balance. He reports falling twice in the past 6 months due to feeling unsteady on his feet. He states that he's had years of diarrhea and passed tissue and blood with his bowel movements and doesn't have any further concerns in regards to this. He takes no vitamins or medications. His daughter insists that he has become withdrawn and has memory problems. The patient's physical examination is significant for pale conjunctiva and skin, and a rumbling sound over the lower abdomen with hyperactive bowel sounds. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. He experiences difficulty with tandem walking but does not have dysarthria. His rectal examination reveals a prolapsed rectal mass. His neurological examination is normal. Laboratory testing reveals a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL (normal range, 13.0-17.0 g/dL) and a mean corpuscular volume of 90 fL (normal range, 80-100 fL). His serum folate level is 1.5 ng/mL (normal range, 3.0-20.0 ng/mL), vitamin B12 level is <100 pg/mL (normal range, 200-900 pg/mL), and his stool 9:00 AM cortisol level is 4.0 μg/dL (normal range, 4.0-19.0 μg/dL). A Schilling test is planned. Which of the following would be the most appropriate vitamin or vitamin cofactor to replace initially?
Options: A: Cobalamin
B: Folic acid
C: Hydroxocobalamin
D: Thiamine
E: Pyridoxine
Answer: A

Question: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of nausea and shortness of breath that started while he was at work one hour ago. He also reports lightheadedness that started earlier in the day. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin and sitagliptin. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He appears pale and diaphoretic. A 12-lead ECG is shown. Which of the following are the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Viral myocarditis
B: Acute inferior myocardial infarction
C: Acute inferior myocardial infarction
D: Saddle pulmonary embolus
E: Second-degree AV block

Question: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of nausea and shortness of breath that started while he was at work one hour ago. Question: A 22-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a 2-week history of nasal congestion, runny nose, and inability to smell or taste food. She does not feel ill, and she has not had a fever. Her symptoms began after she returned from the Philippines, where she hiked in a rural area for 2 weeks. Physical examination shows ethmoid and sphenoid sinus tenderness without exudate. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Fluconazole
B: Amoxicillin-clavulanate
C: Hydrocortisone nasal spray
D: Endemic fungal infection
E: Azithromycin
Answer: B,D

Question: A 21-year-old man presents to a clinic with a 1-week history of a nonpruritic rash. The rash began as a papular eruption on his trunk and spread to his proximal extremities. He also reports a blanching erythematous rash on his palms and soles. The rash is exacerbated by scratching. Examination reveals multiple, well-demarcated, erythematous papules on the trunk and proximal extremities. The palms and soles show a blanching erythematous rash with minimal scale. The mouth is ulcerated. The lymph nodes are not enlarged. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Secondary syphilis
B: Erythema multiforme
C: Contact dermatitis
D: Eczema
E: Chickenpox
Answer: C,D,E

Question: A 32-year-old male presents to the ED with acute-onset chest pain. His blood pressure is 157/90 mmHg and his his pulse is 116/min. He appears anxious and agitated and a careful exam reveals dilated pupils and a perforated nasal septum. An EKG reveals ST segment elevation so he is urgently taken for cardiac intervention. Upon review, this patient reveals that he has not had care from a physician since he graduated from college. In the interim he has been largely unemployed and admits that he has recently been homeless. When asked directly, the patient admits to alcohol and marijuana use but denies illicit drug use. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the agent most likely responsible for this patient's presentation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Blocking reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine
B: Inhibiting breakdown of biogenic amines
C: Antagonizing the NMDA receptor
D: Activating the acetylcholine receptor
E: Blocking reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine

Question: A 32-year-old male presents to the ED with acute-onset chest pain. His blood pressure is 157/90 mmHg and his his pulse is 116/min. Options: A: Blocking reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine
B: Inhibiting breakdown of biogenic amines
C: Antagonizing the NMDA receptor
D: Activating the acetylcholine receptor
E: Blocking reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine

Question: A 21-year-old woman presents to the clinic for management of her menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea. She has had very heavy menstrual periods that last for a total of 8 days since menarche at the age of 12. She describes her menses as flooding and needs to change her tampon every hour. She has associated dysmenorrhea and also experiences severe premenstrual syndrome (PMS) that consists of bloating, headaches, breast tenderness, and irritability. Her menstruation begins every 21-25 days. Her last menses started 2 weeks ago, and her symptoms were alleviated by a 10-day course of naproxen sodium during days 1-10 of her period. On this visit, she is prescribed a continuous regimen of 30 µg of ethinyl estradiol (EE) with 150 µg of drospirenone (DRSP) to help control her symptoms. Which of the following most accurately describes the mechanism of action of EE and DRSP in this regimen? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: EE acts as an antagonist of the androgen receptor, while DRSP acts as a partial agonist of the progesterone receptor.
B: DRSP acts as an agonist of the androgen receptor, while EE acts as a partial antagonist of the estrogen receptor.
C: DRSP acts as an antagonist of the progesterone receptor, while EE acts as an agonist of the estrogen receptor.
D: EE acts as an agonist of the androgen receptor, while DRSP acts as a partial antagonist of the estrogen receptor.
E: EE acts as an agonist of the estrogen receptor, while DRSP acts as a partial agonist of the progesterone receptor.
Answer: E

Question: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fatigue and painless bruising over her arms and trunk. She has also had several episodes of nosebleeds that resolved with compression after a few minutes. She recently completed treatment for a urinary tract infection. She has had no changes in her weight. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her last menstrual cycle was 5 years ago. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Home medications include metformin, amlodipine, and enalapril. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. There are ecchymoses and petechiae over the upper extremities, chest, and back. There is no lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8.7 mg/dL
Leukocyte count 1100/mm3
Platelet count 54,000/mm3
Reticulocyte count 0.1%
Mean corpuscular volume 93 μm3
Serum
Total bilirubin 1.1 mg/dL
LDH 80 U/L
. Which of the following are most likely to confirm the diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Serum transferrin level
B: Bone marrow biopsy
C: Flow cytometry
D: Peripheral blood smear
E: Serum porphobilinogen level

Question: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of hot flashes and sweating. She also reports that she has been having trouble sleeping for the past several weeks. She had a hysterectomy 1 year ago. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows normal blood pressure and heart rate. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Menopause
B: Estrogen deficiency
C: Thyroid deficiency
D: Vitamin D deficiency
E: Cancer
Answer: A,B

Question: A 25-year-old woman presents to the physician because she feels fatigued, has lost significant weight, and has had increased urination and thirst over the past 3 months. She is currently 8 weeks pregnant. Her mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Glucose 145 mg/dL
Serum sodium 139 mEq/L
Potassium 4.5 mEq/L
Chloride 101 mEq/L
Bicarbonate 23 mEq/L
BUN 9 mg/dL
Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL
Total protein 6.5 g/dL
Albumin 3.8 g/dL
Hemoglobin 10.8 mg/dL
Hematocrit 33%
Leukocyte count 4800/mm3
Platelet count 160,000/mm3
Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Home monitoring of blood glucose
B: Continue daily physical activities
C: Oral administration of insulin
D: Regular prenatal visits
E: Oral administration of sulfonylurea
Answer: A,B,E

Question: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a sudden loss of consciousness. He has asthma and has been hospitalized multiple times. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is somnolent and diaphoretic. Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL and a potassium concentration of 2.4 mEq/L. A dextrose infusion is administered, after which his glucose concentration normalizes and his symptoms improve. He is admitted to the hospital for further observation. Overnight, he has another episode of decreased consciousness. Serum studies taken during the episode show a glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL, an insulin concentration of 108 mIU/L (N=2.6–24.9), and a C-peptide concentration of 0.3 ng/mL (N = 0.8–3.1). Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Factitious disorder imposed on another
"
B: Glucagonoma
C: Factitious disorder imposed on another
"
D: Conversion disorder
E: Factitious disorder imposed on another
"

Question: A 26-year-old black woman is seen in the prenatal clinic for her second appointment. Her previous pregnancy was uneventful, with the delivery of a healthy baby 2 years ago. She does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. Her blood pressure is 122/72 mm Hg. Urine dipstick testing shows 1+ proteinuria. Which of the following are the most important risk factors for preeclampsia? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Black race
B: Previous preeclampsia
C: Maternal age < 20 years
D: Nulliparity
E: Multiple gestation
Answer: A,B,E

Question: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after he was found at home unresponsive. He has a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, stroke, atrial fibrillation, and a recent hospitalization for pneumonia. Prehospital electrocardiography demonstrates atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. In the emergency department, his BP is 168/55 mm Hg, pulse is 160 beats/min, respirations are 28/min, and oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry is 93% on 2 L nasal cannula. He is disoriented, restless, and his pupils are 2 mm bilaterally and sluggishly reactive to light. Which of the following are not the most appropriate treatment? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Diltiazem
B: Dopamine
C: Epinephrine
D: Metoprolol
E: Amiodarone
Answer: C

Question: A 33-year-old woman presents to the clinic for follow-up of her AIDS treatment with highly active anti-retroviral therapy (HAART). She is in good spirits and has been fully compliant with her medications and clinic visits. Other medications include prophylactic co-trimoxazole. Recent blood studies show the following:
Hemoglobin (Hb%)  11 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)  80 fl
Reticulocyte count 0.5%
Erythrocyte count 2 x 106/mm3
Leucocyte count 700/mm3
Neutrophils 40%
Platelet count 20,000/mm3
Assays also show a decreased viral DNA and mRNA burden, as well as a significantly diminished viral load. To avoid modifying the effective anti-retroviral therapy, she is started on a ‘blood improving’ medication. Thirty minutes after the first dose, the patient develops difficulty breathing, severe muscle pain, and vomiting. Her pulse rate is 120/min and the blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Which of the following medications were most likely administered to the patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Sargramostim
B: Sargramostim
C: Sargramostim
D: Sargramostim
E: Thrombopoietin

Question: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being stung by a jellyfish in the ocean while swimming. She has localized pain and swelling of the left leg. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left leg shows a dark, erythematous rash with a poorly defined border. There is no clear demarcation between the area of rash and normal skin. No tentacles are seen. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Apply heat
B: Administer epinephrine
C: Apply lotion to the affected area
D: Perform superficial skin scraping with a razor blade
E: Administer benadryl
Answer: E

Question: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with concerns regarding weight loss. She has lost 20 kg in the past 6 months despite maintaining her usual diet and exercise regimen. She has no history of chronic illness. For the past several weeks, she has also had polyuria, polydipsia, and nocturia. She denies abdominal pain, dysphagia, or constipation. Her blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg, the heart rate is 80/min, and her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis shows a specific gravity of 1.035. An HbA1c level is 14.5%. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Chronic pancreatitis
B: Hyperthyroidism
C: Adrenal insufficiency
D: Pancreatic cancer
E: Type II Diabetes
Answer: A,C,D

Question: A 62-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of difficulties walking for the past year. He has had multiple falls over the past 4 months. Over the past 6 months, he has had progressive urinary urgency and now wears an adult diaper as is not always able to control the urge to void. His appetite has also decreased in this time period. He used to drive, but his wife convinced him to stop after she noticed that he was becoming increasingly inattentive while driving. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include ramipril and metformin. His temperature is 37.1C (98.8F), pulse is 90/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Examination shows a broad-based gait with slow and short steps. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person and place but not to time. Attention and concentration are impaired. He recalls only one of three objects after 5 minutes. Which of the following are the most appropriate therapy for this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Ventricular shunting
B: Heart--ventricles shunting
C: Temporal lobectomy
D: Heart.ventricle shunting
E: Sertraline therapy

Question: A 32-year-old woman presents to the physician with a 2-week history of bilateral parotid swelling. She has also noted mild difficulty opening her mouth and increased salivation. She denies a history of pain, fever, chills, dysphagia, or weight loss. She had a normal thyroid function test (TFT) 2 years ago. Her last menses was 5 weeks ago and she denies a history of infertility. Current medications include levothyroxine. Examination reveals normal blood pressure and pulse. The thyroid is not palpable. The parotid glands are symmetrically swollen and tender. There is no tenderness of the salivary glands in the floor of the mouth or submandibular regions. Liver and spleen are not enlarged and there are no skin rashes. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Radiolabeled choline iodine scan
B: Iodine uptake study
C: Use of rifampin
D: Electroencephalography
E: Fine-needle aspiration biopsy
Answer: A,E

Question: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of dysarthria and right hemiparesis of 2 hours' duration. His wife is concerned because this is the third such episode within 2 months. He has a history of hypertension with a recent systolic blood pressure in the 200s. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 50 years. He had a pulmonary embolism 2 weeks ago. He is taking aspirin and nitrates. Physical examination shows blood pressure of 170/98 mm Hg, temperature of 37.2°C (99°F), and respiratory rate of 30 breaths/min. His skin is dry. The carotid pulses are diminished on the right. Examination of the neck shows distension of the right internal jugular vein. Auscultation of the heart shows right-sided murmurs. Examination of the lungs shows coarse rales throughout both lungs. Examination of the abdomen shows moderate hepatosplenomegaly. Examination of the extremities shows clubbing with right hemiparesis. Which of the following are not the most likely explanation of this patient's current symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Myocardial infarction
B: Cerebral infarction
C: Pulmonary embolus
D: Aortic dissection
E: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
Answer: C

Question: Six hours after birth, a newborn boy is evaluated for tachypnea. He was delivered at 41 weeks' gestation via Caesarian section and the amniotic fluid was meconium-stained. His respiratory rate is 75/min. Physical examination shows increased work of breathing. X-rays of the abdomen and chest show no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows elevated pulmonary artery pressure. He is started on an inhaled medication that increases smooth muscle cGMP, and there is immediate improvement in his tachypnea and oxygenation status. Three hours later, the newborn is tachypneic and there is blue-grey discoloration of the lips, fingers, and toes. Which of the following are the most likely cause of this infant's cyanosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Oxidization of Fe2+ to Fe3+
B: Oxidization of Fe2+ to Fe3+
C: Oxidization of Fe2+ to Fe3+
D: Inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase
E: Oxidization of Fe2+ to Fe3+

Question: A 60-year-old woman has a 2-day history of left-sided facial droop. She also has weakness in her left arm and leg. She has no headache or sensory changes. She takes simvastatin for high cholesterol. Her blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg, the pulse is 70/min, and the respirations are 15/min. Examination shows that her left eye does not close completely and the left side of her mouth does not move when she smiles. There is no ptosis. Muscle strength is decreased in the left arm and leg. Sensation is intact. The plantar reflex is extensor. Which of the following are the most appropriate initial step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Aspirin
B: Computerized tomography (CT) of the brain
C: Pulses
D: Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography
E: Carotid endarterectomy
Answer: B

Question: An 84-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe pain in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. He has had a history of Crohn disease for the past 3 years and has had his disease well controlled. Two days ago, the pain started as a mild ache but has become increasingly severe over the past 2 days. He denies fever, nausea, and vomiting. His last bowel movement was 2 days ago. Physical examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness and resistance in the left upper quadrant. What is the most likely cause of this patient's pain?
Options:
A: Stricture of the small bowel
B: Perforation of the appendix
C: Diverticulitis
D: Duodenal obstruction
E: Volvulus of the sigmoid colon
Answer: A

Question: A 26-year-old man presents to the office complaining of persistent epigastric pain for the past 2 months. He states that his pain is worse a few hours after he eats. His father had similar symptoms. Past medical history is insignificant. He is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol. The vital signs include blood pressure 120/90 mm Hg, heart rate 83/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). Physical examination is insignificant except for mild epigastric tenderness. A metabolic panel reveals the following:
Serum sodium 136 mEq/L
Serum potassium 4.2 mEq/L
Calcium 13.2 mg/dL
Bicarbonate 26 mEq/L
Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals multiple duodenal ulcers. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Gastroesophageal reflux disease
B: Gastric adenocarcinoma, intestinal type
C: H. pylori infection
D: VIPoma
E: MEN1

Question: A 36-year-old, right-handed, working woman is seen for evaluation of an acute onset of speech and language problems. She suddenly developed difficulty speaking, despite being able to speak fluently the day before. She was able to complete some sentences and produce some words, but she had impaired comprehension and orientation. A noncontrast, computed tomography (CT) scan of her brain without contrast is shown. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Cortical venous thrombosis
B: Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis
C: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
D: Cerebral venous thrombosis
E: Epidural hematoma
Answer: B,D

Question: A 75-year-old man presents to the clinic for a postoperative follow-up appointment. The patient underwent a right total knee arthroplasty 3 weeks ago. During the initial visit, he was started on ticagrelor (Brilinta) 90 mg twice daily along with aspirin 81 mg once daily for 6 weeks. The patient notes that he is still experiencing pain at the site of the incision. Physical examination is significant for right knee effusion and pain with flexion and extension of the knee. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following laboratory tests is most likely to be abnormal?
Options: A: PT/PTT
B: Non fasting lipid profile
C: CBC with differential
D: HgbA1c
E: Urinalysis
Answer: A

Question: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician after elevated liver function tests were found after a routine screening. He has had occasional headaches over the past year, but otherwise feels well. The patient reports that he was involved in a severe car accident 30 years ago. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He has never used illicit intravenous drugs. He takes no medications and has no known allergies. His father had a history of alcoholism and died of liver cancer. The patient appears thin. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14 g/dL
Leukocyte count 10,000/mm3
Platelet count 146,000/mm3
Serum
Glucose 150 mg/dL
Albumin 3.2 g/dL
Total bilirubin 1.5 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 75 U/L
AST 95 U/L
ALT 73 U/L
HIV negative
Hepatitis B surface antigen negative
Hepatitis C antibody positive
HCV RNA positive
HCV genotype 1
A liver biopsy is performed and shows mononuclear infiltrates that are limited to portal tracts and periportal hepatocyte necrosis. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Sofosbuvir and ledipasvir therapy
B: Sofosbuvir and ledipasvirum therapeutic method
C: Sofosbuvir and lédipasvir therapeutic
D: Sofosbuvir and ledipasvirum method treatment
E: Schedule a follow-up in 6 months

Question: A 55-year-old woman presents with a chief complaint of severe constipation for several years. She has a history of multiple sclerosis. After 5 days of no bowel movements, she develops nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. She reports using several over-the-counter laxatives, including psyllium, aloe vera, and senna, with minimal relief. On examination, the patient has an abdominal mass on palpation of the left lower quadrant. A colonoscopy is performed. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Surgical removal
B: Irrigation enema
C: Laxatives
D: Disimpaction and addicting osmotic agent
E: Foley catheter placement
Answer: A,C,D,E

Question: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive left leg pain for 2 months, which has started to interfere with his sleep. His mother has been giving him ibuprofen at night for “growing pains,” but his symptoms have not improved. One week before the pain started, the patient was hit in the thigh by a baseball, which caused his leg to become red and swollen for several days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows marked tenderness along the left mid-femur. His gait is normal. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and an ESR of 68 mm/h. An x-ray of the left lower extremity shows multiple lytic lesions in the middle third of the femur, and the surrounding cortex is covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the left femur shows small round blue cells. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Ewing sarcoma
B: Ewing sarcoma
C: Osteochondroma
D: Ewing sarcoma
E: Ewing sarcoma

The tonsils are not notably enlarged. Laboratory work-up shows an elevated lymphocyte count, atypical lymphocytes on a peripheral blood smear, and a positive heterophile antibody screen. Which of the following are the best management of this patient's condition? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Bed rest and activity limitation
B: Bed rest and activity restricted
C: Bed confinement and activity limitation

Question: A 36-year-old woman presents to a physician with a 7-day history of a rash on her trunk and extremities. She noted a fever that lasted 4 days and resolved 1 day ago. Although she is a sun worshiper, she denies being in the sun recently. She has a history of 3 miscarriages, 1 at 6 weeks, 1 at 11 weeks, and the most recent at 17 weeks, which occurred 2 years ago. Her urine pregnancy test is negative. Physical examination reveals multiple annular patches in various stages of evolution on her trunk and extremities. None of the patches show vesicles. Biopsy of the rash shows a minimally necrotizing vasculitis of small blood vessels in the superficial dermis. Immunofluorescence studies are positive for IgG and C3 antibodies. Which of the following medications are most likely to improve this patient's symptoms?
Options: A: Hydrochlorothiazide
B: Nifedipine
C: Prednisone
D: Chlorpromazine
E: Methotrexate
Answer: C

Question: A 36-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of progressive dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, fatigue, and lower extremity edema. She states she cannot walk up a flight of stairs without stopping to catch her breath. She has a past medical history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) diagnosed 10 years ago which was in remission until recently. Her only current medication is prednisone 20 mg daily. On examination, blood pressure is 155/100 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 26/min. Examination of the chest is significant for rales throughout. There is 1+ pitting edema in both lower extremities. Laboratory studies are significant for an elevated BNP level. Which of the following are not the best initial diagnostic test? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Chest X-ray
B: Serum creatinine
C: Brain natriuretic peptide level
D: Ultrasound of the heart
E: Electrocardiography
Answer: B,C

Question: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks gestation is brought to the emergency department by her husband. She is in active labor and has lost a lot of blood in the past 2 hours, but appears alert and cooperative. At the hospital, her blood pressure is 88/65 mm Hg, the pulse is 110/min, and the respirations are 23/min. Neither the hospital nor the emergency department is equipped for high-risk pregnancies. The patient and her husband request a transfer to a more capable center. They are informed of the hospital’s obligations under the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act and the risks of transfer. They insist to be transferred. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: After stabilizing the patient, allow the family to leave in their car to go to a different facility
B: Decline admission and refer the patient to the closest capable emergency department
C: Treated with and delivery the patient after she makes a written request - action
D: Treat and transfer the patient after she makes a written request
E: Transfer the patient only if the medical benefits of transfer outweigh the risks

Question: A 35-year-old man presents with a 7 month history of insomnia. The patient admitted to having trouble sleeping from a young age but became more aware of how much this is affecting his health after attending a sleep conference earlier this year. He is worried that his health has suffered because of this, and he is also concerned that he will not be able to pay his bills if he were to get sick. He has no past medical or psychiatric condition and is not known to use any recreational drugs. The patient arrived for his appointment an hour early because he was afraid he might miss it. The patient is afebrile and his vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals an irritable middle age man who is tense and somewhat inattentive during the interview. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
 
Options: A: Generalized anxiety disorder
B: Adjustment disorder
C: Social anxiety 
D: Agoraphobia
E: Normal worry

Question: A 63-year-old man presents to the emergency department with left-sided weakness and slurred speech which began 1 hour prior to arrival. His wife reports that he was fine when they went to bed 10 hours prior to arrival. He has a medical history of transient ischemic attack (TIA) 1 week prior to the current episode that resolved within 2 hours. He has a history of hypertension, for which he is taking no medications, and hyperlipidemia; he quit smoking 1 year ago. On examination, the patient has a NIHSS score of 6, with left-sided facial weakness and left hemiparesis. CT head scan indicates an acute left middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke. Which of the following are the most appropriate next step in management for this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Monitor patient in the emergency department
B: Perform mechanical thrombectomy
C: Administer recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (r-tPA)
D: Administer ticagrelor
E: Prescribe atorvastatin
Answer: B,C

Question: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue. She also reports generalized itchiness that started approximately 2 months ago. Two weeks ago, she noticed yellowing of her eyes. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She uses eyedrops for persistent dryness of the eyes. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jaundice of the conjunctivae and skin. The mucous membranes of the mouth are dry. The abdomen is soft. The liver edge is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. There are generalized skin excoriations. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7,700/mm3
Platelet count 332,000/mm3
Serum
Glucose 122 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 3.1 mg/dL
Direct 2.5 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 452 U/L
AST 155 U/L
ALT 168 U/L
Hepatitis B surface antigen negative
Hepatitis B core IgM antibody negative
Hepatitis B surface antibody positive
Hepatitis C antibody negative
Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows mildly increased echogenicity of the liver. Which of the following additional findings are most likely to be found in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices."
Options: A: Inferior vena cava thrombosis
B: Cutaneous xanthomas
C: Butterfly-shaped vertebrae
D: Increased CA 19-9 levels
E: Kayser-Fleischer rings
"

Question: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fever, unintentional weight loss, night sweats, and a red rash on his chest that has spread to other areas. He also reports odynophagia and an enlarged cervical lymph node. He works as a cashier in a supermarket. He had a tonsillectomy when he was a child and he denies other childhood illnesses. He is sexually active with 1 female partner. He does not use condoms because he has had a vasectomy. On physical examination, the temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), the pulse is 100/min, and the blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination of the mouth is normal. There is a maculopapular rash on the chest and abdomen. Multiple enlarged, rubbery, and tender cervical lymph nodes are noted. An HIV test is done and is positive. Which of the following additional findings are most likely to be found on further evaluation of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Decreased CD4+ lymphocyte count
B: Increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
C: Salmonella colitis
D: Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia
E: Candida esophagitis
Answer: A,B,D,E

Question: A 26-year-old man comes to the office because of fever, sweat, and weight loss. He also reports headaches, back pain, and abdominal pain, all of which have been progressively worsening over the past few days. He has no history of prior medical conditions. He does not take any medication. On examination, he has scleral icterus. The liver is tender to palpation. Initial laboratory studies show:
Total bilirubin 8.8 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 5.8 mg/dL
Aspartate aminotransferase 135 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase 188 U/L
Albumin 2.1 g/dL
International normalized ratio 1.5
Urinalysis: 2–3 RBCs/hpf, WBCs 1–2/hpf
Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis(es)?
Options: A: Acute cholecystitis
B: Hepatitis A
C: Chronic type B hepatitis
D: Viral hepatitis
E: Acute hepatitis
Answer: A,C

Question: An 18-year-old patient is visiting the pediatrician with her mother for her annual exam before college starts. Her height and weight are appropriate for her age, and she is up to date on all her vaccinations and has no medical complaints. She is doing well in school and has a part-time job stocking shelves at a clothing store. She was offered a higher-paying job as a cashier at the store, but she declined. She is very shy and withdrawn with the physician. Afterwards, her mother asks to speak to the physician alone and expresses concern that her daughter is very socially isolated and feels lonely. She is also worried that her daughter is extremely sensitive to criticism, even from family. The daughter is interested in art and music, but hasn’t participated in any extracurriculars because she says that she is untalented and thinks nobody wants to hang out with her. When her mother has encouraged her to invite friends over, the daughter bursts into tears and says, “Nobody wants to be friends with me, I am too lame and ugly and I just know I’ll end up getting rejected.” . Which of the following are the most likely explanation for the daughter’s behavior? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Personality avoidant disorder
B: Generalized anxiety disorder
C: Avoidant personality disorder
D: Paranoid personality disorder
E: Dependent personality disorder

Question: A 68-year-old woman who has osteopenia presents with a 2-month history of gradual onset of vague generalized abdominal pain. It is worse with eating and relieved with lying down. She has recently lost 20 lb. There have been separate occurrences of melena. She has no nausea, vomiting, dysuria, or hematuria. She has no history of heartburn or acid reflux, and she denies uses of NSAIDs, alcohol, or tobacco. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mm Hg. Her abdomen is soft, but there is some epigastric and periumbilical tenderness. Laboratory studies show:
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL
Sodium 142 mEq/L
Potassium 4.2 mEq/L
Chloride 100 mEq/L
Unconjugated bilirubin 1.1 mg/dL
Conjugated bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 140 U/L
AST 30 U/L
ALT 35 U/L
Amylase 50 U/L
Gastric acid secretion
Basal 2 mEq/h
Peak after histamine 6 mEq/h
Gastrin 275 pg/mL
(normal < 200 pg/mL)
Secretin 29 pg/mL
(normal < 30 pg/mL)
Which of the following are not the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Retained antral gastritis
B: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
C: Adenocarcinoma of the stomach
D: Duodenal ulcer
E: Peptic ulcer disease
Answer: D,E

Question: A 61-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of a productive cough and worsening shortness of breath. He has had frequent episodes of a productive cough over the past 3 years. He had smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 1 year ago. He appears distressed. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Chest auscultation reveals diffuse wheezes and coarse crackles. A chest x-ray shows increased lung lucency bilaterally and flattening of the diaphragm. Which of the following are the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Prednisone and albuterol
B: Albuterol and montelukast
C: Prednisone and tiotropium
D: Albuterol and theophylline
E: Roflumilast and prednisone

Question: A 24-year-old primigravida at 35 weeks of gestation presents to an outpatient obstetrics and gynecology clinic for a routine prenatal visit. During routine urine studies, significant proteinuria and hematuria were noted. She denies any symptoms of urinary tract infections, including dysuria, frequency, or urgency. The patient maintains an otherwise healthy lifestyle, exercises regularly, and has followed up for routine prenatal care visits. A diagnosis of preeclampsia is made. Which of the following is the preferred treatment to limit exacerbations?
Options: A: Indomethacin
B: Corticosteroids
C: Magnesium sulfate
D: IV fluids
E: Methyldopa
Answer: E

Question: A junior orthopaedic surgery resident is completing a carpal tunnel repair with the department chairman as the attending physician. During the case, the resident inadvertently cuts a flexor tendon. The tendon is repaired without complication. The attending tells the resident that the patient will do fine, and there is no need to report this minor complication that will not harm the patient, as he does not want to make the patient worry unnecessarily. He tells the resident to leave this complication out of the operative report. Which of the following are the correct next action for the resident to take? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Disclose the error to the patient but leave it out of the operative report
B: Disclose the error to the patient and put it in the operative report
C: Tell the attending that he cannot fail to disclose this mistake
D: Tell the attending that he cannot failing to disclose this mistakes
E: Refuse to dictate the operative report

Question: A 21-year-old old college student is brought to the emergency department by his roommates because he has been "acting strangely." Over the last 7 months, he has claimed to hear voices telling him that he must prepare for the end of the world. He used to be a straight A student but started failing exams recently due to his erratic behavior. Furthermore, there are periods of time where he does not sleep for several days and redecorates the entire apartment. During those times he spends huge amounts of money on online shopping. These periods usually last for about 2 weeks and happen every other month. On physical exam, he appears unkept and irritated. He seems to respond to invisible stimuli, and he jumps from topic to topic without clear focus. Which of the following are most consistent with this patient's presentation? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Bipolar with psychotic features
B: Disorder schizoaffective
C: Schizoaffective disorder
D: Schizoaffective-type schizophrenia
E: Affective disorder schizo

Question: A 50-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for treatment of a chronic lower respiratory tract infection that has not responded to prior treatment with macrolides or beta-lactam antibiotics. On physical examination, the physician finds chronic wheezing and rales in all lung fields. The patient's chest X-ray shows hyperinflation and thickening of the bronchial airways. Which of the following is the most likely underlying disorder?
Options: A: Cystic fibrosis
B: Bronchiectasis
C: Tuberculosis
D: Pleurisy
E: Asthma
Answer: B

Question: A 36-year-old G2P2 woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents for evaluation of sudden onset of left-sided abdominal pain. Her prenatal course has been unremarkable to date, and she is not taking any medications. Physical examination reveals tenderness and hypoactive bowel sounds in the left lower quadrant. Which of the following is not likely to be the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Rectus sheath hematoma
B: Ectopic pregnancy
C: Ovarian cyst torsion
D: Ureterocele
E: Crohn disease
Answer: E

Question: A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute onset neck pain and enlargement. Specifically, he reports that he has been experiencing pain and swelling of the anterior portion of his neck near the midline. Otherwise, he says that he has been getting tired easily and feels cold often. Physical exam reveals a painful diffusely enlarged thyroid gland with many small nodules. A biopsy is obtained showing diffuse cellular hyperplasia with areas of focal colloid hyperplasia. Given these findings, the patient is started on appropriate therapy, and the neck mass becomes smaller over time. Which of the following are most likely associated with the cause of this patient's symptoms? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: HLA-B8 risk factor
B: Increased 131-iodine uptake
C: Iodine deficiency
D: Iodine deficiency
E: Iodine deficiency

Question: A 46-year-old female patient presents to her physician with a complaint of 3 weeks of right ankle pain and swelling. For the past week, she has been having difficulty walking. She has a history of type 2 diabetes for the past 5 years but denies taking any medications for it. On physical examination, the patient is afebrile and has normal vital signs. There is swelling and erythema extending around the distal right ankle joint. There is pitting edema of the right foot and toes. Her range of motion is limited by pain. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next steps in this patient's treatment? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Nitrofurantoin
B: Amoxicillin--clavulanate
C: Aspirin
D: Cefprozil
E: Metronidazole
Answer: A,B,C,D,E

Question: A 22-year-old woman with a history of asthma visits her physician for worsening shortness of breath. She states that she feels as though her “lungs are falling apart,” noting that her lung function has been steadily deteriorating. She further states that she has visited a number of other physicians who prescribed several different types of inhalers, but she feels that they have not helped her control her asthma exacerbations. She has experienced 4 episodes of pneumonia in the last 3 years and often suffers from “random” bouts of excessive coughing and wheezing. When asked if her coughing episodes produce sputum, she states, “Yes, the stuff is greenish with specks of red in it.” She also states that her coughing and wheezing episodes are associated with fever, malaise, and occasional expectoration of brown mucous plugs. The vital signs include: blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg, pulse 66/min, respiratory rate 26/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the patient appears frail-looking and in moderate respiratory distress. Auscultation reveals inspiratory crackles in the right lung base and coarse breath sounds in the bilateral upper lung lobes. Chest radiograph, as shown below, reveals atelectasis in the right lung base. There are also branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows” (noted by the arrow in the image). Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels are elevated. Which of the following are the most appropriate therapy in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Isoniazid
B: Fluconazole
C: Prednisone
D: Prednisone
E: Prednisone

Question: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department after he was found unresponsive at home by his roommate. The patient was last seen 8 hours prior, at which time he was intoxicated. The patient's roommate reports that an empty bottle of opiate medication was also found in the patient's home. On examination, the patient is lethargic, but arousable to painful stimuli. He is intubated to protect his airway and receives naloxone. After intubation, he becomes bradycardic and hypotensive. Which of the following are the most likely underlying medical condition in this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Opiate overdose
B: Alcohol withdrawal
C: Sepsis
D: Myocardial infarction
E: Cerebral vascular accident (stroke)
Answer: A,B

Question: A 30-year-old man with HIV presents with a 2-day history of blurred vision, floaters in his left eye, and headache. There is no coryzal drainage or change in visual acuity. He does report feeling unusually tired for the past month. He is being treated for HIV with tenofovir/emtricitabine and raltegravir. In addition to the visual complaints, he also notes a rash on his palms and soles for the past 4 months which has worsened recently. Physical examination is significant for a nonexudative rash on the palms and soles with erythema, swelling, and desquamation, as well as bilateral conjunctivitis and blurred vision in the left eye. Ophthalmologic exam demonstrates multiple round, white retinal lesions. Which of the following are not the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Fluconazole
B: Valganciclovir
C: Slit lamp examination
D: Ocular coherence tomography
E: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain
Answer: A,D

Question: A 38-year-old woman presents to an urgent care clinic with the complaint of epigastric discomfort and cramping pain for the past 2 hours. She states that she has experienced similar pain in the past. These episodes occur mostly after meals and often subside several hours after she finishes eating. Due to this reason she mostly avoids eating. She says she has lost a few pounds in the last couple of months. She is a smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. Past medical history is insignificant except for chronic knee pain, for which she takes over the counter painkillers. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), respiratory rate is 16/min, pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 120/89 mm Hg. A physical abdominal exam is unremarkable, including examination of the abdomen. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Gastric ulceration
B: Stomach ulcer
C: Ulcus ventriculi
D: Gastric peptic ulcer
E: Gallbladder cancer

Question: A 26-year-old man is seen in the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. He has a history of diabetes and depression. He takes metformin, amitriptyline, and trazodone. The patient is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. His speech is slurred. His blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg; pulse 75/min and blood glucose is 120 mg/dL. His electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm. Examination of the head, eyes, ears, nose, and throat shows right periorbital edema and ecchymosis. Neurologic examination shows fine tremors, dysmetria, and dysdiadochokinesia. A computed tomography scan of the head shows a 5 mm right frontal parietal acute subdural hematoma. Which of the following are not the most likely cause of the hematoma? There may be one or more correct choices.
Options: A: Amitriptyline
B: Trazodone
C: Metformin
D: Alcohol
E: Motor vehicle collision
Answer: A,C,D

Question: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status. He was found on the floor in front of his apartment.
